We need to proceed with the greatest care therefore  for embryo research is a complex issue which involves the whole spectrum of medical scientific ethical  and moral issues 

It also abounds in myths and partial truths 

The first is the notion that freedom to experiment on human embryo  is necessary to help infertile couples

A recent article and correspondence in The Lancet on benefits of in vitro fertilization  raised important questions about the cost of I V F  its benefits and the ratio of cost to benefit 

Other critics of I V F point to its experimental status its uncertainty  its as yet unappraised risk factors and the divergent rates of success 

This doubt was raised in a report of the World Health Organisation 's regional office for Europe entitled Are In Vitro Fertilization and Embryo Transfer of Benefit to All 

There is a remarkably  lack of scientifically-based assessment of rates of success worldwide which has led inevitably to doubt as to what are the real success rates 

There is also growing doubt as to whether further embryo research is the best way forward  and even increased recognition that assisting fertility does not depend on I V F alone 

For example microsurgery  for women the growth of services for male infertility and new techniques of molecular biology demonstrate that the lack of destructive experimentation would not ipso facto impede the improvements in the treatment of fertility

It 's a tribute to an outstanding young officer of the Grenadiers a former pupil of Ampleforth who read modern history at Oxford and was commissioned in January nineteen seventy-three

Robert Nairac joined the Second Battalion Grenadier Guards whose colours have been trooped this morning did four tours of duty in Northern Ireland

and one night in May in nineteen seventy-seven was abducted from a village in South Armagh by seven men taken across the border

and there he was subjected to  savage assaults in an attempt to extract information from him

the talk today About Earthquakes and Buildings Shaken and Stirred

and this relates really to experiences of earthquake damage tied with the Earthquake Engineering  Investigation Team which is a British group of engineers scientists and seismologists who visit major earthquakes with the intention of observing damage and learning lessons for the future in terms of better earthquake resistance design

It was formed in eighty-two and is a joint venture between universities and industry

The team specifically consists of four to eight people roughly split between the two equally

And funding for the university side comes from research sources such as S E R C and the industrial sources for uh the industrial participants

There are eight major earthquakes listed there which have been visited four of which in the last eighteen months

I 've personally been involved in three of those

I 'm going to show some illustrations today from two quite different earthquakes the Santa Cruz earthquake in California in eighty-nine and the Australian earthquake of eighty-nine in Newcastle Australia 

The basic principles of earthquake resistant design require that buildings should be as much as possible regular and also should possess enough ductility in order to absorb the energy of the ground motions that 're imparted to them

I 'll explain what ductility is later on

But basically let 's go through those points where the regularity can be violated and thereby cause problems in terms of earthquake resistance 

First of all asymmetry is an area of concern because it leads to uh differential forces on elements in the structure such as walls and columns and leads to excessive loading on one side of the structure compared with the other

The geometry is also important for the same reason except that includes tower structures built on top of uh other buildings of different dimensions which again cause the mass not to be distributed uniformly 

There are situations where wall constraints are not continuous throughout the height of the building causing a vertical irregularity and the so-called soft storeys uhm chiefly in terms of architectural reasons in the first storey and with a building where there are requirements to enter the building which lead to weakening of those floors

garages being another example of where the first storey in particular can weaken

The ductility is present in such structures as are built in steel or reinforced concrete modern engineered structures but is often not present in brittle structures such as unreinforced brick masonry which is a typical example of the constraint in Australia 

An example of an asymmetric building showing frames and walls that are distributed non-uniformly

This is the plan view

And as a result of that distribution of walls and frames

the columns are these dots

and the the walls are here

and basically the distribution of mass and of stiffness is such that there is a separation between the two illustrated here by these vertical lines where the centres of mass of each floor and the centres of stiffness are located leading to a rotational mot motion in the building in response to ground motion and excessive forces on the cradle walls situated the furthest from the centre of stiffness 

And this is a plan view of an element suffering excessive motion on this side due to the addition of the torsion motion to the sheer motion 

Typical modes of vibration in buildings

The top shows first mode

and the bottom second mode consistent with various stiff floors such as concrete slabs and more flexible floors such as steel frames

And it 's these motions we 're designing for

And they lead to forces acting on the structural elements which are usually then distributed through the height of the building

And their origin is an inertia force a mass times acceleration effect

What we 're looking for is to design for these forces such that the vertical elements are able to withstand the load

And in the case of irregularity certain vertical elements get uh subjected to greater loads

and this makes them more vulnerable to failure causing the collapse of floors downwards one upon another

The ductility is defined as the ability of an element of a structure to go beyond its elastic range which is this initial part of the graph 

In terms of deformation it would perhaps experience a ratio of four or six times the elastic deformation

The advantage of structures which are capable of undergoing this loading behaviour is shown here

The shaded area this is the load cycle  in an element

The shaded area represents the amount of energy dissipated

And if the structure 's able to do that possibly over several cycles in a long earthquake uh and remain intact then clearly it satisfies the requirements for earthquake resistant design

Brittle structures tend to fail before they reach point B and are therefore unable to absorb the energy and can collapse 

In design therefore the forces that we 're designing a structure for and this is shown against the natural period of the structure the vibration through the fundamental mode whereby the short or stiff structure that 's to the left and the taller structure to the right the force involved in terms of actual demand would be perhaps sixty or seventy per cent of gravity

That is for a major earthquake the structure could experience loading horizontally equal to about two thirds of its own self weight 

With the ductility incorporated the design is often reduced by a factor of four to six representing that ductility ratio such that the actual forces involved are much smaller

But compensating those is the additional displacement or deformation in the structure

The dashed line shows the actual capacity and allows for uh effects that increase the inherent strength of the building above the design and safety factor

Uhm uh  testing integrated circuits

I 've taken down this short talk from  the introduction I do to one of my  third-year undergraduate lectures 

Uh integrated circuit te testing is something we teach 

We teach people to de design integrated circuits  but a a reasonable question is what 's so difficult about it 

People tend to focus on the desi design  of a circuit  and the testing is rather  a downstream activity that may be forgotten 

But what is so difficult

Can't you just  plug an integrated circuit into a board  turn on the power and see if it works 

The answer  is definitively no

They are very very complex  things integrated circuits

We have tens  hundreds of thousands perhaps millions of transistors in an integrated circuit 

and to cut a long story short basically in order to test something thoroughly  you need to access every single one and check that it works 

Second thing is that each transistor itself is a very complex thing  got complex structure with many failure modes and some of these failure modes are are quite subtle 

So it 's not at all clear whether individual transistors work sometimes

So it 's a complex interesting uh and difficult task 

Now to emphasise the difficulty  of testing a circuit 

The whole thing is actually made that much more difficult by the high integrity  that 's needed for an individual circuit  so it 's a short amount of mathematics  some probabilities

If we define P R C as the probability that an individual circuit once tested  is really OK  and the probability P B as that of a circuit board containing N of these chips  and the probability that that circuit board is going to work OK then these two parameters are related by P B as P I C raised to the power of the number of chips 

So for example  if we are ninety-nine per cent certain once we 've applied our testing procedures to a chip that it works OK  and we use such chips  it means a hundred such chips in an individual board then you find that you 're only thirty-seven per cent sure that the board will work

In order to raise this probability  to ninety-nine per cent we require that the probability that our test procedure was correct has got to be ninety-nine point nine perc nine nine per cent 

But if you cannot thoroughly test the chip therefore  the chip may as well not have worked in the first place

So it 's a  very stringent requirement 

So it 's difficult 

The  need to get the testing right is also quite urgent  because of this problem 

We 're circuit designers 

We 're going to pass on our work down to a whole stream of people who will use the product of our work

We 'll pass the circuit down to a layout technician who will produce some information that allows an integrated circuit foundry to make the chip

This will then be packaged put into the little containers you see them in

They will then be passed on to another company that will make them into some sort of product and finally go to an end customer  something like NASA or whoever

But at every stage if an error is found in the final produced item the product the cost of backtracking tends to increase by an order of magnitude for every stage down here that we go 

So it 's important that every time a product leaves one of these stages that it works properly and this means that testing has got to be right and thorough 

Now the thing i is everybody downstream here depends on this man  to have a tractable job in testing 

If this person who designs the integrated circuit has not considered the problems of everybody else downstream the circuit will not be testable

It will be He will design a complex system that the people who inherit his work cannot test 

So what we try and teach our  our students when we teach them integrated circuit design  is simply this this 

You are designing a complex system 

It 's absolutely  vital that as an integrated circuit designer you consider the needs of the people that are going to use your circuits and test them at an early stage

You must design circuits that are testable

The term clinical trial can be applied to any type of planned experiment which involves patients and is des designed to determine the most appropriate treatment for future patients with a given medical condition 

Historically medicine has advanced in a haphazard and in inefficient way

The first clinical trial wasn't  run until nineteen forty-eight and it 's only in recent years that it 's become widely recognised that properly conducted clinical trials which follow the principles of scientific experimentation provide the only reliable basis for evaluating the efficacy and safety of new treatments 

The essential characteristic of a clinical trial is that the results based on a limited sample of patients are used to make inferences about treatment for the general population of patients 

The main ethical problem of clinical trials is balancing the interests of the individuals in the trial with the potential benefit to a much larger number of patients in the future

Clinical trials are structured as for most scientific research as this flow chart shows

I 'll briefly cover the important considerations in the areas areas of design analysis and publication of trials and comment on the impact of trials in clinical practice 

There are two aspects of clinical trials which are essential for good scientific practice

The first is randomisation

Randomised clinical trials remain a reliable method for making specific comparisons between treatments

And randomisation is used for three specific purposes to safeguard against selection bias

otherwise doctors could wittingly or unwittingly pre-select patients for a particular treatment as insurance against accidental bias

And randomisation is essential to perform valid statistical tests

Most cancer trials are a randomisation between a sounder treatment and a new and hopefully better treatment

The second important factor is the size of the trial

There are important statistical and ethical implications in the choice of sample size

In general the smaller the difference between treatments that the doctor wishes to be able to detect the greater the number of patients needed

The size of the trial is decided by balancing statistical against practical considerations such as the expected recruitment of patients into the study and the limitations of time or money

Studies that are too small are extremely common and may be statistically and scientifically useless and therefore unethical in their use of patients and resources 

Irrespective of what treatment pat the patient actually did receive after randomisation on to a study the patients must be analysed in the group they were randomised to

All statistical analyses must be on an intention to treat basis only 

For tri for trials in potentially fatal diseases such as cancer the main evaluation is whether the patient dies or not and at what point in time after randomisation

This analysis can be displayed graphically as shown here

For each treatment group a life table or survival curve estimates the percentage of patients surviving any to any point in time 

A significance test compares the two curves and tests the null hypothesis

Here treatment A is better than treatment B and is in fact significantly better 

There are many patient characteristics which may predict the patient 's survival

The study of these prognostic factors plays an important role in an analysis of clinical studies 

The whole purpose of a clinical trial is to advance knowledge and therefore it is important that all randomised clinical trials should be published irrespective of their results

Unfortunately there is tends to be a bias towards publishing only positive results

There is also a danger of publishing trials with too small patient numbers which can po can produce false positive results and exaggerated treatment claims

Clinicians need to make critical evaluations of the papers in the medical journals 

The separation of patients into good and poor prognostic groups can assist in the design of future studies either as radical curative studies or studies with palliative intent only

Unfortunately in cancer research small improvements between treatments is all that can realistically be expected and therefore studies with large patient numbers are needed often in in excess of four hundred patients

Psychological reactions to torture

A four-theme model 

There 's increasing awareness of the harmful long-term consequences of exposure to organised state violence including torture

Survivors are likely to experience adverse physical and psychological effects 

Tanner and Gore Stansworth my co-presenters have developed a four-dimensional model of reactions to torture 

This model recognises that torture is an activity with complex psychological and physical sequelae affecting not only individual survivors but whole communities as well

Their framework helps us to understand reactions seen in survivors of torture in terms of the following four dimensions 

Firstly incomplete emotional processing 

Secondly  depressive reactions

Thirdly somatoformal bodily complaints

And finally there is the existential dilemma 

I need to briefly talk about a study that examines clinical evidence in favour of the four-theme model among a sample of clients who were attending the London-based charity the Medical Foundation for the Care of Victims of Torture 

The samples studied were a hundred consecutive referrals to the foundation

There were seventy-eight men and twenty-two women and the mean age was thirty-one 

Among our sample of a hundred survivors fifty-eight per cent  fifty-eight subjects came from the Middle East including twenty-two Kurds and thirty-six non-Kurds 

Smaller numbers came from elsewhere from Africa predominantly as well as Asia South America  and  Europe 

Our sample had suffered a range of different forms of torture 

They all described experiencing psychological torture

And sixty-eight per cent had also experienced one or more forms of physical torture 

Two-thirds sixty-five subjects had experienced impact violence including beating and falacca 

Falacca is a particular form of torture in which the victim is held down and the soles of the feet are whipped or beaten with a light cane 

Sometimes there may be no scars at the time

But in other cases infected wounds develop and the survivor often goes on to suffer chronic pain which may be very difficult to treat 

We also see that  forty-eight p per cent gave accounts of being deprived of either food or water or basic living conditions facilities for significant lengths of time 

Subjects also described sexual torture in twenty-three cases and other physical forms of torture for example electrical torture and torture using high-pressure hoses 

Looking now at psychological torture in a little more detail

This might involve threats to the self or threats to other people

Subjects also described  accounts experiences of sensory deprivation with twenty-eight individuals having periods of prolonged isolation and twenty-seven of blindfolding 

Perhaps most distressing of all were the experiences of hearing or being made to watch other people being tortured 

Twelve people also described going through a mock execution 

What is the evidence then for our four-theme model of the reactions to torture

About seventy-five per cent of tumours will start  within the main bronchial tree  here

And  the tumours spread from the primary site  to

They either spread locally from the primary site to within to within the lung or they spread  through the the blood system and the lymphatic system particularly to the brain and to the liver  and to the bones and to the bone marrow 

About seventy-five per cent of patients who present to their doctors will have extensive disease that is disease beyond the primary  site of the uh tumour which is usually arises within within the lung 

Uhm sadly the prognosis of lung cancer remains poor with only five to ten per cent of patients with limited disease alive at two years and only two per cent of patients  alive at five years 

Uhm untreated patients with limited disease would die in about three months 

Although lung tumours are responsive to radiotherapy  chemotherapy is the treatment of choice because as I said the majority of patients will present with extensive disease 

Radiotherapy will only treat one particular area 

chemotherapy will treat the whole body and hopefully the cytotoxic drugs will affect all tumour sites 

Studies over the years have shown us which the most effective drugs are and how much to use 

The standard treatment for lung cancer would be to give about three to five cytotoxic drugs every three weeks for about six courses 

However we 've devised a regimen which is far more dose-intensive 

Uhm here the treatment is given every week for twelve weeks 

Patients entered on to this study would be randomised to receive a standard three-weekly regimen  or the weekly intensive regimen 

This diagram starts at week nought so whilst one tends to think of the three-weekly regimen six courses every three weeks running into eighteen weeks  the di diagram here actually stops at fifteen weeks 

But if you take those patients  on the weekly regimen who finish their treatment at  this point in time here  they will have received a much higher overall dose than patients on the three-weekly regimen at the same point in time

It 's not something that everyone goes through  and which everyone  but certainly is something which everyone has an interest in avoiding 

There 're one or two further points about this uh  division of the life course which is so important to my subject and the notion of the third age generally which I shall just run my fingers over 

Now  to me  uh the immodest inventor of that particular system  the boundaries of the four ages  are  of crucial importance 

If not fixed  certainly not fixed by calendar age

There 's no calendar age above which  you  become a third-ager  a term I don't like which is certainly getting some currency because it 's a social matter  it 's a matter of personal choice 

And the imposition of calendar age on everybody  by social life and by bureaucracy is something which I think we 're right strongly to resist 

Nevertheless  the transition is real 

The ages and the transfer between those ages are to me as important as the thesis that they exist at all 

For example  if a person 's in the third age  which for most of us means they 're retired from their jobs  for those in the third age  to want a job  to take back  not simply the rewards  but the trammels of the second age  is in a way  to go back on the system  to deny by implication  that the third age  is a thing  that it is distinct from the second 

The membership of the four ages therefore is not as definite  as perhaps  might be expected 

And the reality of those uh  ages and their membership  is perhaps best illustrated by the example  of the second age in relation to the third itself 

For a woman 

and one of the great difficulties of  elaborating theories of this kind  one of the great difficulties is that you 've got to be one sex or another 

and it 's extremely difficult for a as masculine a character  as I find myself in looking at the evidence  to be properly sympathetic  to the other gender 

But the reality of the second age for a woman  and the importance of the transition to the third  is I think a key element in the system 

When the children have left home  when that which traditionally  though not of course  uh as conspicuously in our own time  when  in traditional vocabulary and outlook a woman has had her children  her children note  one should say when couples have had their children but I 'm trying to take the experience of women  uh as as if it were isolable in a rather old-fashioned way  their object is not to keep the family as a unit

The success of a woman 's second age  is to  watch the children grow up and go away  ending  the second experience from her point of view 

And I think it 's also in a sense the same type of phenomenon  for their husbands or for males generally 

Retirement is unwelcome to many people 

It is forced on many people 

Its  bureaucratic guillotine-like character  is an oppression  an oppression  which  is harder on Englishmen and Englishwomen than any other European as far as I can see 

Nevertheless  it  corresponds  to a very real element  in the   of male and female human life 

There is this sense  that we 're in a temporal procession  and it 's correct  to make way for our juniors  that the ve vital life stream has to be renewed  that you can be too definite about the roles attached to points in the life course 

But as I insist  they are real 

I 've talked of the  tendency of some people dissatisfied  with retirement and they may have been unjustly unjustly treated in being put there  wishing to get back into the second age 

But what is most conspicuous about the third age at least in my experience with the University of the Third Age is how little  that attitude  is found  how clearly being in the third-age  is something which corresponds to spontaneous self-image  and desire 

That then 's a point I wish to insist on  uh because it 's important I think for my general  consideration  of the thesis as a whole and the trusteeship question  uh in particular 

There 's a third feature or further feature of the ages which uh is something  I should mention because uh it 's been that the feature of A Fresh Map Of Life which has attracted most criticism 

It is that although the third age defined in this sort of way  defined as a stage of life  defined as socially created of course  although it is  in that sense  a period of everybody 's life  not quite like that because because to be at leisure  to realise yourself  to be able  to read and understand  culminate what you 've wanted to do for yourself  you 've got to live in a society  uh which can afford you  which is 

Well there are in position mechanisms  for persons to say  and institutions particularly educational institutions widely spread through society which will enable a third-ager  to live a life I 've hinted at 

And it 's perfectly possible

and I insist on that to me a rather sad point very strongly in A Fresh Map Of Life 

it 's perfectly possible and is beginning to happen  that you 'll have  countries with enough people  of an age chronological age here is being used to be in the third age  but which don't  have the money  and the institutions which would enable  that  period of life to be as described for anybody in it except for  an elite few 

It 's not generally known that the expectation of life in China  is now well up with western  expectations of life 

It 's not recognised I think  that many poor countries like China  are going to have vast numbers of persons  as dependent  on the second age as the first is dependent on them without the wealth without the transfer mechanisms  without all the  social apparatus making it possible to achieve  a third-age life

That 's an incidental point 

but it 's one incidental  to what I now wish to confess to which so many people find unacceptable 

Defined as an age of achievement a third age can be lived alongside  of this theory  as the first or the second 

If you 're already very very good at your job  as a second-age occupation  or ones we wouldn't think of that way

Well my subject Citizen Who  Citizen How is is perhaps you may think an odd one 

Citizenship by its very nature will always be a variable and contested concept  subjected to much a academic debate from Greek periods onwards 

Tonight I hope you 'll not mind if I eschew the academic and pursue a more earthy albeit reflective tack analysing the soil within which citizenship can root and thrive

And in so doing I I must necessarily be selective partial and personal given the heroic scale of the subject 

Insofar as it 's relevant I 'm content to accept the description of education for citizenship in the National Curriculum Council Guidance Paper Number Eight of that name published last November which I abbreviate thus

The aim of education for citizenship

And now of course citizenship is one of five cross-curricular themes in the National Curriculum

The aim is to help pupils to acquire knowledge and skills on the one hand and attitudes values and motivation on the other which together will enable them to explore and exercise their rights and responsibilities in the democratic society 

I 'm also happy to acknowledge even if I do not uh uh shall not be directly discussing the work done over many years under the auspices of the Hansard Society and by the Politics Association as well as the report last year of the Speaker 's Commission on citizenship which contained a valuable review of the field together with a long agenda of practical proposals

I 'm only sorry that the Speaker 's intention to be present tonight has been frustrated

But I 'm glad that others of his commission are here 

There 's also of course Charter Eighty-Eight a new non-party constitutional campaign with now twenty-five thousand subscribers which is taking up the whole subject of citizenship as indeed are a number of institutions such as Leicester University and many individuals 

Lately too citizenship has entered the party political arena

And there is today quite a scramble by each of the major parties to appropriate the word

Long may they fail 

But their interest is all to the good

For decades the political establishment has done little to admit let alone bridge the chasm of ignorance and helplessness which has opened up between the ideal of citizenship and the reality 

Although the Royal Commission on Legal Services noted in nineteen seventy-nine the pressing need for law-related education in schools and although two years before that an H M schools inspectorate report rhetorically asked what has the curriculum done to help school-leavers in legal matters of fundamental importance to adult life  Professor McGurk of Surrey University was in nineteen eighty-seven still driven to conclude his extensive researches into these issues by saying 

I 'd be happier if he 'd said what

what is it about British life

but there we are 

Maybe it was because I found much academic study of the law almost wilfully obscure and introverted that I felt for the common bloke whose benefit it was all supposed to be 

So in the late sixties I persuaded a tolerant secondary school head in Sudbury Suffolk to let me loose on a class of fifteen- and sixteen-year-olds for one lesson a week 

I wanted to find out what they knew and whether they could be interested in the values procedures and principles of the law 

I vividly remember their relief almost elation as soon as it dawned on them that what is the law and what is fair are by no means necessarily the same  and that the object of politics in a democracy is precisely to allow every citizen to contend for or support proposals for narrowing that gap 

In one leap as it were  the unravelling of that frustrating knot made the law approachable for them where it had been alien in need of their care and attention rather than their resentment amendable not carved in stone 

Soon I had each of them proposing the law they 'd most like to see enacted sorting out as they readily did the essential components of an effective statute and the basic rules of drafting 

They and I were hooked

So I remain

Citizenship could rule and it was certainly OK 

Despite excellent work by the four year law and education project which my chairman has referred to funded as he said by the Law Society and run in conjunction with the predecessor of the National Curriculum Council school-leavers today know little more about the legal political and social world they 're heading for than did they did a decade ago whilst meanwhile their dependence on and indeed dominance by the law has increased inexorably 

If Parliament will not restrain its law-making zeal it should at least have addressed this state of affairs by making legal advice and assistance available to the myriad caught in its tentacles 

Yet Mr Justice Darling 's jibe about legal redress being available to everyone like the Ritz is ever more true

Legal aid is in deep crisis and our proud claim of equality before the law is hypocrisy 

Furthermore our neglect of the consequences for the public of the uhm maxim ignorance of the law is no excuse has no excuse

M Ps must know that our youngsters wallow in near total ignorance 

That is not to imply criticism of our schools overburdened as they already are with new obligations without commensurate resources 

I sometimes think s Mao Tse Tung had one good idea 

What untold benefits might not flow from requiring M Ps and their Whitehall mandarins to spend one week a year working for example in one of the thousand Citizens ' Advice Bureaux which are expected this year to deal with over eight million cases of citizen citizen ignorance confusion and distress 

And why not dispatch the senior judges my chairman excepted of course to preside in the overburdened magistrates ' courts of this land which handle over ninety-seven per cent of the national caseload

And perhaps to show due impartiality I 'd also tip out the commercial lawyers of the City and Temple to work in high street general practices and law centres many of which are opting out of legal aid right now wracked by the unviable state remuneration or local authority grant cutbacks on the one hand and unparalleled unmet demand on the other 

This experience might just quicken the hearts and inform the minds of these influential people to the realisation that their bit of civil society in Britain is degenerating dangerously 

It is not only that our criminal laws are being broken more profligately than ever

Over four million offences of violence or dishonesty last year

Up by nearly a fifth 

It 's more that all the signs are that fewer people respect the law 

Police public confidence continues to dissolve 

Confidence in the judicial process falters

Scepticism about fair and equal treatment of offenders and alleged offenders grows 

In a survey of one and a half thousand fifteen- to eighteen-year-olds which the Citizenship Foundation has just done  a quarter revealed that they 'd been assaulted though most of them were too afraid to report it and a big majority had serious concerns for their safety 

Over a half had had something stolen and also knew a thief 

Another aim of my no doubt pie-in-the-sky role-change would be to stimulate commitment to a series of reforms big and small to transform legal services with vital benefits for citizenship

For example one one might look to the appointment of a non-lawyer as Minister of Justice with the prime task of delivering legal services effectively 

One might require a plain English version of every statute plus an inte an intel intelligible resum&eacute; with illustrative flow charts

commission tip-top broadcast campaigns to explain the bones of major new laws perhaps even institute a six to nine months public service period to round off the training of every new lawyer which would be spent for example in the lower courts or on secondment to advice centres and charities 

Above all there should be sensible funding of the legal aid scheme

The seven hundred million pounds net cost last year the price of five Tornadoes is simply not enough to defend fifty-five million people against injustice 

Part of my pipedream would be to make legislators realise that putting fine rights on the statute book is barren work unless they are delivered

Who knows

That might even redirect the energy devoted by solicitors and barristers to their own demarcation dispute to their real calling 

Some may wonder whether all this is the true stuff of citizenship

And to that I unequivocally say yes 

Any attempt at inculcating notions of citizenship in our young adults is surely condemned to vacuousness unless the legal system itself broadly exemplifies its own ideals in its treatment of them 

Far from this happy state of affairs existing it is as I say in retreat 

Although the causes are many and complex one component is the never-ending cascade of legislation which last year devour devoured many thousands of pages of Hallsbury 's Statutes and Statutory Instruments

And I can't resist digressing to tell you of a not untypical paper bullet which lately shot across my desk The National Health Service and Community Care Act Nineteen Ninety Commencement Number Six and Amendment and Transitional and Savings Provisions Order Nineteen Ninety Number Two Five Double One

And all to regulate local representative committees 

If all this is driving lawyers into ever narrower deeper ruts of specialisation what hope for the public 

In fact the trend suits the lawyers rather well making them more indispensable for those of course who can afford their escalating fees

So it is that the law conceived as the protector of the weak against the strong too often today operates in reverse 

We 're getting back to the eighteenth century condition where Goldsmith observed

lords grind the poor

and rich men make the law 

Lawyers are increasingly used as mercenaries in unarmed but deadly combat 

Willingness to be so used poses or should pose a rising dilemma for my profession 

Justice is not as common a word in lawyers ' offices as it should be 

I would controversially add that quite apart from the money the undeniab undeniable intellectual fascination flowing from microspecialisation also infects those of us who try sometimes to be on the side of the angels

It can lead to a disproportionate preoccupation for example with esoteric tax issues which may affect only a handful of people invariably the already-advantaged as compared with the unattended deserts of popular ills particularly in fields of poverty law and tribunals 

The stultifying effects of all this cause even those best able to cope to groan 

Look for example at the financial services sector and the Financial Services Act 

Such an overburden of inorganic regulation has insidious side-effects 

Though internalised moral autonomy individual and institutional is so much the best governor of human conduct  it is undermined and sometimes ousted by laws which nonetheless rarely provide more than a lowest common denominator

Yet the increasing external regulation without that internal underpinning eventually leads to a descent into more law-breaking which begets yet more law

As Hirsch wrote fifteen years ago in Social Limits To Growth it leads to I quote a rising mass of codified petty regulation swollen by the need for rules to enforce rules and to counter their avoidance

He designed a torsion apparatus to measure the friction  excuse me  and found some most surprising results

For example for copper sliding over copper

the friction was at first increased by the passage of current

But after repeating the experiment a few times the friction was decreased with the passage of current 

For graphite sliding on graphite  current flow always reduced the friction

But for the case of real practical importance copper sliding on graphite current flow decreased the friction even more

and nature is not always so kind 

This work was written up in the Journal of the Institution of Electrical Engineers with a thoroughness which at this early stage in Harold 's career is extremely impressive

that Professor Barlow uh uh in the film just spoke about

Harold published eleven research papers in the period from nineteen twenty-four to nineteen thirty-nine 

Four of these were related to power engineering topics  three to measurements  and the remaining four to the validity of Ohm 's Law

It 's obviously impossible to do justice to all of these while leaving time to describe some of the later work

so I 'll simply mention one or two 

May I have the first slide please 

The first published evidence of Ha Harold 's inventive ability appears in his invention of the valve ammeter

The valvometer was already a known device

The measurement of current of radio frequencies in the nineteen thirties was usually done by thermocouple and a galvanometer 

This system had two severe disadvantages 

The thermocouple was easily burnt out and  the uh uh response was usually rather slow

Both of these drawbacks were alleviated in the new instrument 

The principle was very ingenious

The radio frequency current was passed through the filament it was a a directly heated filament here uhm superimposed on a larger direct current which provided the main heating 

The anode voltage applied was sufficient to ensure that the anode current was limited by the filament temperature

It was therefore very sensitive to any change in this caused by the added radio frequency current

This change unbalanced the bridge

and the galvanometer G in the diagram could be calibrated directly in terms of radio frequency current 

This graph shows that the instrument worked well up to five megaHertz

An important aspect of this work is that it attracted the attention of industry for G E C and Tinsley both supported it

It also attracted great industrial interest in a a discussion at the I E E after Harold Barlow presented a paper on on the subject 

From the earliest days all of Harold 's work started one of two things

It either leant towards useful device or it produced fundamental knowledge

And the next thing I 'm going to talk about is in the second category  the work on Ohm 's Law 

This shows the the very complicated bridge which Harold used to test the validity of Ohm 's Law

The last paper which Harold published before the Second World War appeared in the journal of the I E E in August nineteen thirty-nine

My aim today  is to tell you about a number of different topics that interest me and upon which I 'm currently carrying out research which concern how ancient Egyptian scribes went about their work  the tools of their trade and their techniques  and which concern the use of writing literacy and education in Egypt 

I also want to suggest  that much of this detailed work can contribute to building up a better picture of what ancient Egyptian society was like  and of how it developed 

In fact literacy is rather a fashionable subject of research at the moment both in the study of the modern world  and in the study of the history of all periods and of all parts of the world 

Egyptologists over the last twenty years have joined in a general enthusiasm for social history 

Writing in Egypt began very early 

The idea of writing was not we now think actually invented in Egypt 

However we can follow a continuous history and development of writing there for longer and perhaps better than anywhere else 

The hieroglyphic script was invented close to the very beginning of the historical period in Egypt  not long after three thousand before the common era 

The principles of the script were not taken up with enthusiasm by other countries  but within Egypt itself we can trace the history of the script

There were other scripts such as Hieratic that developed from it for over three thousand years 

During the Greco-Roman period Greek became the language of the administration  and the Greek triba the Greek scribal tradition gained a foothold in Egypt 

Changes in scribal habits accompanied changes in education and in society 

Christianity brought a new approach to writing  and the desire to write the native Egyptian language in an expanded form of the Greek alphabet

This stage we now call Coptic 

A certain amount has been written recently on the extent of literacy in ancient Egypt 

The discussion has not reached a very high plane of sophistication mind you 

It is usual first to try to guess the total population of Egypt 

This is notoriously difficult 

I would consider it presumably varied perhaps quite dramatically from one period to another 

No pharaonic Egyptian source gives us this information 

Some classical writers attempted to 

but it is unclear how much reliance ought to be placed upon their figures 

Then the bulk of the population presumably worked on the land  but exactly how many 

And then recent writers  have tended to consider what kind of numbers of people were of sufficiently high status to have learned to read and write 

But for me this is precisely the question to be answered 

Those who specialise in the study of ancient agriculture do not seem to have reached a consensus as to what food production in Ancient Egypt could have supported in the way of population  nor the manpower needed for its production and distribution 

Again Egyptian archaeology does not on the whole provide us with typical towns with villages nor cities  with complete cemeteries or ground plans to analyse 

When we do have a certain amount of data to work with  it is from untypical sites such as workmen 's villages outside the cultivated area on the desert edge or for example  which briefly occupied the capital of placename 

A recent estimate puts the proportion of the literate in Egypt at around  half of a per cent certainly no more than one per cent 

This however is largely based on the assumption that we know what kind of people were literate 

Some information on this we do have 

It is for example clear  that pharaonic Egyptian society did not contain people whose status was so elevated that they felt writing to be beneath them 

The New Kingdom royal princes went to school with the children of important non-royal families and those of  foreign rulers in a royal school attached to the palace 

Thus the king could write 

In the Middle Kingdom literary text which we call The Prophecy of Name King Name of the Old Kingdom is described as asking the priest Mehotee to entertain him with some fine words 

Offered a choice of subject matter between the past and the future name not surprisingly selects the future 

Then the king reaches for his box of scribal equipment takes a papyrus roll and palette and settles to writing down what Mehotee has to tell him 

The passage is fiction

but it implies that there was that there was nothing surprising about seeing a great king writing or at any rate able to write 

We would assume that kings did not usually do their own secretarial work and letters and documents were usually read out to them at court 

The arguments that the great mass of the ancient Egyptian population could not read or write  is partly based upon our general perception of the nature and structure of the society  apart from the point that there is no positive evidence that anyone of clearly commoner status ever wrote anything

The much greater problem is to assess the real position in society of the writers whose work we do possess 

The author of a letter for example may evidently own land or boast some administrative or priestly title

but what does this mean 

Uh let me sketch for you the normal equipment used by the Egyptian scribe 

First the writing ground 

For Egyptian scribes of all periods  the writing material par excellence was the papyrus roll 

Other writing grounds were in common use leather wooden boards flakes of limestone or broken pieces of pottery

However  many characteristics of Egyptian writing seem to have been termed seem to have been determined by the nature of papyrus and of the papyrus roll 

And the dominance of the roll was not challenged until well into the Roman period 

Uh please could we have the lights down  now 

Well I cannot here discuss papyrus manufacture 

I 'd like to mention it briefly  but by way of a  pleasant illustration

Here 's a nice one 

Essentially strips freshly cut from the pith of the stems of the papyrus plant were used

Individual sheets of papyrus were made by arranging first one layer of parallel strips laid down side by side  just touching one another or very slightly overlapping  and then a second similar layer with its strips running at right angles to those of the first 

The supple freshly cut papyrus plant provided natural adhesive properties 

And after pressing or hammering the strips cohered to form a strong supple sheet 

In Pharaonic Egypt a very thin and nearly white sheet was considered the ideal  though one not always achieved in later periods 

It is quite clear that although individual sheets of papyrus  must have sat in piles in workshops you could not go and buy them 

The manufacturer pasted the sheets up into rolls making each sheet overlap its neighbour by about a quarter to a half an inch 

Rolls of twenty sheets were standard although these could be pasted together to produce much longer rolls if it was desired to write for example a large account roll or a substantial book of the dead 

For small tasks the writing of a short letter for example the user could in theory have regarded the standard roll as stock in hand from which to cut off small pieces as required 

However in fact the practice was to work with the complete roll and to cut free the portion used after the text had been written 

You have there the front and the back  of a letter from north Sakara on which Professor Smith and myself are working 

The letter 's been written in short lines down the extreme  edge of the first unrolled part of the roll

and then when the job was completed  the strip was cut free 

The pen

Well the normal script of everyday life during the Pharaonic period was the Hieratic script 

This was a natural development from the hieroglyphic script  in which each s sign came to be written more rapidly as a simplified or abbreviated or even a completely stylized form 

Hieratic emerged at a very early stage almost as soon as we can observe hieroglyphic script  

And it became not only the script for practical everyday use but also the script for the scribes to learn first the staple of their education

Hieratic was always written from right to left for reasons that I shall try to explain later 

Hieratic was written with a rush pen 

This consisted of a convenient length about five to nine inches of the stem of the round  rush Juncus  which is commonly found growing wild in Egypt 

The writing end was usually cut obliquely with a knife  and the fibres that form the sheaths of the plant stem were often lightly chewed to achieve a stiff but almost brush-like point 

The rush thus tended to produce thick and thin strokes automatically according to their according to the direction of movement of the pen as in the modern italic hand

But this could be overridden in various ways  both by twisting the pen in the fingers and by changing the angle of the whole hand  so that Egyptian writing never showed an entirely mechanical alternation  of thick and thin strokes 

To judge from Egyptian two-dimensional pictures of scribes at work the writer seems to have held the pens some one and a half to three inches from its writing end  and not to have let the heel of the hand rest upon the writing surface uh except when  

In some ways the use of the rush pen resembles that of the brush Chinese and Japanese  calligraphy

However the rush pen was not held vertically in the typical Chinese fashion but at an angle 

The grip was not unlike that most commonly adopted by modern European writers using the thumb and the first and second fingers 

The action however we should describe more as painting than scripting 

From what I 've already said  it would be apparent that every Egyptian scribe must have possessed a sharp knife  first in order to cut letters or documents free from the whole papyrus roll  when they had been written  and secondly perhaps to shape his pen 

Scribes also often cut whole rolls in half or into thirds rather in the manner of someone slicing a baguette or  a sausage in order to produce two or three rolls with a smaller page height 

It is odd but we 're not sure what these knives might 've been like 

In museums and exhibitions you often see one kind of knife called the scribe 's knife or  of that

But I am not aware that there is any solid evidence to associate this type with scribal use 

The normal ink of the Pharaonic period was carbon black  lamp black or soot if you like finely ground then mixed with water and gum arabic or a similar glue 

This neither fades

nor does it damage the papyrus writing material 

In fact once dried in place it 's fairly tough  although if you both moisten it and rub it is removed easily and virtually  completely 

It was not kept ready for use in liquid form but as round cakes  rather like the rectangular blocks of watercolours of modern times 

It is really getting dark

Now this is but an artist 's palette with a wider range of colours 

The scribe 's palette was originally a very small wooden board

Who 's next

Once you 've mastered clutch control and can move off without stalling  you will then go on to learn basic manoeuvres 

And you 'll start by riding around a small circuit under close observation from your instructor who will be monitoring your progress  as you learn to control your bike

You will go through a series of basic manoeuvres  the routine of which will become the foundation of your road riding technique 

You 'll be taught the correct procedure for starting  changing gear  stopping  making a left turn  or a right turn  and how to ride your bike in simulated slow speed traffic 

Not everyone at the training sessions will be a complete novice

so don't be discouraged if you don't pick things up quite as quickly as everyone else 

You 're bound to make mistakes early on and the instructor is there to help you put them right 

Controlled braking 

The most important thing you will ever learn is how to use your brakes effectively 

The techniques will vary according to road condition and you will have to master them all 

Pulling away 

Even something as simple as this has to be learned otherwise you will never know the correct procedure 

The figure of eight course teaches you how to manoeuvre your bike 

The idea is to ride your bike around the two centre cones  without going outside or touching any of the surrounding cones 

It 's a combination of rear-wheel only braking  clutch control and of course balance 

It 's not quite as easy as it looks 

and the only way to be able to do this successfully  is with practice and concentration 

And mastering this technique can be a lot of fun 

Turning both left and right 

Again a precise sequence of looking signalling and manoeuvering has to be established 

The theory behind these manoeuvres is to give other road users clear indication of your intentions  and to teach you when to look and how to react to the varying traffic conditions 

Slow speed control 

Matching the speed of your bike to the differing pace of the instructor will show you how to handle your bike in slow-moving traffic 

On the road riding 

Once you have proved your ability to control your machine at the training centre an instructor will then take you out onto the open road 

He 'll fit your helmet with a radio receiver so he can advise and teach you actually as you ride 

As a beginner you 'll need to have an expert at hand for the first time you encounter traffic 

Take your time 

There 's no hurry 

And remember

all you 'll be doing here is putting into practice everything that you have been taught at the centre 

Once the instructor is happy with you riding quiet roads with minimal traffic  you 'll both venture out onto busier roads

How long you spend in training on the road depends on your learning abilities how much you already know and how good you actually are 

We 're riding here with our visors up as it was a very cold and humid day

Your training will continue until you are brought up to this standard

So first of all why do we use it 

Well  we 're interested in looking at voice production because the majority of the time we spend speaking we actually do spend voicing so we actually use our voice 

And it 's OK to look at it with making speech measurements with a microphone

but it 's much more useful if we can somehow get a direct measurement right from the larynx without  everything else superimposed on that information

So we want some kind of direct physical measure

We also need something that is non-invasive so that we can do it on anybody children adults people who have disorders of some description

So something that 's non-invasive doesn't involve having an anaesthetic for example  and something that 's harmless and repeatable so that we can do measurements several times a day many days in a row for example 

And lastly we need something that doesn't actually interfere with speech production itself 

Uhm if we had something that went in the mouth or up the nose and and down the mouth back of the mouth to look at the larynx which they do do  uhm then that would actually interfere with your ability to speak and then we 're not going to be measuring real speech we 're going to be measuring some strange interfered speech 

So  we choose the device called a laryngograph

and I want to just describe to you a little bit about how it actually works 

It 's based around a pair of gold-plated electrodes 

And these electrodes are just placed on either side of the the cartilage in the neck the larynx 

So  they 're just placed on either side and they can be secured with a neckband  so that the subject can hopefully forget about them  after a few minutes

They don't have their hands tight round their neck all the time 

So the gold-plated electrodes are used

And the electrodes pass a very small current 

One electrode sends out a current and the other electrode picks up that current  and so then we can plot how the current flows across the larynx 

And I 'll show you the type of current flow that we get in different situations 

OK

First of all  OK

First of all I 'm going to show you three different postures of the vocal folds 

So first of all in quiet breathing here we have the cartilage of the larynx and one electrode placed on either side

So this is the front  and this is the back so i it 's kind of looking at a section through the neck

And you can see that the vocal folds are here in red 

And these little cartilages at the back actually move the vocal folds when they 're going to be vibrating

So for quiet breathing there 's a gap between the folds so that the air can come out through them and out to produce speech 

During voicing they have one of two different extreme postures

They 're either  separated so that the air can flow out and we call that the open phase  or they 're actually closed together and we call that the closed phase 

And they actually work through a cycle of vibrations

so if we imagine them starting together then they 'll peel apart fairly slowly

and then they kind of snap back shut again

So they have the open phase and the closed phase 

Now if we plot the current flow with a laryngograph what we find  is that we get this characteristic waveform

So we 're going to draw a  plot of current flow against time

Now when the vocal folds are open if you remember back  to this this one here then what we can see is that the current can only flow really around the outsides

It doesn't flow happily across that air gap between the vocal folds

So that means when we plot current flow on an axis we have to plot it  at a minimum

There we see a minimum current flow when the folds are open 

As the vocal folds start to close what we find is that the current flow actually increases quite dramatically until when they 're fully closed

it reaches a peak 

and then as they peel apart the current flow drops again

and then finally when they 're fully apart it 's completely  back down to its minimum value

So we have this cycle of the vocal folds closing  closed opening and open

And we see that happening for every single vibration over time

So we have this idea of how well they 're closing and opening

but we also have an idea of how many times they close and open per second 

so we can work out the frequency or the pitch of the voice as well 

So just to summarize that then

the laryngograph shows us some information about how the vocal folds actually make contact  whether they make contact with just a small portion of them and we have low current flow or whether the fat vocal folds actually make complete contact and we have a high current flow 

And they also show us the stages in the cycle of vibration

On twenty-first of  December in eighty-five  at Tunbridge Wells  the plaintiff  tripped over a drain in the road  and fell hitting her face on the ground 

She sustained a commuted and depressed fracture  of the left  malar bone 

She sued the local authority 

and on the sixteenth of September nineteen eighty-eight  she succeeded in establishing  the defendants were a hundred per cent liable 

Since her prognosis was then by no means clear  the issue of  quantum of damages was adjourned 

That has been the subject of the present hearing 

At the time of the accident she was thirty-nine years old  married  with children  and working full-time  as a nursing auxiliary  at the Pembury Hospital  near Tunbridge Wells 

It was work  which she much enjoyed  a and to which she was fully committed 

There 's no doubt that she was highly regarded  as an auxiliary nurse 

She had been so engaged since nineteen seventy-one 

She was then a stable  outgoing person  on the plump side if I may respectfully say so  fun-loving  sociable  independent  confident  happy-go-lucky  with a  good marriage  including  the sexual side  and in general she had very good health 

One gets a good idea of what she was like from the photographs  which have been introduced into in evidence 

And the one showing her in Austrian national  dress was taken I think about a year before the accident 

She then took size fourteen clothes 

On the day of the accident  and following it  she blew her nose and her left eye  came out of its socket 

It was induced back by ice packs

And fortunately the episode was short-lived  but it was very frightening 

Thereafter for the next five years she had a truly terrible time 

In the course of this case I remarked that she had taken a battering  a description  endorsed by one of the doctors  who gave evidence 

I shall now run through  a chronology  of the major events  assisted by  uh Mr Shaw 's  helpful document 

As I 've said the on the twenty-first of December eighty-five the date of the accident  she was admitted to the  Kent and Sussex Hospital overnight for observation 

On the twenty-third of December eighty-five she went to the Kent and Sussex Hospital  and uh  the injury which I 've mentioned was diagnosed 

She was then referred to the  Queen Victoria Hospital East Grimstead  which specialises in  matters of this sort 

So on twenty-seventh of December  there under a general ana anaesthetic  there was a reduction and fixation  of the fracture of the left malar bone  with wires 

And an antral pack  was inserted  that was to  raise I think the uhm  depression  and to keep the uh  reduced bones in place 

From January eighty-six  she suffered heavy menstrual bleeding 

Though this was probably not attributable to the accident 

The uh fitting of this uhm antral pack was a  a painful business 

The pack became infected 

And on the  fifth of February  she had a second operation  when the pack was removed  under general anaesthetic 

She was discharged home on the sixth of February 

On the seventh of March eighty-six she had a chronic discharge from her nose 

On the ninth of June  she resumed  her pre-accident work  but working two nights  a week instead of three or four which she had done previously 

By October eighty-six  the plaintiff 's general practitioner  Dr Reeves  noticed an increased sinking of the depression  on her left cheek 

She had noticed in February  that an old  surgical scar  was apparently swelling and this turned out to be  an incisional hernia  in other words the uh  gut was trying to come through  the old operation scar 

On the second of October  eighty-six  she was readmitted to the Pembury hospital  or rather admitted to the Pembury hospital  for repair of the  hernia 

That took place on the next day  and she was discharged home  on the fifth of October 

The hernia was due  to uh  vomiting  as a result of the treatment that she was given for her injury  and straining while defecating  because she had become constipated again due to this  due to the uh treatment 

On the sixth of October 

She 'd obviously ceased to work  uh this time  a a and became  uh and ceased work because of the necessity to attend to this hernia 

Thereafter she suffered from thrombosed  haemorrhoids  again I 've no doubt due to the uhm  accident 

And she had to try to build herself up  for the next operation 

She was readmitted  on the fifteenth of January to the Queen Victoria Hospital East Grimstead  and had a fourth operation on the sixteenth of January  and then  what 's called a  proplast implint impl a proplast implant was introduced 

This is a prosthesis  an artificial object 

She had a lot of swelling and pain  following the operation 

And on the twenty-seventh of March  eighty-seven  she was readmitted to the Queen Victoria Hospital  and the implant was removed  under general anaesthetic because it had become infected 

By April eighty-seven  Dr Reeves noticed that the floor of the eye socket was sinking 

Nevertheless on the eighteenth of May she resumed work  as a nursing auxiliary  in the out-patients department of Pembury Hospital

That means working d working days 

On the sixth of June  her general practitioner noticed an increased collapse of the left maxilla 

On the seventeenth of August eighty-seven she ceased work on medical advice 

I 'll come back to that later when I deal with the question of loss of wages 

On the seventh of March eighty-eight her employment was formally terminated 

On the sixteenth of May eighty-nine she was readmitted to Queen Victoria Hospital where her sixth operation  took place the following day 

And then a  lyophilised cartilage implant  was placed 

That 's uhm  some sort of animal cartilage 

She was discharged home on the eighteenth of May 

Subsequently  it became infected  and the infection burst through the cheek  and discharged through the cheek 

On the eighth of June eighty-nine she was readmitted to Queen Victoria Hospital for her seventh operation  which took place the following day  for the removal of this cartilage implant 

The antrum was explored  multiple polyps were removed  and a lateral antrostomy was performed 

She was discharged home the eleventh of June 

And on the fourth of July eighty-nine  she was readmitted to Queen Victoria Hospital  for her eighth operation 

Took place the following day 

And there the infra-orbital wound was debrided  small pieces of cartilage were removed 

Discharged home  two days  later 

By then she was having  difficulty with her teeth 

A plate had been advised  but which she hasn't subsequently worn  t

two teeth had been extracted  from the upper left side  at the rear 

Her general practitioner said that her significant injury  was deteriorating 

By this time she had had several operations  on her face  and was becoming pretty desperate 

And nobody blames her 

And uh  she decided to  try another avenue 

And uh after research by her solicitors  she consulted a Mr Patrick James  who apparently is a  world authority  on this type of surgery 

And he advised  that instead of uh  these alien bodies being introduced into her face  that she should have an autogenous  bone graft taking bone from the iliac crest of her hip  and inserting it into the left cheek bone

The bones hadn't knitted properly and were unstable 

And this operation was performed on the twenty-seventh of March  nineteen ninety this year

And she was an in-patient until the  third of  April 

I shall return  to that later when I deal with the question of uhm future loss  and and her general prognosis 

Now what effect did all this have upon the plaintiff 

Dr Reeves described her as a very brave courageous woman  who coped very well 

Oh yes she suffered greatly and still suffers 

She has had no feeling  on her left cheek 

The left side of the nose  the left upper lip  the left upper gum  and two  of the front teeth on the left side are numb 

And that will be permanent 

That 's due to the injury  to the  nerve which provides sensation 

This part of the face is also paralysed  and can produce no facial expression 

That 's due to damage of the motor nerve 

And when she smiles her face is a bit lopsided 

It 's not gross 

But it 's there to be seen 

Now this may improve  depending of course upon whether the nerve improves 

But there is the possibility  of some improvement 

The left side of her face is hypersensitive  and reacts to weather conditions 

As a result  she 's had difficulty in  chewing  and drinking 

She tends to dribble from the corner of her mouth  and this causes soreness  and embarrassment 

She can't tell whether her left nostril is running  and this is also embarrassing for her 

She has a dragging sensation on the left side of her face  and feels as though the cheek is full of food 

There 's a certain amount of scarring 

But it is not gross  and can  to a great extent be camouflaged 

She has difficulty in keeping her teeth clean

She can't feel 

She 's had twitching of the left eye two or three times a day  though it is getting better 

She 's had headaches two or three times a week  for a couple of hours at a time  but she 's getting better 

She 'd had anaemia 

And there 's a scar on her hip  as a result  of the  bone graft  which gets a bit sore at times 

She has suffered  pain and discomfort as a result  of these numerous operations 

And also perhaps more importantly  she 's been boosted up  with the thought that the next operation may be successful and be the last  and then repeatedly let down  because of the repeated failures  of these operations 

She has had financial worries owing to not being able to work  or rather I should say at this stage  owing to not working 

As a result of her condition her husband became ill and depressed  and once with symptoms of a heart attack  which of course reflected back upon her 

She suffered a reactive depression 

That is a definite psychiatric illness  brought on by a situation  not serious enough to warrant a referral to a psychiatrist  but treated by her general practitioner Dr Reeves  who in my judgement is a competent and caring general practitioner  with good insight  into the psychological health  of his parents  of his patients

I beg your pardon 

She uh suffered weight loss 

She now wears  size ten in clothes  whereas formerly she wore size fourteen 

She has suffered from broken sleep and still does  and from tiredness  and anxiety 

Anxiety of course  about the prognosis for her face 

some anxiety attributable to this  litigation 

She suffered a gross loss of confidence 

She has a fear of receiving a blow to her face 

And she has a fear of  having a further fall 

She has a feeling of incompleteness  and that she is damaged and imperfect 

And this has had an adverse effect upon her sex life 

There has also been a loss of social life  for she has been too embarrassed to eat out 

To hide her facial deflects defects  she  applies a special  camouflage make-up which has been prescribed for her 

Apparently it takes about an hour  altogether  to put it on and take it off again 

It is obviously very time-consuming 

She has been treated with sleeping tablets  and from time to time  with anti-depressants 

Following her last operation  she hoped  and I think with some justification  that the injury to her face can be resolved  in an acceptable way  both structurally  and cosmetically 

Her depression  and its symptoms  are at the moment getting better 

And her state of mind will depend upon what happens in the future 

She is well motivated 

And I think she will improve emotionally once this case is over  and provided the last operation is successful 

She told me that she wants to be free of lawyers and doctors  and and to be independent to run her own life again 

And I think if she can achieve that  to an acceptable degree  then her depression will completely disappear 

As I 've said it is reactive and depends upon  how she perceives her situation 

Well what is her prognosis 

If her body does not reject the bone graft which  Mr James has done  and does not become infected  it is probable she will need a further operation  during the period September to December of this year 

At the moment the graft is too bulky  and the bone is rather prominent below the left eye  and will probably need trimming

By what is uh called an interim final arbitration award dated the twentieth of December nineteen ninety uh the owners were awarded a net sum of one hundred and seventy-one thousand four hundred and seventy point two six dollars in respect of seven instalments of time charter hire

One defence raised by the charterers uh which failed before the arbitrators uh was based upon Clause Seventy-Three of the time charterparty

Uh the charterers sought leave to appeal against that decision by su uh summons a motion issued on the tenth of January nineteen ninety-one uh

and secondly uh the arbitrators did not give the charterers a proper opportunity to present their case as regards the scope of the arbitrators ' jurisdiction or as regards their the charterers ' liability for these further instalments 

The time charterparty was for the period of a voyage from the U K continent to the Red Sea Indian ports the charter being dated the sixth of September nineteen ninety

The arbitration clause Clause Seventeen uh required the appointment of three arbitrators as in fact was done

The hire provision in Clause Five provides for the payment of the hire in every fifteen days in advance what were in other words effectively half-monthly instalments

Delivery took place on the seventeenth of September

It followed that the dates for the payment of hire instalments according to the charterparty uh were on October the first and sixteenth on October the thirty-first and November the fifteenth and on November the thirtieth and December the fifteenth

I can say here i in parentheses uh that on one view of the matter that period of arrest and allegedly when the vessel allegedly was on hire affected the dates when the hire instalments became due
