Uh a that was after what might be called a false start

Uh another matter entirely separate from present uh issues ha had arisen but then evaporated at the dispute in October

Now the nature of the charterparty is important for this reason 

When the owner of a time chartered vessel is entitled to periodic payments of hire it is important for him that he should receive prompt payment of each instalment in order to preserve his cash flow 

He is entitled to such payments subject only to the limited category of cross-claims which the law permits to be raised as defences by way of set-off in such circumstances

The owner of course does have the or usually has the right to withdraw uh the vessel for nonpayment of hire

But that is not likely to be an effective or a sufficient sanction when the market rate is no not higher than the charter rate or alternatively when there is cargo on board uh which uhm inhibits the owners uh from withdrawing the vessel with immediate effect 

It is common therefore for owners to seek prompt uh uh arbitration award in respect of instalments of hire the procedure for which London Arbitration is provides in such circumstances

A and the reasons for it uh were considered in uh detail and authoritatively considered uh by Mr Justice Robert Gough as he then was in the Costas Milos nineteen eighty-one One Lloyds Reports page eighteen 

It is accepted in the present case uh that there is a separate cause of action in respect of each instalment of hire

and I shall also assume for present purposes uh that arbitrators can also award uh the payment of any instalment of hire unless they have been appointed so that they have authority to make such an award in respect of each disputed instalment of hire 

The only uh gloss which I would uh respectfully add to what was said in the judgement of the Costas Milos is this

The phrase interim award there used is interim in the sense that the final resolution of the charterer 's liability is deferred to a final award that is to say a final award in respect of the same instalment or instalments of hire 

One reason why uh such a final resolution uh may be deferred to a final award is the fact that it is sufficient for charterers to show an arguable and bona fide set-off uh defence uh for the purpose of resisting an interim award

The fact that they failed to do so at that stage does not preclude them uh from doing so uh or from establishing their cross-claim by further evidence before any final award is made

Now in the present case the phrase interim award has been used or may have been understood to be used uh in another sense

When an arbitration is proceeding concurrently with a time charterparty successive instalments of hire become due i

in this case it was every fifteen days uh during that period

Here uh the owners were claiming the the first instalment which was paid and then the second and the third instalments of hire on the basis that there would have to be after redelivery a final settlement of account

Therefore an award in respect of instalments as they fall due is interim rather than final i in the rather different sense uh that a final award uh will become necessary in respect in in the event that they are disputed in respect of the final charterparty account when the vessel is redelivered at some future date

I assume here  uh that the arbitrators have jurisdiction only in respect of an ac of accrued causes of action that is to say in respect of those instalments of hire uh which have already become due and as I 've already said that there is a separate cause of action in respect of each instalment

It follows from those assumptions uh that arbitrators cannot have jurisdiction in fu tu turo futuro that is to say to make any award in respect of the final charterparty accounts until such time as redelivery has taken place and the sums due on the final settlement of account have been established

It also follows from what I have said uh that the arbitrators uh must have authority to make an award in respect of each instalment of hire as it falls due

Their authority or their jurisdiction is consensual

uh

and therefore the agreement between the parties must be one which confers upon them an authority which is wide enough to include all the instalments of hire in respect of which they have thought to make awards whether those awards are interim or final 

It seems to me that that was the nub of the problem uh which is has arisen in this case

The arbitrators were first appointed when two instalments were due and unpaid

Subsequently they made their interim final award uh when six further instalments  had become due further to the first instalment

It is not alleged that there was any express agreement to widen their initial jurisdiction sufficiently to include those subsequent further instalments

And therefore the question and the issue is as to the scope of what agreement should be implied in the circumstances of the present case

If there was no agreement beyond the initial agreement uh then the arbitrators were restricted to making an award in respect of two instalments of the hire which is what the charterers contend

On the other hand if their jurisdiction or their authority was extended as successive instalments became due uh then they did have the jurisdiction which they uh exercised uh to make an award in respect of the initial two plus a further four instalments making a total of six

The owners submit uh that that is the true uh analysis of the present case

They the owners were demanding payment of instalments as they fell due or became due up to the date of the award

They say that the owners responded to those claims without protest or without any protest

it was sufficiently clear

and not made too late

The charterers on the other hand say uh

we never agreed to extend the jurisdiction of the arbitrators in that way





This being a dispute about the scope of the authority of the arbitrators uh the relevant principles of law uh uhm were outlined uh by Mr Justice Devlin as he then was in whatever in the Westminster case that is Westminster Chemicals and Produce Limited against  and Leuter nineteen fifty-four One Lloyds Reports page ninety-nine 

The learned judge there distinguished two different questions between two different questions 

On the one hand there may be a question as to the scope of an agreement to arbitrate 

Colloquially uh the  uh question which then arises is

had I the relevant party agreed to submit this dispute to arbitration

But on the other hand uh there may be a dispute as in that case involved as to the scope of the authority which was actually conferred upon an arbitrator uh when the parties appeared before him and submitted to his jurisdiction

Then the relevant question is

what authority did I confer 

Uh

one notes in passing uh that the law permits a party who does appear  to do so under protest provided the protest is made early and loudly enough so as to prevent any submissio any such appearance from amounting to a submission to the authority of the arbitrator in law

The Iraqis have told the Red Cross they 're ready to release allied prisoners of war in exchange for the return of their own captured troops

The International Red Cross says Iraq is now ready to exchange prisoners of war with the allies

Details will be worked out tomorrow when allied and Iraqi military commanders meet to negotiate a formal ceasefire 

The talks which were planned for today were postponed at Iraq 's request 

However Baghdad has now confirmed that they 'll take place in the morning in allied-held territory in Iraq 

The release of P O Ws is one of the conditions laid down by President Bush for a ceasefire 

Throughout the conflict efforts by the Red Cross to be allowed access to prisoners of war in Iraq have met with refusals

Our foreign affairs correspondent Matt Frei reports

A Red Cross spokesman said the Iraqi announcement was very good news because the Iraqi authorities have been describing captured allied soldiers as criminals and not prisoners of war

Today the Iraqi government also mentioned for the first time that it intended to release them although it 's not clear what Baghdad meant by immediately

There are thought to be at least thirty allied P O Ws in Iraqi hands

Another fifty-six allied soldiers have been described as missing in action

Some of them could also be held as prisoners

The Red Cross spokesman added that by referring to the Geneva Convention the Iraqis should now recognise the right of the Red Cross to visit the prisoners  a right which had continually been requested but not granted

A thirteen-man Red Cross team has been in Baghdad for some time waiting to visit the P O Ws 

According to the spokesman a large question mark also hangs over the Iraqi demand for reciprocity

This the spokesman said was not in line with the third Geneva Convention which merely calls on combatants to perform their humanitarian duty to release prisoners of war once hostilities have ceased

It 's also not clear whether the Iraqi government intends to release the thousands of Kuwaiti civilians it 's thought to have captured nor whether it wants the immediate release of all the estimated one hundred and seventy-five thousand Iraqi P O Ws in allied hands  many of whom may now invoke their right under the Geneva Convention not to be repatriated to Iraq

Some of the immense logistic difficulties involved in a release of P O Ws will be discussed tomorrow when Iraqi and allied military commanders meet to thrash out the terms of a permanent ceasefire 

At the American military briefing in Riyadh Brigadier General Richard Neill has emphasised that the repatriation of allied prisoners of war will be the allies ' number one priority 

He warned the Iraqi command against playing for time at tomorrow 's talks





General Neill also gave details of incidents in the battlefield which demonstrated that many Iraqi troops were still unaware that the war is effectively over 

This report from our defence correspondent Mark Laity who 's in Riyadh

The allies believe recent battlefield casualties have shown how vital tomorrow 's meeting between the allies and Iraq is

These are amongst many soldiers bypassed during the high-speed allied offensive and others are still being rounded up 

Elsewhere several allied soldiers have died in minefields

and to arrange a demarcation line between Iraqi and coalition forces

British and American engineers are taking part in a major operation to remove wreckage from the main highway north of Kuwait City  the scene of allied bombing on Tuesday in which hundreds of fleeing troops were killed

He sent this report

A one-mile stretch of the highway has been turned into a landing strip 

This 'll be used to fly in supplies and fly some of the troops out

Five American B Fifty-Two bombers have taken off from a base in Gloucestershire possibly on the first bombing raid of the Gulf War to be launched from Britain

The B Fifty-Twos arrived at R A F Fairford earlier this week after the British government had agreed to an American request to use the base for sorties against Iraq and occupied Kuwait 

This afternoon officials refused to say whether the bombers were on a war mission although staff at the base were seen loading five hundred pound bombs onto the planes

From RAF Fairford our Midlands correspondent Bob Sinkinson reports

The huge B Fifty-Twos arrived at Fairford last Tuesday

Eight of them have remained parked at the side of the runway all week

Maintenance crews have worked on them every day but this morning they began loading bombs and sweeping snow off the planes ' wings and fuselage

I watched some of the armaments being fixed to the aircrafts ' wings

As they were being attached air crew could be seen writing messages on them

Then shortly after lunchtime the engines of five of the aircraft were fired up and it wasn't long before the bombers were thundering down the runway 

The first four took off at one minute intervals the fifth a little later

They threw up plumes of powdered snow as they sped down the runway

Then as they banked to the right they were quickly lost in the gloom of a winter 's afternoon

Security at the airbase appears to have been tightened considerably in the past twenty-four hours with increased military patrols around the base 's perimeter fence

British forces in Saudi Arabia have been moving vast quantities of fuel and ammunition in preparation for an Allied ground offensive

Details of the operation were given at the British military briefing in Riyadh by Group Captain Niall Irving

In preparation for land operations the army has completed its most complex logistic operation ever

A vast logistic base has been established and stocked in the operational area

Over forty thousand tons of ammunition and three and a half million gallons of fuel have been moved so far 

The petrol is enough to take an average family car one hundred million miles or four thousand times round the world

Group Captain Irving  said the R A F had now mounted more than two thousand eight hundred air sorties

Among their most recent targets had been Iraqi storage tanks surface to air missiles and two bridges one of which had been destroyed and the other badly damaged

Allied attacks on bridges were he said having a devastating effect on Iraq 's ability to supply its forces 

Group Captain Irving said the Royal Navy destroyers H M S Manchester and Exeter and the frigates H M S Brilliant and Brave had joined the British naval forces in the Gulf 

At the American military briefing General Richard Neill said that around twenty per cent of Iraq 's military hardware in and around Kuwait had been destroyed

Giving what he described as confirmed figures he said more than seven hundred and fifty tanks six hundred and fifty artillery pieces and six hundred armoured personnel carriers had been put out of action

General Neill said no further Iraqi aircraft had fled to Iran

The figure remained at a hundred and forty-seven

But he was able to give details of the tactics being adopted by Iraqi pilots in their attempt to reach Iran

The two men who 'll advise President Bush on the timing of an Allied ground offensive have been meeting American military commanders in Saudi Arabia

With his assessment of this and the day 's other events here 's our defence correspondent Mark Laity

Mr Cheney and General Powell have spent the day receiving assessments of the campaign so far from General Schwarzkopf the commanders of the air and naval forces and a variety of other officers

The British commander Lieutenant General Sir Peter De La Billi&egrave;re General Sir Peter De La Billire also met them to discuss the British contribution

The general picture they received was described as upbeat and confident although the figures released today also show the scale of the task remaining

The seven hundred and fifty tanks six hundred and fifty artillery pieces and six hundred armoured personnel carriers amount to less than twenty per cent of the total numbers in the Kuwait theatre and the Allies will want to destroy far more before starting a ground offensive

Nevertheless the figures are not regarded as unsatisfactory because Allied air power has only recently made such targets a high priority

Military sources are also suggesting a high proportion of the destroyed vehicles are from the elite Republican Guard and therefore valued far more highly than those of lesser units

It 's also being emphasised that these figures are confirmed with many other vehicles at least damaged

The Americans seem to be aiming at reducing the effectiveness of the Iraqis by about a half

But this doesn't mean half the equipment must be destroyed because a range of other factors such as supplies and morale also affect fighting capability 

The morale of units in southern Kuwait is believed to be particularly low where the Saudi spokesmen were reporting that an Iraqi Lieutenant Colonel was among several officers who crossed into Saudi Arabia today

Such prisoners have said they 're suffering from severe food shortages much of the credit for which is being given to the Allied campaign to isolate the Kuwaiti theatre

As part of this effort sixty-five bridges have been targeted with forty-two attacked already and at least half destroyed

They include one hit today by RAF aircraft in raids that also damaged another as well as a petrol dump and Republican Guard artillery positions and command posts 

President Gorbachev has warned the Allies that they 're in danger of exceeding their legal powers to oust Iraqi troops from Kuwait

The Soviet leader said the military operations were endangering the spirit of the U N resolutions which authorised the use of force against Iraq 

In a statement carried by the official news agency Tass he made a public appeal to President Saddam Hussein to reconsider his position

The statement also said that he would be sending a personal envoy to Baghdad for a meeting with the Iraqi leader 

The Iraqis in a military communique broadcast within the past hour said that Allied forces had carried out three hundred and forty-five air raids over the previous twenty-four hours

Iraq had launched a Scud missile attack on Tel Aviv and had also carried out missile attacks on Allied positions in Saudi Arabia

Our correspondent Alan Little is in Baghdad

He sent this report on the mood in the Iraqi capital

In Baghdad city centre there 's visible evidence of the precision of the early bombing raids targets in densely built up areas picked out and destroyed

The front wall of the impressive local government ministry has collapsed into the street its frame jutting out at an angle like the ribcage of a decaying carcass

Rubble has spilled on to the road

A few yards away the compound of the British Embassy is unscathed

The main post office is a burnt-out shell its telecommunication tower a twisted heap

Next door a branch of the Rassidian Bank is still trading 

But local people say the bombing changed in the third week of the war

New targets were attacked bridges roads buildings and residential areas

Al Jamoria bridge is down in two places and impassible

but there remain five bridges across the Tigris in the downtown area alone all intact

People here expect further city centre raids aimed at them with inevitable civilian casualties

Earlier this week an apparent attempt to hit Al Adamir bridge failed

Nearby houses were hit

A kerosene heater in one of them caused a fire

One eyewitness I spoke to said six people had died 

Baghdad has been quiet for two nights now

Three air raid alerts last night but no new damage

Many of those who left the city early in the war are beginning to return

The shops are closed but the souks are thriving

Food is available but not fuel to cook it with

Everyone expects the ground war to begin any day

The official media here are preparing public opinion

A front page editorial in Al Khadasir says Iraq will crush its enemies and inflict unprecedented catastrophe on them

It hints that President Saddam Hussein will determine when the conflict will begin and seize control over the course of the war

After twenty-three days of bombardment a kind of routine has descended on Baghdad

Anxiety has given way to making do with no electricity limited water and rapidly diminishing fuel

There 's little enthusiasm for war but no vocal opposition either

Baghdad has dug itself in to wait 

Iran 's top policy-making body has begun discussing Iraq 's response to the Gulf peace initiative being suggested by Teheran

President Rafsanjani and his nat and his Supreme National Security Council were given a message from Saddam Hussein by Iraq 's deputy prime minister Mr Sadoum Hamadi who 's now returned to Iraq

Few details of the Iranian initiative have emerged

But Iran has emphasised that Iraq must withdraw from Kuwait unconditionally

The initiative has been seen as the first credible attempt to find a peaceful solution since the war started 

The Israeli prime minister Mr Yitzak Shamir has played down the significance of the latest Iraqi Scud missile attack on his country

Speaking on Israeli radio Mr Shamir said the danger of Iraqi attacks was waning

Raids on Baghdad 's forces by the Allies would he said end the murderous terrorist attacks from Iraq 

Allied military sources in Saudi Arabia said an Iraqi mobile Scud launcher was destroyed overnight but not the one which was used in the attack on Israel 

The Foreign Secretary Mr Douglas Hurd has arrived in Saudi Arabia where he 's having talks with the exiled Emir of Kuwait and Saudi officials

it had to come from Arab leaders 

The American authorities have discounted terrorist involvement in an attempt to blow up storage tanks near the United States naval base in Norfolk Virginia

The Prime Minister Mr John Major has expressed his absolute confidence that Iraq will be defeated in the Gulf War

Mr Major who flies to Bonn on Monday said Britain was strongly committed to the European Community

It 's eight o'clock on Wednesday the seventh of November

The American mid-term elections have brought little change in Congress but the Republican Party of President Bush has lost two key ton contests for state governors

Mr Edward Heath has said Iraq may let more than fifty British people leave the country next week

Today 's newsreader Lawrie Macmillan 

In the American mid-term elections the Democrats have retained control of both the Senate and the House of Representatives and President Bush 's Republicans have made a net loss of three in contests for state governorships 

With results still coming in only one Senate seat looks like changing hands and fewer than eleven Democratic gains are expected in the Lower House

However the defeat of Republican candidates for governor in two key Southern states where Mr Bush had campaigned personally may have laid the groundwork for further Democratic gains in the future

Here 's our Washington correspondent David MacNeill

The Democrats have gained a handful of additional seats in the House of Representatives where they already hold a big majority

There 's been very little change in the Senate where the Democrats appear to have increased their majority by one seat

So on paper it hasn't been a bad night for President Bush

After all the party that controls the White House invariably loses ground in the mid-term elections for Congress and usually much more ground than has been lost this year

However there are worrying signs for the Republicans in the contests for state governors

Because of the shift in population to the warmer parts of the country states like Florida Texas and California are to be given extra seats in Congress

The governors of those states will have a big say in redrawing the boundaries

And it 's here that the Democrats have made significant headway

They have won the elections for governor in both Florida and Texas from the Republicans although Mr Bush 's party appears to have held on to the biggest prize of all California

So while this mid-term election has not been a disaster for the Republicans it does spell trouble for them further down the road

and it 's given new heart to the Democrats as they ponder their chances of ousting the President from the White House two years from now

At the same time neither party can afford to ignore the two main messages from the electorate

One there is widespread dissatisfaction with politics and politicians

and two woe betide the incumbent who raises taxes or the candidate who refuses to rule out the possibility of raising them 

The European Agriculture Commissioner Mr Ray McSharry has given an undertaking that no farmer will be driven out of business by the Community 's agreement last night to cut subsidies by thirty per cent over ten years 

The formula includes income assistance for farmers damaged by loss of financial support and quotas to limit cheap imports

The former Prime Minister Mr Edward Heath has said more than fifty British hostages could be freed by Iraq next week

and one of the main allied aims was to so weaken the Iraqi air defences that attacks in daylight would not be so risky

France and Germany have urged the European Community to forge a common defence policy at the first meeting of E C foreign ministers since the outbreak of the Gulf War

The German Foreign Minister Hans Dietrich Genscher said that the war showed the need to make security part and parcel of a joint Community foreign policy

However the plan got a lukewarm reception from some countries including Britain

The Foreign Secretary Douglas Hurd said that the Gulf War had exposed deep divisions and differences between member states on key issues

At the same meeting the E C foreign ministers agreed to lift sanctions against South Africa as soon as President De Klerk starts fulfilling his pledge to repeal the apartheid laws

Our political correspondent Eleanor Goodman at I T N reports 

The European Community 's difficulties in agreeing how to respond to the Gulf War has added to the problems of foreign ministers trying to agree a formula for political union

For while the British believe that the Gulf has reinforced their view that the way ahead must be through improved cooperation between individual national governments the Germans argue that on the contrary it showed that such negotiations always reduce initiatives in the field of foreign affairs to the lowest common denominator 

As ministers went in it was clear that all regarded this issue as central 









Ministers chatted affably before today 's meeting

But as the E E C President Jacques Delors has admitted the Community has not acquitted itself well over Iraq with the Belgians refusing to supply ammunition to the British the French and the Germans backing a last minute diplomatic initiative and then the Germans only belatedly making a substantial contribution to the war effort 

Privately I think that the majority of the European leaders and the diplomats believe that the Gulf crisis has shown that the Community can no longer afford not to have the authority to decide uh to act and speak with one voice in an area like this

Many of them feel that they 've been sucked step by step into a situation they don't they do not fully control and the consequences of a war which they fear may leave the Middle East in a more troubled state than we found it

And for all of those reasons they say never again

We want the Community to have much more authority to speak with a single voice and to take collective action in these crucial matters that affect all our interests

The British agreed today that a European foreign policy was a necessity not a luxury

But Douglas Hurd argued that the best way of achieving such a policy was through closer cooperation of national governments through existing bodies like the Council of Ministers rather than by giving the Commission new powers to initiate policy

The new structures it was said wouldn't themselves conceal policy differences

But the French insisted that the war had not weakened the will of the twelve to put in their place a common foreign and defence policy

Together with the Germans they proposed developing a British plan how to use the western European union as the basis of a European defence policy and less acceptably to the British giving foreign ministers new powers to implement defence policy through majority voting

What the majority seem to want is that the heads of government the prime ministers ' meeting and the regular summits of the Community should lay down certain areas of common collective foreign policy-making

They would set out what these policy areas would be and then the foreign ministers of the twelve would implement those policies on the basis of majority voting

Now the British will not like that uh but they are I understand preparing some alternative proposals themselves

And once again we 'll have a situation I think where the majority will set the pace and the British will slowly but eventually follow

The meeting did agree though that any moves to forge a common defence policy should not be legally binding

The constraints on member governments would be purely political so in practice probably wouldn't prevent individual governments going it alone as they did in the Gulf

Afterwards Douglas Hurd said he didn't go along with those who thought the whole idea of European cooperation a farce but that he had stressed there had to be consensus

We 're not going to get a  progress on this just by altering the nature of our machinery 

The defects evident from the Gulf crisis were not caused by absence of machinery or the breakdown in machinery 

They were more basic than that

They dealt with substance

Uh so that uh I was clear so that we needed to proceed in these matters by consensus

But the message of today 's meeting was that the majority of European countries still have much more ambitious plans for political union than Britain is prepared to contemplate

The official law reforming body in England and Wales the Law Commission  has published its long-awaited proposals for a radical reform of the divorce law 

As expected it 's recommending a minimum twelve-month period of reflection before divorces are granted  and the abolition of the fault grounds for divorce  such as adultery and unreasonable behaviour 

It also suggests that a court should have the power to prevent divorce in cases of extreme hardship 

Our legal affairs correspondent Jane Peel  has been studying the proposals

The Law Commission recommends that in future anyone who 's not in a violent relationship will have to prove the marriage has broken down  by spending at least a year considering and reflecting on the decision to split up 

During that period the couple would have to seek agreement on the future of their children  money and property 

The courts would encourage but not force them to visit counselling or conciliation services 

If there 's no agreement after a year the courts may postpone the divorce  or in rare cases where it would cause grave financial hardship  refuse to grant it at all 

The report which is accompanied by a draft bill says these new proposals will make divorce fairer and less humiliating  for husbands wives and their children

The Treasury and the Bank of England have acted to quash speculation about another imminent cut in interest rates 

In an unusual move  they 've both issued statements saying the cost of borrowing will stay at fourteen per cent until it 's safe to make a reduction 

Speculation about another cut in interest rates has been fuelled by the C B I report on Tuesday  which said industry was in the middle of a recession 

The government has given the go-ahead for shops and garages to charge higher prices to customers using credit cards  than to those offering cash 

The Corporate Affairs Minister Mr John Redwood says the new arrangements will be in place by March next year 

Our business affairs correspondent Peter Smith reports

This decision has been inevitable since the credit card company Visa failed in the High Court to block the Government from going along with a recommendation from the Monopolies Commission 

It 'll mean traders will be able to offer a discount for cash  or alternatively charge extra to customers using credit cards 

Until now the card companies have been able to impose a rule preventing shops from discriminating between sales in cash or plastic  forcing them to charge all the same price

It 's likely to make little difference to the big retail chains  who can negotiate cheap terms with the card companies 

But small shops who have to pay up to five per cent on credit card sales  are likely to introduce two-tier pricing and many petrol stations may do the same

The Law Commission 's long-awaited report on divorce recommends a simpler system and a system designed to cut down the bitterness and the trauma when a couple decide that they must part 

Its intention is partly to minimise some of the damage and of course that damage is often done to the children of a broken marriage

It 's a human rather than a political problem

A story which could no doubt be told by many children 

So what has the Law Commission tried to do 

I asked Professor Brenda Hoggett who 's one of the authors of the report

It 's taking us we hope towards a better and more honest and more humane system of divorce law

Without making divorce necessarily easier in all cases

No i it would not make divorce generally either easier or more difficult 

It would make it quite different and in our view better

But the key it seems to me is that  the the grounds for divorce are going to be simplified

That is right 

The present ground for divorce is that the marriage has irretrievably broken down 

But that can be proved in one of five ways 

three of which involve proving fault  which in practice is quite easy to do because the other person can't really challenge it

And in any case it does nothing to help the parties ' relationship or to mend the marriage 

We are proposing that in the future  irretrievable breakdown should be shown by the lapse of a minimum period of twelve months  during which the couple would be expected to consider what arrangements should be made uh in the event of their actually being divorced

So there are two uh points which spring from that

One is that for example adultery as grounds for divorce goes

That is right

And secondly there is a lot of emphasis on the whole question of conciliation after it has been agreed by the parties that they want to part 

There is an emphasis on sorting out the practical consequences  what it will mean for the couple their children their home their property their money what they 're all going to live on  before rather than after they get divorced 

Unfortunately at present a lot of that is sorted out afterwards not before 

One of our principal concerns was to minimise the harm that the children can suffer both while the divorce is happening and in the future 

They suffer  very much if they lose touch with one of their parents 

uh

and they need to feel that both of their parents are still involved in their upbringing if at all possible

So some of the quickie divorces so-called that now happen would actually be stretched out by the procedures that you 're advocating

That 's right 

Uh

but of course during that stretching out it is hoped that the arrangements that will be necessary if it happens will have taken place whereas at present you can get a quickie divorce and then fight about the consequences for years afterwards

Although the Queen is regularly touted as the world 's richest woman  the Emperor of Japan is not to be seen on the list of the world 's richest men or people  at least not until a long way down

The big difference between Britain 's royal family and the imperial family of Japan is that the latter don't own any land 

If it did the Emperor would probably be the richest man in the world  because the two hundred acres the Imperial Palace and its grounds occupy in the centre of Tokyo must easily be the most valuable tract of undeveloped land in the world 

The land however belongs to the state 

Mind you the state 's very generous because in a city where rents are very high the Royal family gets this pad rent-free 

And the government thanks to the tax payers it represents of course coughs up a lot for various imperial ceremonies and functions 

Last year 's enthronement for example cost something like thirty-two million pounds

One of the many reasons the heir to the throne is having trouble finding a bride is that his relatively austere lifestyle puts off the rich eligible women who know they 'll have much more fun away from the imperial family 

The members of the family lead a very different lifestyle from Britain 's royals 

They 're expected to do far less in terms of public engagements  and yet are much more restricted in what they can do and where they can go

Their lives are largely run by the mysterious men in the imperial household agency  which holds the family 's purse strings 

Prince Charles reportedly once made a comment about the Japanese royal family being nothing more than puppets and prisoners in their own country

Emperor Akihito inherited about four and a half million pounds from his father  but had to pay about two million of that in inheritance tax 

and under a new law the tax paid on it had to be displayed publicly 

When they heard about this imperialists were outraged saying it was a disgrace to the Emperor 

One protester locked himself in a room at the tax office dealing with the assessment  and fired a random shot before surrendering to police 

Because tax officials were wary of similar protests  they decided to display the tax assessment on a desk in a private conference room guarded by police instead of on a bulletin board as usual 

Theoretically this was still public because any member of the public could still request to see it 

But since the day of the display wasn't publicised no one did 

But the law was upheld so everyone was happy 

So if it 's not really worth trying to get born into the imperial family what about entering Japanese politics

Well this invigorating area you know is positively awash with cash and lucrative shareholdings as the sporadic financial scandals show 

And whereas Britain 's Prime Ministers generally wait until after they 've left office before they capitalise on their name and earn tidy sums giving speeches and opening supermarkets and the like  in Japan they can do it on the side while in office 

For the record the Prime Minister 's official salary currently stands at twenty-five million yen or about a hundred and ten thousand pounds 

Japanese firms would also save part of an employee 's salary for a two-part bonus to be paid in the summer and at the end of the year 

The government is no different

and somehow the powers that be have decided Prime Minister Kaifu 's summer bonus should be two million yen or about eight and a half thousand pounds

Germany did away with its monarchy in November nineteen eighteen 

Well it didn't so much abolish the Royal Court

rather the Kaiser and the princes stood down

and as their credibility was at an all-time low  there was little if any resistance 

It 's difficult to say whether the Germans would want them back

On the one hand it 's a modern country with an elected head of state  but at the same time the Germans crave for pageantry and glamour of royalty and one notices here that counts and countesses of territories lost at the end of the last century  still hold on to their titles

But it doesn't bring much only a title because Germany 's head of state is an elected official

There have been six federal presidents since the birth of the modern federal German state and none has been as popular as Richard von Weizs&aumlaut;cker the present president 

He took on the job back in nineteen eighty-four and was duly re-elected for a second five-year term in nineteen eighty-nine 

There 's even been talk of changing the constitution which allows only two terms as federal president so von Weizs&aumlaut;cker could remain in the top job

But he says he 's had enough

Ten years as the top man in the country is enough for anyone 

He 's elected by a special constitutional body made up of M Ps known as the federal convention

It comes together solely for the purpose of electing the president  and it 's parliament who decides how much money the presidential office receives

There 's a great deal of work to be done

The president accredits and receives ambassadors appoints and dismisses judges and can pardon convicted criminals 

He makes frequent trips abroad drumming up business for German firms and smoothing the feathers of Germany 's enemies 

But what has made Richard von Weizs&aumlaut;cker popular among Germans is his high moral standing  sort of the Vaclav Havel of Germany

So with such a popular man at the helm his budget goes through the Bundestag virtually on a nod 

It costs ten million pounds annually to keep his office and two palatial residences operating

and their remuneration for twenty-four hour a day devotion to the fatherland  one hundred and twenty thousand pounds a year 

That 's some ten thousand pounds a month  but with the modern German state comes the modern tax collector and even the president of high moral standing or not is not exempt from paying tax 

And there are few tax dodges and tax allowances for the man

After all he has few outgoings

Travel meals accommodation and security costs are all picked up by the state

Ships still ride the tides of the Thames

but most go no further today than the modern port of Tilbury near the Thames estuary in Essex 

Further upriver is desolation 

There 's been some revival in barge traffic with the rebuilding of the old docklands upriver

Sand and gravel 's towed on the floodtide to the Canary Wharf development on the Isle of Dogs 

A fifth of London 's rubbish goes downstream in barges to be buried in Essex 

But to those who knew the river in its heyday it 's dead 

It 's now once again a natural feature of London 's urban landscape 

The world renown of the Thames was always quite out of scale with its natural grandeur 

Compared with the Nile or the Amazon or the Mississippi it 's a mere sea creek 

It 's famous because in the Victorian era the greatest city in the world grew up on its banks 

The first London was just a colonial outpost of the Roman empire 

The Romans crossed the Channel landed in Kent and marched north to the river Thames 

They built a wooden bridge across it here just below modern London Bridge when the river was much wider lapping Lower Thames Street 

Roman Londinium had a thriving port but it didn't last 

When the Romans retreated in four hundred A D their port and their town disappeared 

The Saxons had a port upstream but the Thames tides carried no significant trade for five hundred years 

It was five hundred years after that in the Elizabethan era that the river took on a real economic importance for London and England 

The great natural force of the tides carried ships far inland on the flood and out on the ebb 

This linked London with growing industrial centres in other parts of the country 

Coastal shipping gave England an industrial lead 

Before good roads or railways landlocked European cities were left behind as London grew  overtaking Paris in size in seventeen fifty

Historian Robin Craig

The lorries of the river the most local of the ships in the coasting trade were the Thames sailing barges 

Their special spritsail rigging was designed so they could be worked by just two men 

The form of the Thames barge evolved in the early nineteenth century replacing an earlier more primitive kind of sailing vessel 

This kept down costs and made it a competitive form of transport well into the twentieth century 

One of the last surviving of the old barge skippers is Dan Wills from Gravesend 

Some of the larger barges were sea-going vessels like the Lady Daphne 

Though they seem quaint now the sailing barges had tremendous economic importance in the past 

No great city could grow without building materials food and fuel

On its tidal estuary linked to all other parts of Britain by the sea London began to take the lead 

Its most significant cargo when it began to emerge as a world city was coal 

Coal was first in great demand in the fifteenth century

It couldn't be carried efficiently overland 

London 's coal came down the East coast from Newcastle and was known as sea coal 

By the eighteenth century the trade in sea coal to London was the single most important employer of shipping 

Captain Cook learnt his seamanship on this route and his first explorer ship was a Whitby collier renamed The Endeavour 

A Whitby collier also gave its name to a Thames-side pub 

London 's dependence on sea-borne coal continued into the age of electricity 

The first power stations were built along the Thames so that river water could be used as a coolant 

This is Battersea power station under construction in the nineteen thirties its chimneys towering above the river 

Because power stations were built on the Thames the most efficient way of delivering the millions of tons of coal they devoured was by ship 

The men who manned the colliers were the unsung unglamorous heroes of the London river 

Kevin Greenwell a liner steward did a stint on the Thames coal boats 

Collier skipper Albert Dale 

The coal trade provided a great deal of work for Londoners

It was one of the most lucrative cargoes on the Thames 

Lighterman and tug skipper Bob Harris 

The coal trade and nearly all of the coasting trade has gone from the Thames 

All the power stations the gas works and the factories have closed down 

The ships that had carried a more adventurous and exotic trade and which brought great wealth to London are now museum pieces beached like the Cutty Sark on the shores of the capital 's history 

London was the centre of England 's foreign shipping

It was here that the great charter companies were established from the sixteenth century onwards 

Royalty with political power and the City with economic power gambled on the risky business of sending ships to the far corners of the world to bring back valuable goods 

London became the largest city in Europe in the days of the square-rigger 

Few now can remember life under sail 

Robert Williamson sailed from the West India Docks before nineteen fourteen 

The deep-sea sailing ships brought back goods which were stored in London 

By the nineteenth century it had become the warehouse of the world 

Its spices and other valuable cargoes from the empire were resold in Europe 

The Port of London was more than just a port

It was an emporium in which the world 's goods were valued and auctioned 

Thousands of Londoners made a living from this trade 

Even a schoolboy like Bill Brown could find work as a paper boy selling to ships ' crews from all over the world 

Trade on the Thames remained lively until after the Second World War 

It disappeared rapidly from the nineteen seventies when the old river port which had sustained London for centuries died 

Why that port disappeared is another chapter in the history of the river 

Not much remains but the sand and gravel barges helping to build a monument to the wealth the river had created on the Isle of Dogs 

A few craft have been preserved for the amusement of the new inhabitants of London 's riverside 

The Lady Daphne is now a pleasure boat hired out for executive trips down the empty river 

We 're beginning a new series of Nature with a programme about children 

The children of the nineteen nineties will be the biggest generation ever 

One and a half billion babies will be born over the next ten years 

That 's twice the present population of Africa 

How will they cope with the environmental problems that we have created 

Do we

or will they have the power to make the changes for the better 

Later in the programme we 'll be reporting from a world summit meeting about just those questions 

Chitchats or action 

More from New York later 

Here the Government has recognised that schoolteachers will have to educate children about the environment if future generations are to solve global problems 

From September lessons on the environment will be compulsory in England and Wales an essential part of the National Curriculum 

For a preview of what 's in store we 've come to a school where environmental education is already on the timetable 

In fact these twelve-year-olds probably know a great deal more about the earth 's problems than most adults 

Environmental education has been part of the timetable at  school in Aberystwyth for years now 

From September it 'll be compulsory at all primary and secondary schools  more than twenty-five thousand of them 

Environmental lessons will be incorporated into a new national geography syllabus 

Kay Edwards helped design the new course 

The children are encouraged to look at both sides of the argument 

Class Two has to weigh environmental costs  against economic benefits 

In this case destruction of the rainforests is not just an ecological disaster 

it 's also a way of coping with Brazil 's poverty 

In written work and discussion the children learn that trees are cleared to raise cattle and grow crops 

It may be bad for the earth 's climate  but in the short term it 's good for Brazil 's economy 

Planting trees in Wales can be as controversial as chopping them down in Brazil 

Rows of regimented conifers are not always a welcome addition to the landscape 

Class Two are here to assess their impact 

By any measure they 're already developing an understanding of the environment 

Children learn about environmental problems here 

In other countries they die from them 

Children are the most vulnerable group for some obvious  some complicated reasons

They 're small 

They 're weak

They need food more regularly 

They 're more careless 

The most common killer of children in some countries is diarrhoea  mainly from polluted water 

Diarrhoea kills seven thousand children under the age of five every day 

The stinking slums which surround the first city of the third world are fertile breeding grounds for the water-borne bacteria which cause diarrhoea and death to so many thousands of children 

The poor areas of Mexico City are awash with polluted water 

Open sewers run through the streets irresistible playgrounds for the young 

The combination of natural curiosity and lack of immunity means a child is ten times more likely to develop diarrhoea than an adult 

Mexico City is the most populous city on earth 

The growing numbers put an unbearable strain on the city 's natural resources 

The most precious of those resources is water 

The city has no river and must bear the heavy cost of pumping water in and sewage out over the surrounding mountains 

As many as a million children are born into Mexico 's slums every year 

Their homes do-it-yourself shacks put up without any planning have none of the basic services 

Water the most basic of all is the biggest problem 

Here as in so many parts of the third world running water is a luxury 

clean water rarer still 

Three out of five homes have it on tap 

But only one in five has it free from pollution 

Mexico 's struggled with the problem for generations 

But there 's now a strong sense that the next generation deserves better 

There 's no quick fix to the city 's environmental problems  but there is a simple cheap cure for its most common child-killer 

Diarrhoea kills children by making them dehydrated 

The United Nations children 's organisation UNICEF is sponsoring a worldwide programme which could save them 

In Mexico 's biggest children 's hospital mothers are being taught the technique of oral rehydration 

A simple solution of glucose sodium and potassium replaces the fluids lost during an attack of diarrhoea 

The British medical journal The Lancet has described oral rehydration as potentially the most important medical advance of the century 

It 's been available now for two decades yet in that time a hundred million children have died from diarrhoea 

But the nineteen nineties won't offer medical answers to all the consequences of the earth 's environmental problems 

Atmospheric pollution is the other big child-killer

It causes respiratory complaints and across the world accounts for a quarter of deaths among the under-fives 

In Mexico City motor vehicles three million of them produce eighty per cent of the contamination in the air 

It 's thought that the perpetual blanket of thick smog which smothers the city kills forty-five thousand babies and toddlers every year 

Whatever the source of air pollution the young are always the most vulnerable 

The world stands poised on the brink of its biggest ever baby boom  one and a half billion births over the next decade 

In Mexico alone there 'll be nearly two million new mouths to feed every year 

The country 's president told me this was a cause both for concern and optimism 

Children aren't only the victims of environmental problems 

they can also be a focus for change 

The United Nations in New York recently staged a world summit for children 

The president of Mexico organised it after a long campaign by hundreds of children 's groups 

We sent a team of young reporters  from the Early Times newspaper 

That 's it for this week 

I 'll leave you with the final message that was given to the world leaders at that summit 

It came from the United Nations children 's organisation  a direct appeal to those leaders to concentrate on the generations to come

In the past musicians could copy the sound and style of another group or even take the occasional musical idea

but with a sampler today 's musicians can make a literal copy of someone else 's work  and add it to their own 

For some this so-called age of plunder is a dream come true  instant access to that guitar lick or drum pattern it would take years to learn to play 

But for others it 's a nightmare as they find their work being used without permission 

But how did this situation come about 

How have samplers evolved 

Who is sampling who

And ultimately is it legal 

Prior to the arrival of digital technology there was only one machine that could accurately re-create the sound of real instruments on a keyboard 

Invented in the late sixties the melotron used a complicated system of loop tape recordings to achieve an effect similar to sampling 

It proved particularly popular with progressive rock groups like The Moody Blues who made use of it on their famous track Nights in White Satin 

Genesis also favoured the melotron 's unique sound  and they featured it heavily on many of their classic early seventies albums 

Tony Banks Genesis 's keyboard player recalls using the machine



In nineteen seventy-five Gabriel left Genesis to pursue a solo career and greater musical freedom 

With his interest in unusual sounds and instruments he naturally followed developments in music technology 

and in nineteen seventy-nine he became one of the privileged few to see a demonstration model of the world 's first commercially available digital sampler the Fairlite Computer Musical Instrument 

One of his collaborators at the time was cousin Stephen Payne a keyboard player and expert in sound synthesis 

He also saw the Fairlite C M I in action

Did it excite him

Despite the enormous price tag on the machine Gabriel decided to invest in one and it was first used briefly on the album Peter Gabriel Three 

However it wasn't until his fourth album that the instrument 's capabilities were more fully explored 

Producer Trevor Horne was also amongst the first to invest in a Fairlite and together with J J Dix Alec Gary Langhan and Anne Dudley  he formed the group The Art of Noise 

Their early singles Close to the Edit Beat Box and Moments in Love and their debut album Who 's Afraid of The Art of Noise are milestones in sample-based music 

Anne Dudley remembers her first encounter with the instrument

With the Fairlite the Art of Noise were able to fulfil the futurist dream by making music from any sounds they could record including slamming doors  and a car 's starter motor 

By the mid-eighties samplers had established their ability to generate copies of real instruments or sounds from nature 

But only the occasional orchestra stand had actually been stolen from an already recorded source 

It took hip-hop to popularize the idea of quoting significant parts from other records especially so-called cut up records like Grandmaster Flash 's Adventures on the Wheels of Steel which were composed entirely from existing vinyl 

In the U K Bill Drummond former manager of Echo and the Bunnymen joined forces with colleague Jimmy Caughtie to make a series of hip-hop-inspired audio collage records 

They formed a group called The Jams but are perhaps better known today as the K L F responsible for the hits What Time Is and Three A M Eternal 

Drummond recalls his initial inspiration

The Jam 's first single All You Need Is Love utilising samples from The Beatles Sam Fox and The Sound of Music to make a statement about the current AIDS crisis 

And in terms of audio collage it was undoubtedly a groundbreaking record 

It also clearly flouted copyright law and in its original form no label or distributor would agree to touch it 

Were Drummond and Caughtie surprised by the reaction to the record

Undoubtedly dance music has taken sampling on board far faster than any other musical genre

Dave Durrell manages many of Britain 's top re-mixes and is a D J and re-mixer himself

Does he consider sampling to have been an important innovation

Having faced litigation does Durrell now believe there should be restrictions on the use of sampling

So what exactly is the current legal position on sampling

Andrew Jenkins head of Polydor 's U K legal department

So who actually decides whether a sample can be used or not

Does Jenkins believe there is sufficient legislation at present to deal with sampling cases

Christians in Albania have been guaranteed the right to preach their religion  according to a new draft constitution published recently 

New clauses in the constitution also say that the state observes the freedom of religious faith  but some ob observers have said that it could just be a ploy by the government to increase their support  in next month 's elections 

Pro-life groups have been angered this week by attempts to push through the introduction of a new abortion pill 

The Medicines Control Agency is trying to fast-track the controversial pill  which works by blocking the action of a hormone progesterone  which is vital to maintain pregnancy 

But Catherine Fran&ccedille;ois of the Society for the Protection of Unborn Children  has expressed grave doubts about the pill 

Proper testing hasn't been carried out she says  and there could be an increased risk of cancer 

Miss Fran&ccedille;ois who has labelled the pill a human pesticide is urging Christians to voice their opposition to the drug 

Two and a half million Bibles and Bible portions have been supplied to the Soviet Union and eastern European countries during nineteen ninety 

Fifty-six per cent of the Bibles were supplied to the Soviet Union followed by Rumania who received sixteen per cent 

But according to the United Bible Societies these figures don't tell the whole story  as some countries imported paper  on which to print their own Bibles 

The Evangelical Alliance Relief Fund is set to benefit from the recycling of office waste 

A company based in Bath has agreed to donate one pound fifty for every spent toner cartridge received  from a wide range of photocopiers and laser printers 

The company reckons that a hundred thousand cartridges are discarded every month so the potential income for TEAR Fund could be considerable 

TEAR Fund says that each toner cartridge recycled represents a week 's food for a child in a Third World country 

And finally today marks the beginning of a week of Christian unity  so it 's an opportunity for Christians everywhere to at least unite in prayer for a speedy end to the war in the Gulf

The Villa Somalia which was Siad Barre 's official residence in Mogadishu still lies abandoned  guarded by a handful of young men from the United Somali Congress the rebel force which took control of Mogadishu at the end of January 

But it was in one of the office buildings that I discovered the letters  thousands of them  addressed to His Excellency President Mohammed Siad Barre but all unopened 

I picked up one from Britain 

It had been posted in September nineteen eighty-eight and was signed by a retired schoolteacher from Guildford in Surrey  writing on behalf of Amnesty International to plead for the release of a blind Somali preacher who 'd been imprisoned for his religious beliefs 

The mass of similar letters from all parts of the world were a stark reminder of Somalia 's appalling human rights record under Siad Barre  although on my return from Mogadishu last week Amnesty confirmed that the preacher for whom it had campaigned had actually been released some time in nineteen eighty-nine 

The flood of letters must have had some impact after all 

Siad Barre is still thought to be in the south-west of the country having sought refuge among the members of his minority Marahan clan

His near presence is an obstacle to political reconciliation 

Although Somalis are determined that he should never be allowed to stage a comeback  troops still loyal to the former leader have been active in southern Somalia  and appear to have drawn wider support  using the money and arms with which they escaped from Mogadishu in January 

Last week in the company of two other journalists I ventured into the Somali countryside to investigate the continuing conflict 

Transport and fuel are a problem  but with the help of the entrepreneurial Somalis who prey on foreign visitors at Mogadishu 's  Hotel we were eventually able to hire a vehicle and two gunmen for protection 

Unfortunately it turned out to be a lumbering camper van probably looted last year from a fleeing expatriate family who once used it for weekends away 

It was an incongruous sight on the sandy roads south toward Gismaio as we met U S C fighters in their cut-down Land Rovers with machine guns and bazookas mounted on the back 

Dressed in civilian clothes they gave the impression of being members of a rabble army 

And when we asked for a demonstration of their heaviest gun it took them ten minutes to fire it 

There were signs of skirmishing on the roadside  the occasional corpse  and a large number of wrecked vehicles which had been stripped bare 

But for the time being at least it seemed the U S C had without difficulty driven the opposition south in some haste 

Back in Mogadishu Somalia 's acting president Ali Madi told us that if Siad Barre and his supporters could be chased out of the country  everything would be all right 

Somalis share one language one religion and one culture he said but Siad Barre is still dividing our people

Once he 's gone we can solve all our political differences

Ali Madi is an unlikely person to be holding the reins of power 

He 's a fifty-two-year-old businessman and hotelier  who helped to finance the United Somali Congress when it was first established in Rome 

As we sat in Ali Madi 's house  freshly decorated and lavishly refurnished after being looted in January  the acting president expressed his disappointment that so many in the international community had apparently turned their backs on Somalia 

Only Egypt has so far recognised the caretaker government and reopened its Embassy in Mogadishu 

Humanitarian aid has been slow in coming  and now many in the capital are beginning to starve 

Only a handful of international relief agencies are currently working in the country 

The failure of the caretaker government to convene a national reconciliation conference  fears over security and the lack of communications with the outside world  have left Somalia isolated 

Walking in the streets of the once picturesque old quarter of Mogadishu near the deserted British Embassy  I came across Brian Bowden  a British water engineer who 's lived in Somalia for thirty-three years 

Until the evacuation of the British Embassy in January he 'd been working for the Overseas Development Agency in charge of a tse-tse fly monitoring project 

Mr Bowden has a Somali wife and hasn't been out of the country since nineteen sixty-eight 

He chose to stay on in Mogadishu through the height of the fighting in January and says it 's high time that a British Government representative came back to Mogadishu if only to look at the situation 

In the meantime Mr Bowden is trying to clean up the British Embassy wrecked by the looters of Mogadishu  who left behind only a mountain of official papers and documents 

If the international community is to return much may depend on the moves made by the Italian Government  despite a somewhat ambivalent relationship between Italy and Somalia 

Some say that Italy as a former colonial power has a moral obligation to lead the way and help the Somalis in their hour of need  but others argue that the Italians propped up Siad Barre 's repressive regime for too long  and should now stay away 

But what Somalia needs above all else is peace between its own people who remain divided by clan loyalties 

The U S C quietly admits that some form of foreign mediation may now be the only answer

The North Pole is no ordinary explorers ' obsession

It 's a moving target 

To reach it on foot you must navigate hundreds of miles across a perishing sub-zero landscape of blizzards open water crevasses and drifting ice 

Beneath it an ocean ten thousand feet deep that will kill you in minutes if the ice gives way 

Ever since Robert Peary reached the North Pole in nineteen hundred and nine explorers have been fascinated by the challenge

Many have tried

Few have succeeded and no-one has yet made it without the support of dogs vehicles or aircraft to carry supplies 

British explorer Sir Ranulph Fiennes reached both Poles with support in a transglobe expedition of nineteen eighty-one 

He became convinced he could reach the North Pole unaided 

He 's tried three times

And each time failed 

To reach the North Pole unsupported means dragging three hundred pounds of food fuel and other supplies for more than fifty days through the most hostile conditions on earth 

In March nineteen ninety taking advantage of glasnost Fiennes and his partner Dr Michael Stroud set out for the Pole from the Soviet Arctic

But this time it was a race

In Northern Canada three Norwegians are launching their attempt to get there first 

This is the story of an epic struggle between two teams of men determined to make history

Instead it ends in bitter controversy 

A re-run of the race to the South Pole eighty years ago between Scott and Amundsen  this time to conquer the world 's last great Polar challenge 

Red Square in the heart of Moscow 

Two years ago a sight like this would 've been unthinkable 

Past the queues of tourists outside Lenin 's tomb strides a British explorer with a string of military adventures behind him most of them aimed at the defeat of Communism 

Former S A S officer Sir Ranulph Fiennes along with Dr Michael Stroud and Lawrence and Morag Howell are working with Soviet comrades to attempt an unsupported trek to the North Pole 

The hardware of the Cold War years is now put to a different use 

Soviet military transport and access to forward bases of the Soviet Army on the remote Arctic fringes are essential to Fiennes ' game plan of attacking the Pole from the northernmost pinnacle of Soviet Russia 

Fiennes and Stroud take off in an Antinov Twelve military transport for the fourteen hour journey to the northernmost tip of the Soviet Union 

Their destination the island of  part of Severnaya Zemlya literally North Land not discovered until nineteen twelve and the last place on earth to be mapped 

As they edge closer to the Arctic Ran and Mike must wonder if the Soviet Union offers them a greater chance of success than their three previous attempts from Canada 

This is how Fiennes and Stroud first met in nineteen eighty-six 

Stroud had flown out to Canada from England after Fiennes radioed for a partner to join him on his first effort to reach the Pole unsupported 

They 've never improved on the distance covered on that first expedition 

As supplies are unloaded there 's a chance to meet expedition organiser Dimitri Sparo 

And with temperatures at minus forty celsius at this lonely Russian airbase there 's a chance to reflect on the enormity of the human task that lies ahead 

One thousand miles across the Arctic Ocean in Northern Canada three Norwegians Berger Ausland Ger Rondbe and Erling Kager get ready to mount their challenge to reach the Pole unaided 

The Canadian team has already set off but they 'll give up after less than a week 

These three however are convinced they can finish the job 

In nineteen hundred and twelve while the Russians were still surveying their own northernmost land mass the race was on to reach the South Pole and Norwegian Raoul Amundsen got there ahead of Englishman Captain Scott

Scott and his team perished on the way home 

But in Britain Amundsen never enjoyed the recognition he undoubtedly deserved

Scott meanwhile became a national hero 

Amundsen believed his success was due to the long experience of Norwegian explorers in the harsh conditions of the polar regions 

Seventy-eight years later Fiennes ' Norwegian rivals have cast themselves in the role of Amundsen seeing their race to the North Pole as a rematch 

They chose to start their daunting trek from the Canadian Arctic

Training first at Ikalowit they 'll fly north toward Hunt Island

Though the pack ice is tougher the route is shorter by a hundred and twenty miles 

In desolate wastes like these everything depends on painstaking preparation of clothing and equipment 

A lightweight radio has saved the Norwegians more than twenty pounds

It 's just a fifth the weight of the equipment carried by Fiennes

Instead of contact with a base camp the Norwegian team will use a preset frequency to contact airliners flying overhead using a ski as the antenna 

At the British team 's Soviet base camp Ran and Mike Stroud complete their final preparations  ahead of them six hundred miles of drifting ice 

Their choice of a longer route is based on calculations that the ice will drift in their favour with prevailing winds carrying them northwards 

Ran and Mike will have to pull their life-supporting supplies behind them over some of the world 's most dangerous terrain 

Temperatures will drop below minus forty celsius

Winds will reach gale force 

And since goggles will mist up in the freezing snow blizzards could render them half blind 

Everything they carry will have to earn its keep

Most vital food and fuel 

To save weight Ran and Mike plan to survive on the bare minimum of food intake for such a demanding journey five thousand calories a day dropping to four and a half thousand calories when the sleds grow lighter  a complex arithmetic of survival that is yet to stand the test 

This back-breaking regime is what an unsupported trek is about and why no-one has yet made it unaided to the North Pole 

In Canada the Norwegians have no doubts about their chances

Their route is shorter and their rations better

Seventy days of fuel and upwards of six thousand precious calories a day and all three are superior skiers with long experience of tough arctic conditions 

Dimitri has also strongly advised the British pair that weather conditions are not right 

But on March the seventh Fiennes and Stroud decide to set off for the Pole 

The sleds are loaded aboard a Soviet helicopter that 'll fly them north to Cape Artichevsky an old forward bomber base from the darkest days of the Cold War and the last piece of land before the Arctic Ocean 

This is the last time Ran and Mike will see their Soviet colleagues until the long trek is over 

Now it 's down to hard work human daring  and luck 

It 's a bizarre picture of politics turned on its head 

Two British sleds rumble down a frozen runway built for Soviet bombers to launch attacks against U S targets in the fifties 

Today 's mission has a more benign objective 

The British trek is sponsored mile by mile to raise money for the Multiple Sclerosis Society 

Ran and Mike have enough food and fuel for forty-five days and more than five hundred miles to the North Pole with no outside support 

Yet even with support no other team has ever done it in less than fifty-five days 

If they 're to succeed the two men will need to make unprecedented progress  dragging their three hundred pound sleds and a tiny video camera for more than ten hours a day through some of the worst conditions on the planet 

With the British Polar team now one day ahead of them the Norwegians fly to remote Ward Hunt Island the last outpost of land in Northern Canada  and the place Ranulph Fiennes launched his last three unsuccessful attempts to reach the Pole unaided 

The plane lands on a snow-swept ice shelf and the team readies itself for departure 

When the plane takes off again the nearest civilisation will be seven hundred miles away their small V H F radio the only link with the outside world 

Ahead of them a no-man's-land of deep crevasses and ice boulders forty feet high 

Survival and success now depends depend on the simplest details

How deep is the snow

Will the sleds perform as planned

Will their equipment do the job

It won't be long before the team hit a snag and with sixty more days ahead of them even Berger 's natural optimism wanes 

The Norwegians find it tough going through the thick jungle of ice 

The temperature drops to minus sixty 

In conditions like this eighty years ago Peary had cut off seven of his frostbitten toes with a knife 

Ran and Mike meanwhile are finding good surfaces and have pushed on hard for the first two days 

Even Ran 's radio operator Flo finds his sceptical Russian colleagues are impressed with the mileage already covered 

But even when things are going well in conditions like this the slightest event can spell big trouble 

For the Norwegians too it 'll be hard going 

Huge pressure ridges and drift snow block their path 

Even meticulous planning can't protect them from unforeseen events like a broken ski shoe  a minor piece of bad luck that could prove disastrous 

But Berger is a master of self-help and innovation 

Every night they pitch camp precariously in the snow-covered wilderness sleeping fitfully on dangerous shifting pack ice that shrieks as it moves 

There 's the ever-present fear that the ice will shear off dragging you down into the open chasm beneath you 

Getting up each morning in sub-zero temperatures after a few hours ' broken sleep calls for colossal willpower 

The body has just begun to thaw from the previous day

Now it 's back to the ten hour grind through the Arctic wilds 

At daybreak everything has to be dried

Any moisture left on clothes or bedding will freeze permanently adding extra weight and making sleep more difficult the following night 

Their high energy daily diet is always the same  porridge mixed with fat sugar and high fat chocolate with freeze-dried meat and rice or potatoes for dinner 

Even then it 's a welcome chance to warm freezing hands over a steaming bowl of food 

This daily routine would break even the most hardy Inuit 

As you move you sweat

When you stop to rest the sweat freezes 

Such was the pervasive sense of hunger that Berger Ausland 's diary became filled with crazy recipes as he fantasized about pork roasts spaghetti 

At an age when they might want to take things easy  many women like sixty-three-year-old Eileen Allen are running around after older relatives 

When there is caring to be done the main burden almost always falls on one woman in the family 

Because one of her sisters lives a hundred odd miles away and the other can't drive Eileen has more than her fair share 

As well as her eighty-six-year-old mother-in-law there are her cousins  three stalwart sisters octogenarians all 

Edna is eighty-six and a former gym mistress 

She 's now virtually housebound 

Nellie who 's eighty-four is the only sister who never married 

She lives in a residential home where she used to be a parlour maid 

The baby is eighty  fit as a fiddle until recently when she developed a dodgy leg 

This is Cousin Renee who is not to be confused with Auntie Renee 

And this is Ivy the matriarch 

Eileen has lived all her life in Rotherham Yorkshire 

Six years ago she stopped teaching and retired with her husband Ernest to a bungalow high on a hill in a genteel part of town 

I have spent a quarter of a century among parish councils which have by the way nothing to do with the church but are concerned with village government 

It landed me in some small adventures such as no reasonable Anglo-Prussian might expect 

I got into this because cerebro-spinal meningitis put me out of action for six months in nineteen fifty-two  and as few barristers ' practices can stand that sort of interruption I applied for a job 

The national association of parish now local councils needed a national secretary

It looked interesting even if underpaid 

The interviewing committee of twelve seemed a rum lot 

An admiral was in the chair and there was a weather-beaten lady and in those beardless times a fiercely bearded egghead

It took some while but I managed to make them laugh and came away with the impression that it was in the bag 

As usual in such matters I was wrong

They offered it to someone else but he changed his mind so they had to make do with me 

The outgoing incumbent regaled me with horror stories

There was too much work

there was no money

members were deserting

everybody hated us 

The worse it seemed the more cheerful I felt

Something obviously needed to be done 

She was going to a nice comfortable job in Sarawak

I was casting caution to the winds

At the start I used to get two or three abusive letters a week

Hooray 

The very day I sat down at my new desk I had my first experience of local government negotiation at a shouting match with the associations representing the counties and districts 

We had tabled a policy document a harmless little thing

it was mostly about public benches and footpaths and wastepaper baskets  but going by the uproar it might have been the surrealist and communist manifestos rolled into a U D I 

These people plainly detested us but the very fact that we were in the same room with them added significance 

There were at that time two local government factions
