on the one hand the boroughs wanted to abolish the system and replace it with a uniform network of boroughs  on the other the counties and districts wanted to keep the system and tidy it up at the edges 

The latter feared the boroughs because of their masses of urban voters and were looking for allies

That was why weak as we were they had invited us in 

Actually in the mutual admiration society of local government the hatred or indifference of the public was overlooked

The borough electors for example actually knew nothing of the issues  and as the voting turnout showed cared even less

It was not nominal electoral mass but political contacts which gave clout

In this the parishes were deficient but could compete

I set out to fill the gap 

Politicians were not then esteemed and many people of distinction got career satisfaction in other fields such as law or philanthropy

We 'd already attracted one or two including William Third Lord Merther and Richard Fort Tory M P for Clitheroe 

Their intervention was timely for in the general movement of events we had to make a quick public impact while the association was still on an uneven keel 

We could never be news of the sort beloved by the national media but I could write for local and specialist journals for I have something so far unsaid  uh and besides I needed the money 

I made friends with English and European local government periodicals

indeed because I spoke German and French I was once commissioned by two deadly rivals to cover a ten-day conference in Brussels each by their own correspondent

and each congratulated me on how much better their reports were than the other 's 

Specialist journalism and lobbying put us into natural contact with the two groups important to us the civil servants and the legislators 

The thin end of our parliamentary wedge was the anomalous in fact often daft condition of parish law  which had been made intermittently since eighteen twelve by parliaments where in truth the concerns of small bodies such as ours had been far below the horizon of the good the great and the very bad 

The result had been laughably maddening 

One group of examples will suffice 

To provide a shelter a parish council had to be given the power by a simple majority of an electors ' meeting and then raise half the money by an appeal 

A two-thirds majority but no appeal was needed for a lamp post in a street  but for a lamp post in an open space it could manage without the meeting or the appeal but had to seek the power from the county council 

Our parliamentary build-up made it feasible to promote legislation and the consequent need to brief members with civil servants resulted in they and I actually learning something about parishes 

We also obviously had to try and educate our people but where to begin 

In my first year I was away forty weekends teaching 

I once ran a joint session for parish councillors and schoolchildren 

One of the difficulties was that there was no reliable book on the subject 

I now ran into a long-lost publishing friend who invited me to write a book

It seemed a splendid way of getting my ideas straight 

so I wrote Local Council Administration which has lately been republished 

My theory was that the councils would read it and write me less often for advice 

In fact they simply asked harder questions 

One by-product of this essentially rural work was that with the late Robert Ayckman I became and remain a waterways revivalist

I even organised a mass meeting of M Ps about it 

Another was that in nineteen fifty-five I was asked to serve on the Royal Commission on Common Lands under Sir Ivor Jennings 

Royal commissions are a dormant if not extinct breed 

They labour long and by the time they finish the circumstances or emotions which called them forth may have disappeared 

The pre-nineteen fourteen Canal Commission 's admirable report was wholly ignored 

And then Lord Rothschild said that royal commissions cost a million pounds each and everybody let out a loud whistle 

Ours did not cost that

We were unpaid we had a staff of four and our expenses were reimbursed on so low a scale that we could just afford to lunch together in a second class restaurant near Baker Street 

I can think of two other reasons for their eclipse 

one is that modern bureaucracy is so vast and expensive that governments have to keep it at work and do what royal commissions did before 

If this is so I would have thought that temporary even expensive commissions would be cheaper 

The second reason is that if commission reports were as cavalierly treated as they are nobody worth having will serve on them 

But in nineteen fifty-five all this was in the future 

Our commission first met in one of those beautiful Regents Park terrace houses 

We were a mixed lot

Jennings was fresh from drafting the constitution of Malaysia 

The only colleague whom I knew already was the social and physical geographer Doctor Dudley Stamp who like myself had long been on the Council for the Protection of Rural England 

One of the mass demands much voiced by the Labour Party was the use of the countryside for recreation 

Commons are common only to certain individuals who happen to share rights in the land in common with some other individuals 

The popular fallacy that they were common to all was one factor which created the Jennings Commission  and we had to take the demand seriously 

These lands over a million acres of them were derelict because everybody had forgotten who had what rights or duties over them 

It seemed dog-in-the-mangerish to keep strangers out when no one apparently bothered with them 

And besides it was said that there was a huge miserable urban proletariat with nowhere to go 

This picture was hotly criticised 

The amenity lobby contended that if you let loose hoards of trippers on these scattered properties their numbers and vulgarity would erode and destroy them and so defeat the very purpose of letting them in 

Both sides were wrong 

The urban proles were car-borne or on the Costa Brava 

Then the ecologists said that they contained rare plants and fauna many close to extinction 

We had Professor Alan Roberts and Colonel Floyd distinguished rural scientists to cope with this 

Sir Alan Lubbock a friend of the Sitwells saw the world from a literary and aesthetic point of view 

Trevor Emms the Duke of Norfolk 's agent and Sir Leslie Scott a land commissioner were level-headed men with a lifetime of land management behind them 

None of these accepted extremist arguments at their face value 

Nor was history forgotten 

Commons are mostly the residue of a pre-Norman manorial system  and so we had Doctor William Hoskins the historian 

In this talented group I was obviously the odd man out 

I was less endowed and with my German background my experience was peculiar 

They were mostly in their fifties and sixties

I was thirty-seven 

My only contemporary was George Wild the Commission 's energetic and able secretary 

He was a recent example of the long line of literate golden-style civil servants to whom the English nation and its language owe so much 

We advertised ourselves and then met two days a week 

Pressure groups idealists lords of manors commoners cranks government departments public industries sent us memoranda which varied from weighty documents with many appendices to a few sentences scribbled on cheap notepaper 

One noticeable feature was that so many eager witnesses repeated each other yet believed that no-one else had said it 

There was for example that witty jingle to which we had to pay becoming attention whenever it was quoted 



We travelled far and wide

The Corporation of London took us to Epping Forest in a splendid motorcade  and after showing us round that interesting territory with its deer its cattle customs and its woods entertained us at a hunting lodge

There were three huge fireplaces that blazed with logs against the winter cold  and a delicious meal served by liveried foresters wearing heather-brown bowler hats 

That 's the way to treat a Royal Commission 

Elsewhere our reception might be less elaborate 

Once we arrived in a battered bus at a village pub on the confines of Yorkshire and Westmoreland 

The commoners a rascally looking lot were standing about in their overcoats 

They wanted us to make them the private owners of the huge nearby common 

We explained as we 'd already done by letter that we could only inquire and recommend 

This seemed to annoy them 

We had they hinted been wasting their time 

We asked for the documents which they had mentioned

Documents

what documents

What they wanted was  and so on 

After three years George presented the draft report for our approval 

We had a friendly press conference and dispersed 

None of us were sanguine

we knew too much about the government regime for that  and when seven years later the Commons Registration Act was passed ostensibly on the basis of our report  the government of the day got it wrong 

Would you like to know how 

Commons are our last uncommitted land resource 

We devised ways of ensuring that they remained uncommitted yet put to environmentally-satisfying use 

These ways were left out of the act with the result that astute gravel merchants and estate developers exploit loopholes in the law to discommon and ravage 

I believe that I 'm the last survivor of the commission 

I trust that I 'm not a lone voice 

The celebrations have been extensive and impressive and taken together constitute an enormous outpouring of affection and admiration for both the author and her creation whose appeal is as fresh and undimmed now as it was when he first burst upon an unsuspecting world in nineteen nineteen 

Richmal Crompton succeeded in mastering the short story form and in thirty-eight volumes over fifty years she developed a distinctive and self-contained universe through which to comment on society the family childhood and human nature 

Her work is best described as social comedy and she occupies a position socially and culturally that is midway between P G Wodehouse and Frank Richards 

The Wodehouse world encompassed West End clubland and the country house weekend

The Richards world centred on the timeless ritualised life of the boys ' public school

Miss Crompton 's world was essentially suburbia the world that she observed from the windows of The Glebe Bromley the house she built from the profits generated by her famous creation 

There was a commuting father who was something in the city a placid mother who when she was not darning participated in all the social rituals of suburbia  and a comfortable house The Hollies serviced in prewar years by two maids a cook and a gardener but reduced after the war like many a middle-class household to a daily help

Round the corner were The Lilacs The Laurels The Firs The Laburnums and Beech View

Every aspect of this world is faithfully documented in Mary Cadogan 's authoritative William Companion 

But the three worlds overlap 

All three are located in the mythified undifferentiated home counties and feature a common cast of supporting characters choleric retired generals do-gooding vicars absent-minded professors domineering cooks and assorted spinsters with bees in their bonnets and bats in their belfries the dog-loving the boy-hating the busybody the scatterbrain the short-sighted the long-winded 

But there is more 

Like Bertie Wooster William is troubled by aunts 

He also has to put up with a soppy elder brother Robert who is forever mooning about some girl or other and a sister Ethel who has all the brisk no-nonsense superiority of a true Wodehouse gel

Similarly William is the leader of an archetypal boy gang the Outlaws Ginger Douglas Henry and Jumble the dog serving perhaps as a junior version of Harry Wharton and the Famous Five of Greyfriars though William operates almost totally outside school 

The stories frequently deploy those old standbys of comedy the misunderstanding the coincidence and mistaken identity

But they unfold against the lovingly evoked suburban world of regular meals and formal visits garden f&ecircumflex;tes and flower shows good works and improving activities

The world of William is above all a world of societies in which the middle classes expend their energies their enthusiasms and their spare time ranging from the amateur dramatic society to the archaeological society from the brass rubbing club to the flower-arranging club from the League of Nations Society to the League of Perfect Health 

They 're all observed with an amused affection by Miss Crompton but she extracts endless and rather more merciless fun at the expense of faddists cranks proselytising enthusiasts who allow their hobbies to take them over and who seek to convert the rest of society to their beliefs

So the wilder fringes of such groups as vegetarians bird lovers spiritualists total abstainers literary bohemians self-sufficiency advocates and fresh air fiends all suffer from the fascinated attention of William 

People often think of the world of William as being a timeless inter-war period

But while William and his family never changed their environment did and Miss Crompton faithfully reflected the cultural changes over the fifty years of her writing life 

William lived on to the age of television moon rockets and pop-singers

But one of the most fertile sources of inspiration was the Second World War

To read the wartime Williams is to be transported back to the suburban home front but a home front observed from the child 's eye view just as John Boorman observed it in his autobiographical film Hope and Glory 

For the Outlaws the war is fun a glorious adventure providing new heroes and new experiences

Evacuation for instance is seen in Miss Crompton 's words as a matter of games entertainment unlimited food of unusual kinds and a glorious crumbling of the whole fabric of discipline

William as anxious as anyone to do his bit creates predictable mayhem against a convincing background of digging for victory holidays at home salvage collection the Spitfire Fund clothing coupons evacuees the blackout A R P land girls the Home Guard and the Brains Trust all the reference points of a past era perfectly preserved for posterity as they were occurring 

Ethel joins the A T S Mrs Brown is in her element with make do and mend and suburbia rallies round diverting its energies to the national effort 

But at the centre of Miss Crompton 's universe stands William himself inspired in part perhaps by Booth Tarkington 's Penrod in part by Miss Crompton 's brother Jack and later her nephew Tommy and in part by her own understanding of the child mentality

She gave her own summing up of his character in an article written in nineteen sixty-two





























Miss Crompton 's psychological observation is acute and this coupled with her infallible comic sense her fertile invention and her precise use of language enabled her to explore this multifaceted character for fifty years

Writing originally for an adult magazine she soon also captured a devoted youthful following both male and female

Children recognised in William either a kindred soul or a wish fulfilment figure

Parents could relate strongly to the mayhem and embarrassment caused

But above all to civilised society as a whole William represented the ultimate free spirit

His preferred occupations pirate smuggler highwayman red Indian his gang the Outlaws his natural habitat the woods the fields the lanes the old barn are all part of the same deep-rooted nostalgia for pre-industrial pre-adult innocence which has inspired the centuries-old idealizations of Robin Hood and Dick Turpin

It is the life of freedom freedom from restraint and responsibility from the humdrum cares of everyday life and from the darker drives and psychological complexities of adulthood

But most of all living for the moment enjoying life to the full under the greenwood tree or out on the open road 

Miss Crompton summed it up effortlessly and economically when she wrote  What 'll we do this morning said Ginger





The whole world lay before them 

or even more succinctly 

Everything had gone wrong today

everything might go wrong tomorrow 

but bullseyes still remained 

William 's basic philosophy is outlined in his essay What 's Wrong with Civilisation from a newly edited collection of his philosophical musings in the Happy Magazine



William 's recipe for happiness is thus to live in a cave rather than a house to catch and cook and eat your own food not to worry about the polite rigmarole of good manners or washing your hands before meals or eating with a knife and fork or wearing a collar and tie and certainly not wasting the best years of your life in school learning things that wouldn't be any use to me even if I did learn them when I might be going out with a club dressed in skins and fighting everyone I met and chasing prehistoric animals over rocks 

And as for modern inventions William thought them vastly overrated

Printing because it produced books you were made to read

telephones which enabled people to ring up and complain to your father about your behaviour

and photography which involves you being scrubbed and dressed up and forced to smile inanely 

He lived his philosophy to the full in his defiance of all the rules of good appearance and good behaviour

Truculent is an adjective frequently applied to William 

Miss Crompton was well served by Thomas Henry who illustrated thirty-three of the books before his death in nineteen sixty-two

He created the visual image of William as indelibly as Sidney Paget did that of Sherlock Holmes or C H Chapman that of the other William William George Bunter the fat owl of the Greyfriars Remove

Tousled hair hands in pockets shoelaces undone socks hanging down tie askew collar sticking up face grubby blazer crumpled cap on the back of head William was a walking defiance of all the canons of tidiness the despair of mothers and teachers everywhere 

This was matched by his hostility to school and his contempt for book learning which was very low on his order of priorities

When during the war they heard of the Beveridge Report William and his chums drew up the Outlaws ' Report which fully expressed their world view

A six point plan which involved having as much holidays as school no afternoon school sixpence a week pocket money no Latin French or arithmetic unlimited free supplies of ice cream bananas and cream buns no punishments and staying up as late as you like

The anti-intellectualism gave rise to plenty of the schoolboy howlers that William Brown shared with William Bunter and which gave their creators such amusement William for instance insisting that Guy Fawkes tried to blow up the Crystal Palace

But when he did fasten on a piece of historical information this could form the basis of an entire story as in the cumulatively hilarious tale of William and the Outlaws deciding to live like St Francis and the Franciscans

They call themselves Williamcans don dressing gowns call each other St William St Ginger St Douglas and St Henry and try to preach to Brother Cows and Sister Hens before disillusionment sets in 

But this demonstrates conclusively that William 's actions always have their own internal logic and were often governed by a strong sense of justice as when William is irritated by a local bird lover 's plans for bird week and so organises rat week with astonishing consequences

But it 's the unfairness to rats that stirs him to action and it 's this hatred of injustice and desire to right wrongs that leads him also into his consistent bids to puncture pomposity to deflate self-importance to undermine tyranny and to expose artifice 

William 's distinctive character is counterpointed by alternative models of boyishness soppy sentimentalised little boys like Anthony Martin a wicked parody of A A Milne 's Christopher Robin whose mother makes up rhymes about him like Anthony Martin is doing his sums or snooty know-alls who parade their book-learning and are often called Claude or more seriously William 's arch-rivals Hubert Lane and the Hubert Lane-ites sneaks cheats and pretended goody-goodies always trying to do down William and the Outlaws 

It is also underscored by the presence of girls which involves William in the eternal battle of the sexes 

William clashes regularly with the army of dotty spinsters in the community but most of all he has to resist the blandishments tyranny and unboyishness of girls who in William 's view are  soppy and batty and stuck up and stupid

They can't play fair or talk sense 

The ultimate incarnation of female guile and interference is the pretty frilly lisping six-year-old Violet Elizabeth Bott who has brought blackmail to a fine art with her unanswerable gambit

But what of William 's creator

Richmal Crompton would seem to be the antithesis of her creation 

a devout Anglican and lifelong Conservative a feminist and an intellectual she was a classics teacher in Bromley until polio forced her premature retirement in nineteen twenty-three

It left her lame in her right leg but ensured that she devoted the rest of her life to writing

She seems an unlikely candidate to have created the unruly anti-intellectual specimen of eternal boyhood

But what she shared with her creation was an imaginative inner life

William lived in a world of his own imagination fighting bandits taming lions capturing castles peopling the quiet lanes and orderly back gardens of his home village with all the fantastic adventures and characters dear to someone whose chief reading was sensational fiction like Ralph the Reckless and the Quest of Captain Terrible

Although her own omnivorous reading was more respectable Dickens Trollope Hardy Austen she too lived in a world of her own imagination

She never married claiming never to have been in love and described herself as the last surviving example of the Victorian professional aunt

The two excellent biographies of Miss Crompton by Kay Williams and Mary Cadogan which neatly complement each other and are essential reading mine her adult novels for evidence on her attitudes and relationships

But perhaps the key to her is her shyness

No one who has not experienced it can fully comprehend the agonies of shyness

This is Provence in the south-east corner of France where something much much more powerful comes out of the sky every day 

Sunshine 

And here on this dry desert it 's searing but mix it with a little water and life flourishes 

Since Hercules was here conquerors and tourists have all been intoxicated by this part of France its quality of life its colours and aromas  natural beauty and dazzling light 

Provence is a land of history of ancient myths and strange spiritual matters 

It 's little wonder that so many are still attracted here in search of a slower gentler lifestyle while human curiosity draws huge numbers of visitors seeking some explanation for the mysteries too 

The first foreign occupiers to leave their mark were the Romans who became lords of this land a hundred and eighteen years before the birth of Christ 

They claimed the South of France as a province of Rome

Hence the name Provence 

The Romans knew that such a dry rocky land could never be productive or civilised without plenty of water

So their clever leader Agrippa decided to carry sweet spring water from the hills down to the bathhouses and the fountains of their new settlements over thirty miles away 

All that is left now of this great aqueduct is the Pont du Gard 

This marvel of architecture was built from blocks of stone each weighing many tons and hoisted a hundred and fifty feet above the river Gardogne 

It was completed just nineteen years before the birth of Christ but still it stands 

Although water was a kind of god to the Romans the bridge itself had no religious meaning

Yet it survives as a monument to their power and influence

Obtaining a water supply was clearly worth all the trouble for the Romans occupied Provence for nearly five hundred years 

When Julius Caesar set up his military colony in the town of Arles he created a little Rome

It was the capital of his vast empire of Gaul

Citizens of the new civilisation needed entertaining

So they built themselves a magnificent amphitheatre for popular sporting activities 

Sometimes they used the arena for what they thought was an amusing way of dealing with political dissidents  especially the first Christians 

Before the big show the prisoners were kept back-stage in the dark until it was their turn to go on

They could hear the cheering audience of twenty thousand loyal Roman supporters beyond the gate 

Then they were thrust out into the blinding sunlight and there waiting for them a dozen starving lions 

Many died that way for their faith 

The people of Arles still use this amphitheatre but now for a a gentler entertainment 

This is Escolo Mistralenco dancing their traditional Proven&ccedille;ale farandole

Curious outsiders have always been attracted to Provence 

Vincent van Gogh arrived at the end of the last century to paint his vivid and expressive pictures telling us of his love for the place 

Sadly too much sunshine and far too much alcohol got the better of him

He died by his own hand in a fit of passion 

His images of Arles live on

Les Arlescans has hardly changed 

And this is it 

Les Arlescans means the Elysian Fields and for over two thousand years this was a burial ground

It was built originally for the pagan Romans who believed in nymphs and earth gods but all that was changed with the arrival of a Greek

He was a cousin and disciple of Saint Paul

His name was Trophemus and it was he who introduced Christianity to this land 

Soon afterwards a Roman civil servant called Genesius refused to publish orders to persecute local Christians 

He was beheaded

After his burial miracle cures started to occur by his grave

The word soon got round 

Later when Saint Trophemus was buried here too Les Arlescans became the most desirable graveyard in the Christian world 

A corpse could be wrapped in its winding cloth set afloat anywhere upstream on the Rhone

and when it reached this point the river people would hook it out collect the fee which was gold coins in the mouth  and then give it a decent Christian burial at Les Arlescans 

But interest in the cemetery quickly waned when the bones of Saint Trophemus were removed to Arles where a special cathedral was built as his final resting place 

Trophemus is briefly mentioned in the Acts of the Apostles 

There 's little doubt that he brought Christianity to southern France and was the first Bishop of Arles 

but as all other records and tales of his evangelical life were carved in the cloister nearly a thousand years after he died  his history is rather legendary 

As in most legends the dates don't quite coincide but the story is beautifully told in what is now considered to be the finest example of medieval stone carving in the whole world 

On the west end biblical stories and the deeds of Saint Trophemus are undergoing massive restoration paid for by a large grant from Unesco 



In medieval times Avignon was heavily fortified

It 's now the capital city of the region and a great cultural centre bustling with conferences and art festivals  but it 's lost none of its romance 

Even if you have never been here you may recognise the name Avignon

You may even have a mental picture of the place if you remembered this old song Regardez

It 's hardly a children 's song of innocence

They sing about young courting couples under the bridge in the dark 

Half the song is in Proven&ccedille;al regional dialect but the meaning hasn't changed 

In the past bridges were sacred places where magic rites were enacted at annual festivals 

The next verse tells of one young girl whose kissing got too passionate or so the gossips claim 

When her mother heard about it  she hurried to the bridge  ooh and she got her just deserts 

Of course publicly everyone disapproved of the goings-on under the bridge 

We all know where that can lead 

But then the Pope arrived 

He walked through the town giving out blessings and absolution to all sinners 

And finally they sing on the bridge of Avignon there they danced there they danced while under the bridge of Avignon the Seven Deadly Sins do their dance 

The bridge they were singing about was inspired by heaven

In eleven hundred and seventy-seven a young shepherd by the name of Benese was commanded by the voice of an angel 

Of course everybody thought he was quite mad but when he lifted a huge block of stone and lifted it above his head  then they realised that he was inspired by a great force

So in no time at all they set about building a much-needed bridge over the Rhone at this point 

The bridge itself has been washed away many times  but the song lingers on 

Avignon was once claimed as the centre of Christendom 

The fourteenth century was a time of great confusion with reforms and disagreements about who should be the Pope 

There was much more than theology at stake

The Church was immensely rich  and had great influential power throughout Europe

Political troubles in Italy led to the French-born Pope Clement the Fifth leaving Rome to set up here in Avignon  and so Le Palais des Papes the Palace of the Popes was built 

And what a mighty building this is

The Palace had to be defended against bands of mercenary knights who used roam the countryside just stealing anything they could 

Seven successive popes lived here before the papacy returned to Rome 

During that time both Avignon and the Palace grew

A university was established in the city and new churches sprang up everywhere 

All kinds of people arrived clergy merchants and artists  until it became one of the liveliest cities in the known world 

Meanwhile the Popes and cardinals lived in considerable splendour

It was essential that the Pope appeared to be the most important ruler in the world 

The surviving wall paintings tell us of their pleasures  hunting with hawks in the forest  fishing with nets from a pond which looks remarkably like a modern swimming pool 

The scale of this Palace is gigantic

It was designed to humble the ordinary man if ever he had to be in the presence of the most powerful church leader in the world

The popes had everything any mortal man could want 

If they wished to see the people they had to look down 

From this grand isolation they could afford to be very tolerant of life outside

and though many thousands came to see the Pope for advice and counsel  even more came to Avignon for the good life thieves smugglers and criminals 

The apparent decadence of the whole city aroused tremendous criticism everywhere 

Eventually after seventy years in residence  the rebel popes returned to Rome 

Their great palace was abandoned  but in Notre Dame des Dons God is still worshipped 

The sound of one of Avignon 's many choirs echoes through the stone arches of the cathedral 

As I walked about the great building I could hear Ensemble Vocale d' Avignon in rehearsal 

Where the mighty Rhone river meets the Mediterranean Sea its silt has created a spreading triangle of wild marshes  the Camargue 

A natural landscape which seems at first to be fit only for flamingos egrets and ducks 

but look closer 

and you can see the hand of man 

This unique area of salt marshes reeds and wind has a very special type of livestock farming black fighting bulls the kind that primitive men used to worship for their power and their bravery and they breed them here for the ring 

But the bulls are not killed

The ones who take the chances are these young men in white who try to grab a ring from the bull 's horn

The bull always lives to fight another day 

For most of the year the marshes of the Camargue are left to nature 

Each spring after the migrant birds have arrived others appear on a different kind of pilgrimage and they head to the little village on the southern edge of the marshes Les Saintes Maries de la Mer the Saint Marys of the Sea 

This tiny village is world-famous as the shrine of all travelling gypsies

Each May thousands arrive from all over Europe and beyond to give thanks and to worship their patron saints Mary Jacoby sister of the Virgin Mary and Mary Salome mother of John the Evangelist 

Inside the medieval church is a sacred statue of the Marys sailing in a little wooden boat how they came to be here 

The legend tells us that after the crucifixion the two saints and their Egyptian servant Sarah were set adrift by the Jews of Jerusalem in a boat with no sails no oars and no food

But with the divine protection of the Lord the boat was guided ashore to the foot of the church walls 

Of course over the years the pilgrims have improved this story so that the boat contained Mary Magdalene Lazarus and his sister Martha and various other saints and the whole lot were greeted by Saint Trophemus 

The reason that this is such a sacred place is because the two Marys remained in the Camargue with Sarah the servant and it is she who has become the most important person for the gypsies 

After her miraculous escape from the sea she wandered throughout the Mediterranean region and the gypsies identify with her nomadic existence and her life as an oppressed servant 

Today many thousands are heading into the town for worship and celebration 

Representatives of many different nations camp in the town though most are French and Spanish 

The pilgrimage to Les Saintes Maries de la Mer was established over a thousand years ago

Gradually it has been adopted by the gypsies as their special feast

I asked Beatrice  a French gypsy why this event is so special

It 's recorded that there was a chapel here before the ninth century when the first stone church was built

Here it is claimed were discovered the graves of the two Marys

The stones on which their bones lay are preserved in the crypt

For the gypsies they have miraculous powers of healing 

On the walls of the church are some delightful votive paintings showing miracles attributed to the two saints

In the crypt praying pilgrims queue all day for a chance to kiss the icon of Sarah

The heat of the candles is almost suffocating but here is found true adoration 

The little marsh village hums with anticipation

Each family group tells tales of their travels their ancestors their hopes and fears

The lives of gypsies are still no easier today than in the past

The men are proud never showing weakness and their music reveals their passion for life 

Accompanied by his son and grandson the gypsies ' great guitar hero Manuel Arenas 

There are thousands here today and the atmosphere is electric

Everything must go right as the gypsies are naturally a very superstitious people

Most of them are not conventional churchgoers yet they still consider themselves to be Christians

Just once a year many show their allegiance to the faith for this is their most important day 

Today is the twenty-fourth of May and the local streets have been taken over by the gypsies who are about to parade the icon of Sarah from the church down to the sea from where she came 

The icon is dressed as for a wedding with many layers of silk

They believe that every moment of the procession can be interpreted as a portent of the year to come 

The procession leads to the beach where Sarah is carried down to the sea

The excitement boils over

To protect Sarah from the crowd the local men of the  cowboys with poles form a barrier

But it doesn't stop people surging forward into the sea 

After Sarah has been presented to the sea most of the gypsies pack up and leave 

The authorities are strict as the local people have their own festival to celebrate but they 'll do that next year 

Next day the feast of Mary Jacoby another procession takes place but this is organised by the local folk

Ladies are dressed in nineteenth-century costumes

the men of the  wear Proven&ccedille;al print shirts and velvet riding jackets

Then they more or less repeat the procession of the previous day

The statue of the two Marys is taken from the church towards the seaside for their blessing 

There 's been much criticism that this has become another tourist attraction

yet were not pilgrims in the past the same as tourists

People come to see

Even non-believers are curious

They too want to feel some effect 

Everyone takes part just by being there so the tradition is upheld and the two Marys are still recognised regardless of what the crowds may believe 

Watching from a distance it was a strangely moving event 

The pilgrimage to Les Saintes Maries de la Mer began about nineteen hundred years ago and still they come 

As homage was paid to the saints I thought about all the people who 've been attracted here since the Romans first brought water and therefore civilisation to the area the early Christian struggles the grand popes and their palace and today the travelling folk who come to venerate Sarah with whom they identify and holiday tourists like me 

For centuries countless thousands of people have arrived in magical Provence for the sunshine and the quality of life that it provides

They also find little known stories and folk tales of Christian saints  and though history and legend are tightly woven together the truth is always there to see

As Jesus said man cannot live by bread alone

People always need something more than just the material comforts of life 

It 's called faith

I believe in the crucifixion as a fact and not as a tableau in an altarpiece 

I believe that he was crucified dead and buried and that we do not give enough thought to this 

Knowing the triumph that is to come we hurry on and do not care to give one Saturday 's contemplation to the moment of the failure of Christianity and so to the full range of its achievement as a success

Jesus died and it was a very nasty way to die indeed 

As a journalist for more than forty years I 've had my fill of executions

I 've seen a Prime Minister hanged very slowly from a low tripod

I 've seen a sodomite gassed

I 've seen a row of black marketeers shot  and I thought I would spare you the details which were always messy 

The worst thing really is the way authority tries to look stately on these occasions and ends up looking ridiculous and embarrassed 

How different it all is from the impartial punishment which the advocates of capital punishment imagine 

The only exception is the old-fashioned bloodbath the public execution where we are all animals together and a roar goes up as the axe flashes and the heads held high with closed eyes and parted lips

Ah that 's the real spirit of execution

Unless you 've been there and felt yourself part of the lynch mob it is a mere anecdote at second hand 

This has always seemed to me the essence of the reporter 's task to convey what it is like to be there 

Too many journalists nowadays sound as if they are writing their account from the same news agency tape 

In any case we have to rely on sources even more remote for our account of the Crucifixion though they are remarkably full and varied for so ancient an event 

They have been overlaid with an atmosphere of formality and ceremony which takes us out of the realm of journalism and into the worlds of art and symbolism and theology 

Because we know what comes next we find it almost impossible to concentrate on what the act of crucifixion itself was really like 

But to everyone involved at the time it was the end of the story of one reality 













Perhaps the main point I want to make about the death of Jesus is that it was not only extremely painful and protracted but it was deliberately meant to be utterly final 

It was a form of execution reserved by the Romans almost exclusively for the terrorisation of the slave population and the deterrence of treason and it was particularly dreadful in Jewish eyes

Dreadful shameful and disgusting

You will recall how Saint Paul says we proclaim Christ crucified even though this is a stumbling block to the Jews





The reference here is to the exhibition of the dead body not to a lingering execution

But the point is as Paul makes perfectly clear that the gibbet is defiling

and it 's interesting that the ritual described by the Gospels shows a nice awareness of the necessary details of burial 

The great classical barrister Cicero described the cross as that scourge the most repulsive and horrible form of death

A Roman citizen was supposed to be exempt from crucifixion

hence you find most of the early writers referring to Christians as mad or depraved for worshipping an alleged god who had suffered the death reserved for the lowest form of criminals 

A folly to the Greeks says Saint Paul where it was obvious to the Greeks that the gods were immortal 

It was sheer foolishness to try and sell them a god who even if he had risen again from the tomb had allowed himself such undignified exposure 

What Paul is saying then is that whether you are trying to sell the good news of Jesus to the Jews or the Greeks you have got a pretty unsaleable item on your hands a god who is accursed and unclean a god who is actually dead 

Paul and the early Christians were trying to market a revolutionary upside-down sort of god

Instead of a supreme king in glory he had first to be accepted as the lowest kind of slave butchered like an animal 

Christians today tend to take it for granted that we can easily take that as read

But I am suggesting that in every way it is almost insuperable and the fact that it was overcome in those first two or three centuries of faith is something that we must accept even if we cannot entirely understand it 

Crucifixion was only the climax of a way of death

First came the torture  the scourging and mocking the forced carrying of one 's own heavy cross or maybe a cross-piece for which Jesus was evidently too weak to complete the course

Then the nailing to the cross 

We know now how it was done and it wasn't the way it usually appears in the paintings 

That mysterious relic the holy shroud of Turin though a pious fraud I 'm afraid has got it right

Two nails through the wrists  not the hands because nails through the palms of the hands would not have supported the weight of the body 

A Frenchman called Barbet did some rather gruesome experiments in the nineteen thirties demonstrating this 

In the same way two other experimenters found out that if you simply suspended the body from the wrists with an additional nail through the ankles it was then extremely difficult to breathe in and out and that the victim in this case experimented themselves using rope lashings rather than nails

The victims began to lose consciousness after twelve to twenty minutes  which was not at all the drawn-out agony which the Roman executioner sought 

The Romans were not normally interested in this quicker death as that Christ underwent

They commonly provided an additional means of support either a kind of footrest or a small wooden seat no more than a peg really upon which the victim squirmed in search of a rest that was no rest 

The chances are that Jesus received a fairly orthodox execution

for we are told that his two fellow victims who presumably had been able to sit back and avoid suffocating themselves quickly had to have their legs broken so as to force their weight out onto their arms and thus hasten death before sunset whereas Jesus already weak from loss of blood was unable to keep himself on the wooden peg and was dead 

The spear in the side proves that and if there was one thing the execution squad could 've been relied upon to certify it was that its victims were dead 

Now I have read half a dozen books arguing that in some way Jesus was not dead that the haste of the occasion enabled his followers to revive him 

But there are so many reasons why that will not stand up  chief among them that it is not what the four Gospels allow

and the Gospels are incomparably older than any other version

They 're confused

They are not sure what did happen

But their very lack of neatness is convincing

Above all Paul whose job it was originally to expose the Christian racket and who must have heard and investigated all stories about it Paul was more convinced than anyone of its truth 

It is not my business to write the next chapter of this story and perhaps it is just as well for I do not pretend to know exactly what happened

But that something happened something extraordinary which compelled the belief of the early Christians against all probability that I must believe 

And I believe it all the more because of the unpleasant fleshly facts which I have recounted 

One reason why and I tell it with some unwillingness because in comparison with the suffering of Jesus it is trivial  it is that I am in constant pain myself

Nobody is maliciously torturing me

it 's just one of the pains that flesh is heir to

I 've been fitted with a little electric box which is supposed to deaden it not I 'm afraid very successfully

No it 's not at all the same as being crucified

But it is a reminder that pain can be the one reality in one 's life

It can be the only thing that anyone even the Son of Man can think about

It is perhaps the ultimate

Is it hell 

I don't know but I do know that at the end as one gets near the edge  the body has a merciful way of switching off the sensations it cannot stand of narrowing down its sensations to the essential 

I have had the feeling of being crushed under a rock till I could see only one crack of light and that was the love of God

The absolute certainty when everything else has been taken from me that God loved me 

And then of course things rightened again and all sort of bodily inconveniences came back again one by one

You can't call it the sensation of having died

but it has been a comfort to me ever since

and I 've liked to think that round the corner of supreme agony there lay waiting for Jesus that same assurance that in the end and in spite of it all his Father loved him  and all manner of things would be well 

The Garden of Gethsemane is maybe the darkest place in the Bible

It 's where Christ is betrayed by Judas 's kiss

It 's where he accepts that death is coming soon

It 's where he understands that the last of his life on earth is upon him

For anyone here and now looking for a moment to grasp the essence of it all here it is the dark night of the soul

I think it 's where we can understand that the world of human frailties and weaknesses is about to give way to something else only half understood and mysterious certainly but out there somewhere nonetheless

After the last supper the disciples go there to the garden with Jesus

In John 's gospel it 's preceded by the so called farewell discourses when the disciples are presented with the mystery that 's going to unravel for them















They have no idea what 's going to happen

They 're stumbling around in the dark

They all insist that they 'd never deny Jesus and Peter who 's going to do it three times before much longer is adamant about it

We 're at the moment when there 's about to be a struggle between the earthly and the divine and that 's why this episode illuminates a world that we know

After all the point about Christ 's passion is not just that it is something which leads to good news but that it 's a struggle

There 's no puff of smoke

no magic trick deals with all the problems and people who look at it in that way seem to me to be missing the difficulties that matter and have to be faced

This is Jesus struggling with the knowledge of what 's coming as a man

The last supper is over

They go out into the moonlight on the Mount of Olives up the Kidron Valley that still runs through Jerusalem and they gather together



So this is the submission to the will of God not easily but in anguish and meanwhile the disciples aren't crowded around crouching in some kind of reverence or trying to help

They 've all fallen asleep

Luke offers the excuse that they 're worn out by grief

Matthew and Mark don't

Mark has them jerking themselves awake and then slipping under again three times while their master to whom they 've been swearing a loyalty that won't die has been facing the inevitability of his death as a man

Voltaire that eighteenth century scourge of religion used to refuse to let his friends discuss atheism in front of the servants 

Unbelief was one thing between consenting intellectuals in private but if it spread through society morality would collapse

he said



For the greater part of human history religion has been seen as the foundation of morality 

In Dostoevsky 's words if God did not exist all would be permitted 

But this belief must seem to us now decidedly strange

Whether or not we believe in God we inhabit a culture in which religious teachings are marginal to many people 's moral choices

When did we last hear in a television discussion or a newspaper editorial the simple assertion that something was wrong because God or religious doctrine said so 

Even a religious leader who said this would nowadays be branded a fundamentalist

Our moral language has been effectively secularised

Religion enters our conversations obliquely and with embarrassment

Yet society survives

The world continues uninterrupted on its course

What 's hard for us to understand in retrospect is how anyone could have thought otherwise 

But they did believers and unbelievers alike

No one more so than the man who more than anyone severed morality from religion Friedrich Nietzsche 

But he didn't believe that there could be a smooth transition to a secular morality

On the contrary there 'd have to be a transvaluation of all values a complete redefinition of our mental universe

It was necessary

But it would be a nightmare

And in a famous passage Nietzsche imagines the speech of the madman who announces to a secular world that God is dead and we have killed him 







That 's what it would feel like to lose the divine foundations of our moral world

Within a few years of writing those lines Nietzsche went insane and shortly thereafter died 

What is it these thinkers saw that we fail to see 

How were religion and morality associated in the first place

And how then being thought inseparable did they come to be separated 

Above all what happened to that predicted but strangely invisible tragedy Voltaire 's collapse of the social order Nietzsche 's infinite nothing 

The traditional connection between God and human goodness was straightforward

Revelation was legislation

Heaven had revealed what 's right and what 's wrong

And if it hadn't done so how would we know

It isn't that we 'd lack an answer

It 's that we 'd have too many answers

We 'd arrive at the situation described at the end of the Book of Judges each person doing that which is right in his own eyes 

What 's more the lawgiver was also the law enforcer

God 's existence guaranteed that the righteous would be rewarded and that evil would be repaid with evil

This answered the question that so troubled Plato

Why be good if you can get away with being bad

An all knowing all powerful God ensured that there would be no tax evaders in the kingdom of heaven

So religion underwrote the terms of morality

The knowledge of God led to virtue

And the Day of Judgement put a heavy price on vice 

But for the past several centuries that view has come increasingly under attack for reasons that now seem quite clear

God may well have revealed a moral code but it turned out to be a different moral code for Catholics and Protestants and Muslims and Jews

If we 're to sort out what human beings as such should do we 'll need something other than revelation 

Besides which as Kant suggested if you try to get people to be good by rewarding them if they are and punishing them if they aren't you don't actually succeed in getting them to be good

you merely succeed in getting them to be pragmatic

Then again though this had been noted long before by Abraham and Jeremiah and Job the view that the world was ruled by God on the principle of justice was difficult to reconcile with the facts

Evil prospered

The righteous for the most part suffered

And virtue had to be content with being its own reward 

For people of faith this only served to show how inscrutable divine justice was

But for those who brought less commitment to bear on the question it was difficult to see how inscrutable justice wasn't another name for highly scrutable injustice 

None of these considerations was conclusive in itself 

But by the seventeenth century other factors were at play 

There was the morally ambivalent record of religion itself its holy wars and persecutions 

There was the rise of science as a competing source of knowledge to revelation 

And perhaps above all there was that crucial transition by which in Lionel Trilling 's phrase men became individuals 

It 's impossible to pinpoint when and why the first person singular moved into independent orbit

but we can detect significant moments 

When writers embarked on the new literary form of autobiography when Rembrandt started painting his long series of self portraits when Shakespeare has Polonius say to Laertes this above all to thine own self be true the idea of the individual as a reality in itself apart from its social roles was beginning to emerge

Whatever the cause the consequence was clear

The independent self was about to change the course of moral thought 

At some point the revolutionary idea is born that religion far from enhancing our moral development significantly obstructs it

It keeps us in a state of dependency 

It takes away from us the need through trial and error to find things out for ourselves

We become restless with a demanding father who dictates the terms of our existence

Religion makes us moral children and if we 're to reach maturity we 'll have to do without it 

This idea given its fullest expression by Freud lies at the heart of three centuries of moral reflection in the slow movement from virtue to authenticity from morality as something objectively present in nature and society to something authored by the sovereign self 

It begins with Spinoza excommunicated by the Jewish community of Amsterdam in sixteen fifty-six an outsider in a community of outsiders 

Spinoza saw all religions as human constructs

The legislation of the Bible wasn't God 's law but Moses ' invention to turn a group of slaves into a nation

This then he said was the object of the ceremonial law that men should do nothing of their own free will but should always act under external authority 

In that sentence we hear the distinctive modern accent of the individual no longer shaped by but now set over and against religious commands 

Its echoes are taken up and amplified by Kant who insists that being moral can't be a matter of submission to an external authority

it must be something that we impose on ourselves in what he called autonomy 

Hegel goes further in seeing the Hebrew Bible as the product of a slave mentality

And with an air of Samson pulling the temple down on the Philistines Nietzsche demolishes the whole structure of Judeo-Christian ethics as a pious fraud the bonds placed by the weak upon the strong 

Not all these figures were moral revolutionaries

Kant in particular had a high regard for traditional morality and believed that he was merely underpinning it with more solid foundations 

But radical consequences were to follow

Once morality was divorced from a theistic vision of man 's place in the universe it became hard to see how any particular idea of the moral life had precedence over any other 

What could provide beyond what we are and what we want to be that further dimension of what we ought to be 

Science couldn't do so because it now examined causes not ultimate purposes

nor could anthropology because all it revealed was the immense variety of pictures different societies have had of the good 

The voice of God which had hitherto given societies their most compelling ethical visions had now been ruled ultra vires 

And so however conservative their intention the ultimate effect of these philosophies was to weaken the idea of any moral authority beyond the self 

A fateful process had been set in motion

This was translated in British philosophy into a sharp distinction between facts and values and in French existentialism into Sartre 's declaration that human existence has no essence 

Within three centuries morality had moved from out there to in here

It had become a matter of individual will or preference or emotion or decision

To suppose that moral judgements could be inferred from facts about God or human nature was to have the wrong ideas about language or reason or human freedom

Certainly moral philosophers could no longer tell us what to do

Nobody could do that

At most they could clarify our choices and summon us to have the courage to make them 

This was bound in the end to have political implications 

So long as moral values were seen to be out there in divine commandments or nature or society it made sense to assume a strong relationship between morality and law

Law enforced objective values 

But once the idea took hold that morality was a matter of individual choice it became hard to see how it could be legislated

You might still talk about a moral consensus but that hardly justified making illegal what a minority of the population sincerely believed was permissible

That would be what John Stuart Mill called the tyranny of the majority

Instead so Mill argued the only ground for making something illegal was that it caused harm to others

And by the nineteen sixties that case seemed irresistible and in Britain and elsewhere homosexuality and abortion were legalised 

It takes a long time for the speculations of a philosophical avant garde to become the taken for granted commonplaces of ordinary life but by now they 've done so

The orthodoxies of our time are that morality is a private affair a matter of personal choice  and that the state must be morally neutral 

But this raises a fundamental question 

namely does morality in any significant sense exist any more 

Put this way the question might seem absurd

After all we still use the language of morality

We speak of right and wrong good and bad justice and rights 

But these are all words which were once thought to refer to objective principles and it 's just these that we now believe don't exist 

The use of words like right and wrong suggest that there are impersonal standards by which our choices may be judged 

But if there are no such standards only choices then moral language becomes an anomaly

Some recent writers have suggested just this that our moral vocabulary is a vestige of an earlier age and can no longer be used coherently 

Perhaps this suggestion isn't absurd 

Pick up any contemporary book on how to live your life 

It will begin by asking you to define your goals

It will teach you to organise your time and relationships to achieve them

You 'll learn assertiveness so as not to be inhibited by other people 's agendas

Missing will be any suggestion of right and wrong 

What 's right will be what works for you

The great moralist of our time turned out to be Ernest Hemingway when he said what 's moral is what you feel good after and what 's immoral is what you feel bad after

In such an environment morality becomes a matter of technique alone learning how to reach our objectives or achieve self expression 

We no longer talk of virtues but of values

And values are tapes

We play on the Walkman of the mind any tune we choose so long as it doesn't disturb others 

One of the great motifs of moral thought in the last century  has been the crucial importance of private space the territory in which we 're simply free to be ourselves

Rarely in human history has the idea of an obligation imposed on us by others seemed so constricting and suffocating

And this has profound implications for our understanding of a whole range of issues 

Marriage has become not a covenant but a contract without binding force beyond the consent of the partners

Families have moved towards more contractual relationships between parents and children 

Sexuality is a matter of freely chosen lifestyle

Abortion is the right of a woman over her own body

Euthanasia is the right of each of us over our own lives 

What 's missing in each of these cases is the idea once thought to be definitive of morality that there can be obligations which constrain our choices and duties that place a limit on desire 

It 's not that we 've stopped thinking morally altogether

It 's that our moral imagination is bounded by three central themes autonomy equality and rights the values that allow each of us to be whatever we choose

The central character of our moral drama is no longer the saint or the hero but the free self unencumbered by attachments unobligated by circumstance freely negotiating its temporary contracts with others

Frank Sinatra singing I did it my way 

As a result much of what we used to do as moral beings has come to seem repressive even a denial of the human condition 

To make moral judgements is to be judgemental

Calling a way of life wrong is an assault on the integrity or authenticity of others

The most fundamental of all parental wishes  to educate our children in our own morality is indoctrination and a denial of their free development 

We know that not all choices are wise but we 're reluctant to let that fact serve as the basis for a moral conclusion

Since before dawn today Britain 's forces have been in action in the Gulf 

Their skill and courage has already been tested 

Tonight I want to explain to you why they are there and what this conflict is about 

Our troops are part of an international force

It is drawn from many countries 

It is acting under the authority of the United Nations  and its purpose is to end Saddam Hussein 's ruthless occupation of Kuwait 

He invaded without justification 

His army has conducted itself without mercy 

If such brutality and aggression are rewarded with success  then we are all at risk 

If you appease a bully you pay for it later  and you often pay more dearly 

We did not want a conflict

I need hardly tell you that

We have tried hard to avoid it

We have given Saddam Hussein every opportunity to withdraw

Time and again the United Nations has called upon him to leave Kuwait 

In the patient diplomacy of the past five months leaders from around the world have sought peace  and then sought it again  but Saddam Hussein has chosen war

He has rejected every attempt to reach a peaceful solution

He has rebuffed even the Secretary General of the United Nations 

At the United Nations the world agreed that Iraq must withdraw or be driven out of Kuwait 

We applied sanctions to make that point clear 

We refused to trade with Iraq 

Those sanctions made life harsher for Saddam 's people  but he was not a man to be influenced by their suffering 

Then the world set him a deadline 

Free Kuwait

we said

or we will have to free it from you 

but Saddam Hussein has rejected all appeals 

He has defied the United Nations 

He has increased his force in Kuwait 

He has tortured and killed those who opposed him 

He has tried to wipe Kuwait off the very map of the Middle East 

For our part we the rest of the world have acted with enormous restraint 

Time and again we warned him  and we offered him this promise 

If he would withdraw his invading army from Kuwait and return them to Iraq he would not be attacked 

Saddam has chosen instead to defy the world 

The deadline passed on January the fifteenth and still he refused to withdraw 

That is why we and our partners are now facing up to our responsibility 

It is to compel him to obey the United Nations 

We could not delay any longer 

Delay would have increased the risk to our troops out there in the Gulf 

Delay would have made their task more difficult  and delay would have extended the terrible sufferings of the people of Kuwait 

Our aims are clear 

They have been set out for all to see by the United Nations Security Council 

First we must get Iraq out of Kuwait right out of Kuwait 

Second we must restore Kuwait 's legitimate government 

And third we must uphold the authority of the United Nations 

We and our allies want nothing more than that 

We are not seeking to dismember Iraq 

We have no intention of imposing our choice of government on Iraq 

We are simply doing what the United Nations said should be done 

We are acting with the authority of the United Nations and on behalf of the whole world 

I will not offer you rash promises about how quickly this can be done 

The operation on which we have embarked involves danger and sacrifice  but I am confident that it will succeed and we know it is a battle which has to be fought 

On Tuesday members of Parliament gave the government their overwhelming support 

One of the biggest parliamentary majorities in recent history supported action to enforce the decisions of the United Nations 

It is a just cause 

And it is right that we in Britain should play our part 

I take no pleasure in this conflict 

but I do know what we are doing is right 

Our nation has been through many trials in the past  but when as now right and justice have been on our side  we have prevailed 

The military operation must go on  on until the decisions of the United Nations are enforced 

Then we can start searching again and searching hard for lasting solutions to the problems of the area 

We must try to work out security arrangements for the future so that these terrible events are never repeated  and we shall I promise you  bring our own forces back home just as soon as it is safe to do so 

It is to those men and women serving our country in the Middle East  that my thoughts go out most tonight 

and to all of their families here at home 

To you I know this is not a distant war

It is a close and ever present anxiety 

I was privileged to meet many of our servicemen and women in the Gulf last week 

Their professionalism is outstanding 

their confidence impressive 

and their courage undoubted 

You can be proud of them very proud 

Each one of them has Britain 's wholehearted support  and the prayers of all of us for their safe return home  and our prayers are also for you their families  who carry so much of the burden of Saddam 's war 

We are no less proud of you 

Goodnight and God bless

Since Iraq invaded Kuwait the whole world through the United Nations made two things plain 

First Kuwait must be freed from Iraqi occupation

Second  that should be achieved if at all possible without resort to military force 

Repeated attempts were therefore rightly made to fulfil the purposes of the United Nations without conflict 

They didn't succeed 

And whatever other reasons can be given one thing is absolutely clear 

The major cause of the failure of peaceful efforts was Saddam Hussein 's complete refusal to give any indication that he would accept the rule of international law 

Saddam Hussein has never cared about the suffering of his people 

Anyone in his country who might advise him to accept the will of the United Nations and to avoid disaster would have been executed

Protests about his policy or even complaints about its results would have been punished with death 

Meanwhile Kuwait was loo looted

Kuwaitis and other people were being beaten raped and murdered  and still  if there had been any evidence of willingness on the part of Saddam Hussein to leave Kuwait the war now being waged against him would have been preventable 

Tragically  it was not to be 

Saddam Hussein has now to be driven out by the force authorised by the United Nations 

It is essential for all of our sakes that the authority of the United Nations is upheld 

Its ability to be the major instrument for international security is now at stake 

If for any reason  the United Nations did not prevail Saddam 's aggression would have won  and if that were to occur all people who rightly yearn for peace in the world would get less of it not more 

That 's particularly true of the Middle East 

When Saddam Hussein has been expelled and Kuwait is again independent  the world community through the United Nations must focus firmly on helping the peoples of the Middle East to gain a just and enduring settlement 

In the Gulf area now the men and women of our forces are facing great danger 

They are showing and they will show great bravery and great skill 

They will do more than their duty in making this world a safer place 

We strongly support them  and as we do  we know that for many people in our country the war which our forces are now fighting is not only a matter of international principle or great and grim world events 

it is a matter of deep personal concern about the safety and the wellbeing of loved ones now engaged on our behalf in military action 

Those people most of all need to know that the conflict is in pursuit of just ends 

I can only say to them  that I am sure that  if this task was not done the world would be open to the prospect of greater catastrophe and greater disorder 

The purpose of this war is to enforce international law

it is to uphold the rights of nations to be independent and of people to live without fear 

It is in that spirit  that the men and women of our forces and our allies are going to win the war 

And it is in that spirit that we must build the peace that follows 

Good evening

Building a top-class economy a world-class economy  will take time effort resources  and consistency of purpose and policy 

So much is evident 

But the fact that full achievement is by definition a long term task  should not be used by anyone  as a means of denying the necessity of undertaking it  or of delaying the start 

The long term starts here

Before the Ribble Valley by-election  there was some debate as to whether the poll tax was in its death throes  or whether it would be revived at least in part

The message is now crystal clear 

The poll tax must go 

The people of this country are not prepared to tolerate to tolerate a tax which was so blatantly unfair  with an elderly couple on limited income finding themselves with the same bills as far wealthier people 

The size of bills they were expected to pay for their local services  is clearly exorbitant 

and many simply cannot cope 

And we can all see that this tax is virtually impossible to collect from some people  so that those who do pay are being asked to pay even more to cover the cost of defaulters

This is quite wrong 

There the agreement ends 

What to put in its place has been debated long and hard 

Let us be honest about one thing

Whatever is put in its place will not be universally popular 

There is no such thing as a popular tax 

But we have to pay for our local services 

and we have to be sure local authorities are using the money  efficiently and wisely

not always the case I 'm afraid particularly in the case of some of the London boroughs 

The S D P has always had a clear policy on local government 

We believe a combination of proportional representation  and local income tax  would enable local people to decide what services they want  and how much they want to pay for them 

Local income tax would wor would work like ordinary income tax  where the wea the wealthy pay a higher rate those on modest incomes pay a moderate amount  whilst those managing on very limited incomes  would pay nothing at all

Whatever the chosen system we must make sure that the bills dropping through our letter box  are fair reasonable and affordable 

I believe there is another important consideration here 

Some services should be of a national standard  and are too important to be subject to the annual fiasco of cuts  we have seen in our Town Halls in recent weeks

Vital services like the police and fire service should I believe  be funded nationally

The education of our children  is just too important to be threatened every time the local authority 's books don't balance 

I have been inundated with letters from head teachers school governors and parents  about their fears over what will happen to education  if Greenwich is poll tax capped again 

And that problem wouldn't be resolved if we went back to a property tax like the rates 

We were rate capped then 

Whatever the rights and wrongs of the poll tax the rates or whatever is put in its place  education should not suffer

With the local financial management of schools  they do have a lot more independence 

Let us fund these schools and our teachers from our national taxes  and not leave them at the mercy of the vagaries of local government

Mr Chairman uh Mr  Opposer uh ladies and gentlemen 

In eighteen twenty-seven  Sir Robert Peel after whom this establishment is named  told the House of Commons that owing to the changes which had taken place in society society had outgrown uh police institutions and the time had come for a new model 

That model became the Metropolitan Police 

In nineteen fifty-nine  R A Butler  told the House of Commons that public confidence in the police was declining  and that he was going to set up a Royal Commission on the police because he said  without public cooperation  and the fullest confidence in the system our police cannot effectively operate

The result of his enquiry were the Reforms of the Police Act of nineteen sixty-four 

Today not only public confidence but police confidence in the system is seeping away

There 's a whiff of decay in the air  and the British people have an intuition in these matters 

When they see fair play or justice being threatened they withdraw cooperation  from poll tax gatherers and police officers alike

Less cooperation means less detection of crime fewer convictions of the guilty and further damage to the social fabric

Powerless minorities seek reform through riot whilst others go further

Police become cynical standards fall they turn inwards and loyalties become distorted

The last Royal Commission based the present system on what they described as a political idea of immense practical value namely the partnership between central and local government in the administration of affairs 

Since then the uh local government has been reformed drastically  weakened some would say and the partnership has become unstable

The Audit Commission looking at the police recently commented and I quote





And what of those who have to serve this system

Not all is well here either

The public have been fair

We have the best paid the most numerous the best equipped and the most powerful police in our history 

yet recently the Parliamentary Home Affairs Committee reported its lack of confidence in the system for preparing and selecting senior ranks

Public opinion polls and the British Crime Survey show significant falls of public satisfaction 

Police have sought to redefine and clarify their role in this maelstrom  for the police system continues to move towards the law enforcement model and away from preventive policing 

Again the waxing powers of the State and of policing are seen to threaten liberties which in this country lie unprotected by a Bill of Rights

The reputation of our criminal justice system has been damaged recently by investigative malpractice and Lord Scarman voices public disquiet and concern when he says we simply cannot go on like this

There are difficulties with our police disciplinary system

for more and more aggrieved members of the public turn to the civil courts for redress 

Last year over half a million pounds was paid out for false arrest and malicious prosecution in London alone 

Therefore it is necessary to turn to reform 

The primary object of a new police might be couched in the following or similar terms

quote

the protection of human rights fundamental freedoms and the institutions of democratic government

unquote 

The roots of a new police should be firmly grounded in local communities at district council or London borough level  with community councils in the cities and parish councils in the rural areas having consultative status

There should be three main divisions of police 

One service police locally based 

Two support police regionally based

Three a national police bureau to deal with national and international issues including the Europe after nineteen ninety-two

The existing national functions of the Metropolitan Police should be hived off to the new national police bureau leaving the Metropolitan Police to police London 

Now other reforms should include judicial supervision of criminal investigations into serious crime  a code of civil remedies in cases where damage through police negligence or malpractice has occurred a completely independent police and public complaints authority and a revised police discipline code and a new Police Act to define the hazy issue of police accountability

Now given all these reforms or something like them the police would be entitled to expect  or to demand even the fullest public cooperation without which the system doesn't work 

I ask you to support the motion

Mr Chairman Mr Proposer

I oppose the motion 

and I do so on the basis that  as a senior police officer I have  for the last seventeen years been involved in the organisation  and the management of police forces in various parts of England and Wales

I have served in rural and urban areas comprising a variety of political backgrounds 

And I conclude  that the public can have every confidence in our present system of policing 

Mr Chairman I smell no decay

I see no lack of confidence in the police service

nor do I detect anything hazy about our accountability
