nor do I find any nervousness abroad

But let me dwell for a moment upon the system  which divides the responsibility for policing in this country  between three key players 

There is firstly a police authority  made up of elected councillors and magistrates with a statutory duty  to provide an efficient force and to fund forty-nine per cent of its budget

The Chief Constable is responsible for the operational running of his force  answerable to the police authority who hires him and which can if certain conditions prevail  fire him 

The Home Secretary who provides general guidance and advice

He provides fifty-one per cent of our finances and he maintains a common standard of efficiency  through the offices of the Inspectors of Constabulary 

I accept of course that the Metropolitan Police has a structure which is unique to London 

The tripartite system is a fine example of the checks and balances that each has upon the other  the art of the compromise  the art of the reasonable person behaving in a reasonable manner which is geared to policing vastly different communities  many with their own traditions  their own way of life and in my particular case their own language 

I would suggest that such conflicts as have occurred in the past within police authorities have done so because the vital element of reasonableness was absent

and often people were more concerned with the pursuit of individual power than the wellbeing of the society they were serving

Such difficulties should not of themselves be sufficient reason to seek to fundamentally change our way of policing which has served us well over the last a hundred and fifty years and I would suggest  has stood the test of time

We need to remember that the vast majority of forces in this country  carry out their responsibilities in an efficient  and sensible manner

We hear little of the day to day successes but only of the odd occasion when conflict arises

Such isolated incidents prompt immediate calls for change but this does not in my view  justify the contention that the public cannot have confidence in the system 

It would Mr Chairman be idle of me to stand here and seek to ignore the issues of dissatisfaction in policing standards which feature in the media  from time to time

It would be totally unappropriate to mention specific cases  but recent legislation by way of the Police and Criminal Evidence Act has addressed the substantial areas of dissatisfaction

The ready access of prisoners to legal advice  the tape recording of interviews  and more recently the videoing of interviews will go a long way to dispel the concerns  often voiced by defence counsel during trials

The Labour Zidder scheme ensures unlimited and random access  to persons held in police custody

The introduction of the Independent Police Complaints Authority  with its wide powers of intervention and supervision of the investigation of complaints can but reassure the doubting public 

The introduction of the Crown Prosecution Service separated the investigative from the prosecution process and this ensures that only  those cases which meet the Attorney General 's criteria are prosecuted in our criminal courts 

So much Mr Chairman for the legislative changes of recent times which have been introduced to ensure confidence in our policing systems

What of the British policeman himself 

We have never before attracted the quality of recruits that we see entering the service today 

The percentage of graduates has greatly increased and the variety of backgrounds of the officers ensures a representative spread of the community as a whole

The restructured and reformed training systems  which seek to inculcate at an early stage the confidence and the exercise of discretion which produces I would say a more thoughtful and caring officer attuned to the needs of his changing community 

In serving the public Mr Chairman we must identify their needs and concerns 

Formal and informal contacts from neighbourhood watch schemes to community town and district councils ensures a channel of close communication 

Our specialist teams dealing with the investigation of child abuse work closely with social services

Our involvement in victim support schemes and our support for the Victims ' Charter clearly displays our community commitment as does our cooperation in the multi-agency approach to crime prevention

The police service from constable to chief officer recognises the importance of the quality of service that we must deliver to our public 

We have confidence that our commitment will ensure that the British public can have every confidence in our present system of policing 

I beg to oppose

Owls are one of the most beautiful of all birds 

strange secret night-hunters flying on silent wings beneath the stars 

One of the loveliest of them all is the barn owl with its grey gold and white plumage  and a charming Oriental-looking face 

For centuries these birds have been admired by farmers and country people 

They were given quaint names such as Old Hushwing  Jenny Hoolet and Cherubim

And as early as the seventeenth century special owl windows were built into barns  to encourage them to nest there and so of course rid the farm of rats and mice 

That was at a time when barn owls were plentiful 

But how many of you have seen one recently 

Sadly Old Hushwing is no longer part of the great meadows of our countryside 

One of the problems of course is that the new agricultural methods have decreased grassland areas which were the birds ' feeding grounds  and removed the old barns and hollow trees in which they could roost and nest 

Barn owls now have to hunt their prey along the grassy verges of roads  so as many as five thousand birds are killed by cars and lorries in a year 

A recent survey by the conservation charity called The Hawk and Owl Trust showed that throughout Britain and Ireland the owl population had decreased by seventy per cent  in the last fifty years 

But The Hawk and Owl Trust acted quickly  setting up a most imaginative countrywide project called the Barn Owl Conservation Network 

This is run almost entirely by volunteers who  with the landowners and the farmers find the sites where the barn owls are now living 

Then they work out how each site can be linked up to the next  by a corridor of grassland hedgerow and waterway 

The landowners and farmers along the corridor maintain a narrow strip of chemical-free grassland where the birds can hunt  thus linking owl family to owl family and forming a network away from the worst hazards of modern life 

In only two years this has met with enormous success  in England and Scotland where barn owls can now be seen feeding in these new habitats  and what 's more important breeding in carefully selected nestboxes  which are placed where the buildings and hollow trees no longer exist 

In the three hundred boxes  that the Trust has already provided one thousand two hundred baby owls have been reared by their parents 

But by this time next year a quarter of the traditional nesting sites may have disappeared

So new nestboxes for barn owls are urgently needed 

They 're about as big as tea chests and they cost thirty pounds each and the owls love them 

For centuries these wonderful birds have been our neighbours and friends 

Surely now we can do something to help them 

Given the funds The Hawk and Owl Trust can do just this 

But it is a charity that needs your help and I hope you 'll give it 

Please phone in credit card donations  on O eight one nine nine two  five five two two

The lines are open until eleven o'clock this morning 

The number again is  O eight one nine nine two  five five two two 

Or you can post your gift to me  Gerald Durrell  The Hawk and Owl Trust P O Box seven London  W three six X J 

That 's The Hawk and Owl Trust  P O Box seven London W three six X J 

The address is on today 's page of the Radio Times and on the page six three eight of Ceefax 

Please help The Hawk and Owl Trust to save this magic bird of sundown and twilight  and ensure that our children 's children will be able to see a barn owl silent as a cloud  drifting over the fields of our countryside

I 'm Edgar Wilson

I 've got one head two arms two legs a wife two children and a mortgage

Since I left school at sixteen I 've been gainfully employed in surprisingly respectable jobs in engineering and education 

I was born in Durham and I 'm glad to be a Geordie 

I 'm very proud of being British as well and I admit that tears come to my eyes when I watch something like the recent services commemorating the Battle of Britain 

But for me being patriotic has nothing to do with our monarchy

I think that the idea of hereditary privilege especially hereditary office is totally incompatible with the democratic ideals that British people have fought and died for 

I think that these democratic ideals still have to be achieved in Britain and I hope to show in this programme that this can't be achieved until Britain becomes a republic 

These ideas have been spreading and taken for granted everywhere else in the developed world for hundreds of years so it 's absolutely amazing that in Britain republicanism is something that 's hidden in the closet 

Although I publish quite a lot I discovered a couple of years ago that no mainstream publisher wanted to publish a negative analysis of the British monarchy that I 've written 

I have no doubt that some kind of taboo is at work

At the time there were about two hundred and forty books in print about the British monarchy  and only one of them was critical 

Opponents of republicanism in Britain have always tried to make out that republicanism is a philosophy of cold-hearted rationalism for humourless zealots and nutters of all sorts 

I don't recognise any of this

Far from being cold-hearted the great eighteenth century rationalist republican Thomas Paine who 's been called the greatest Englishman got himself sentenced to the guillotine because he argued passionately in the assembly of the French Revolutionary Council for the life of King Louis 

And speaking for myself I 've always been more impressed by comedians than by most politicians 

In my opinion the case for republicanism is unanswerable  but it 's not often heard 

But I feel the time is right now for people in Britain to consider it 

Although the monarchy is supposed to be part and parcel of British life people of all sorts can envisage Britain without a monarchy

Brian Micklethwaite is one of the new breed of Conservatives 

Although he has no ambitions for political office he devotes his time to exploring ideas that might be taken up as the policy of the Conservative party  

As I was passing through Newcastle station recently I asked some young women what their views were on the monarchy  

These young women obviously didn't feel that there was any taboo about the monarchy 

Like many people who criticise the monarchy they mentioned the wealth of the Royal Family 

Andrew Morton is a journalist and author who has studied the extent of their private wealth  

There are wealthy people in every country of course

What I find shocking and offensive is the way that the special hereditary position of the Royal Family has increased their wealth in recent years whereas their public responsibilities have been greatly reduced over the centuries 

The large private fortune of the Royal Family grows very quickly because their private income is exempted from tax 

Everybody knows that they receive income from the civil list for royal duties 

Most republicans wouldn't carp at this because all heads of state have to be paid for

But really the financial provisions for our Royal Family are far too generous especially when many people in this country are so badly off 

There 's often misunderstanding about royal finances however because there are crown lands that generate income which isn't paid to the Royal Family 

Royalists say that the country makes a profit out of the monarchy

Andrew Morton explains how this idea is mistaken   

Those people were interviewed outside Buckingham Palace

Like many others they believe that having a Royal Family is good for Britain 's tourist industry 

I couldn't find any real evidence that it is

Anyway other countries in Europe such as Austria and Switzerland make far more money out of tourism than we do and they are republics 

Of course republicanism isn't about the Royal Family failing as a tourist attraction but even so it is interesting to discover that it isn't a very great attraction 

The British Tourist Authority 's own figures show that the main tourist attractions have very little to do with living royalty

They 're places like Madame Tussaud 's Alton Towers and the Natural History Museum 

I took this up with the B T A 's chairman William Davis  

Despite William Davis 's predictable enthusiasm it seems to me that the Royal Family are at best marginal to tourism 

When you look at that other common idea that the monarchy is good for trade trade follows the flag and all that it turns out that this is a myth as well 

Personally I agree with H G Wells that it is a great mistake to regard the head of state as a sales promoter

Even so people do and when I checked the statistics for trade with countries visited by the Queen I discovered that there was no evidence that such visits significantly promote trade

In fact if anything the opposite is true

More likely than not either trade falls or a growth rate is reduced or the trade balance is made worse

Occasionally trade may improve after a visit but on the other hand it may not

Trade with China fell significantly after the royal state visit in nineteen eighty-six

I asked William Davis what effect he thinks the Royal Family have on trade  

I must say that until I 'd spoken to William Davis I 'd no idea that the monarchy was the only bright spot on our horizon 

Whatever doubts there may be about our trade and tourism there 's no doubt that the monarchy is good for the business of newspapers and magazines that trade on the popular interest shown in the Royal Family 

In the past the Royal Family didn't receive much media attention 

The most influential writer on the English constitution Walter Bagehot warned that daylight should not be let in on the magic of the monarchy if its prestige is to be preserved

The show-business style spotlight put on it these days is something new and not necessarily to the benefit of the monarchy 

I discussed royalty 's role in the newspapers with Roy Greenslade the editor of the Daily Mirror  

The apparent popularity of the Royal Family is the most obvious fact about it

I 've always found this puzzling in a democracy

Most people are quite content to at least take it for granted and some react very strongly against any suggestion that we might change or abolish it 

I asked Dr Anthony Clare whether as a psychiatrist he could explain the popularity of the monarchy 

It seems that many people are deeply attached to the monarchy despite the fact that some of the things they believe about it aren't true

Indeed it may be because they are ideals and not truths that they are so deeply attached to them 

This must influence people 's attitude to change and to the suggestion that we can only really be democratic if we don't have a monarchy 

I talked to Anthony Clare about the way British people feel about republicanism 

For me the need to alter the British constitution to change the role of the monarchy arises because it has real power and influence 

Many people know that the Queen may dissolve Parliament and appoint a Prime Minister

These powers could be decisive if there were ever a hung Parliament 

There are also considerable prerogative powers that may be exercised in a state of emergency 

And despite the pro-monarchist view that the Queen represents all the British people I think the only way that can be established is through the ballot box

And she doesn't represent me or people like me 

But most importantly perhaps the monarchy is also used to conserve and protect an elaborate system of established privilege and power 

Labour M P Tony Benn has studied the constitution throughout his political life and is currently drafting his own Government of Britain Bill in which he will be proposing to end the existing powers and influence of the monarchy 

He explained how these powers work in Britain  

As a republican from the traditional left I 'm astonished and delighted to see how much interest there is in constitutional change which involves the monarchy

Tony Benn detects support for constitutional reform of the monarchy across the widest political spectrum  

Most recently the deputy director for the Free Market Institute for Economic Affairs which has close links with the Conservative party published proposals which would strip the monarchy of its powers 

It seems to me significant that the I E A has since felt it necessary to retract these proposals and I couldn't find a Conservative politician who would confirm an enthusiasm for such measures

However Brian Micklethwaite speaks for the thrusting entrepreneurs in the Conservative party 

He 's executive director of the Libertarian Alliance which is a journal devoted to developing the same sort of free market policies as the Institute for Economic Affairs

He has wide contacts with young Conservatives and has himself helped to develop their ideas

He 's certain that republicanism is in the air for these people  

So far I 've taken it for granted that the monarchy is widely popular 

I 've always suspected that its popularity is exaggerated however

According to the results of the MORI poll published last January only eleven per cent of people say that the monarchy is important to their own lives

I think that this is really highly significant and could indicate a change in public attitudes to the monarchy that Anthony Clare also perceives 

I agree with Anthony Clare that we are in a transitional period

Entry into Europe is forcing us to question many aspects of our constitution

At a time like this it is important for stability to have traditions but I believe that the tradition we should look to is the one we can be most proud of the radical one of questioning traditions logically 

In this spirit I believe we should seriously question the tradition of the monarchy

In my opinion we would have more to be proud of if our country wasn't a kingdom

Tonight we have Robin Williams and Robert De Niro in Awakenings

Good evening

Awakenings is based on a true story

It 's about a group of latterday Rip Van Winkles who in a Bronx hospital in nineteen sixty-nine were briefly awakened from a catatonic state in which they 'd existed for thirty or even forty years 

Robin Williams is the diffident but dedicated doctor who brought about this apparent miracle

Robert De Niro is chief among the patients 

What had plunged all these people  into a state barely distinguishable from death was the side-effects of encephalitis from which they 'd all suffered in the nineteen twenties 

What brought them back to life was Williams ' experimental use of the drug L-Dopa normally used in the treatment of Parkinson 's Disease 

Goodness knows how accurate it all is

But the film adapted by Stephen Zillion from a book by Oliver Sacks and directed by Penny Marshall is fascinating gently amusing and at times very moving

And yet  well we 'll come back to and yet in a minute

The good points first

Williams is fine as a man so painfully shy as to be almost unable to function in normal society but still driven and pig-headed enough to continue his experiments despite the scepticism of his hospital chief John Hurd 

Well De Niro who is that original one has rightly won an Oscar nomination

And he 's as good as you 'd expect 

There are plenty of memorable and touching moments too

The wonder and exhilaration of the awakenings and then the awful realisation that miracles are not for ever that these people haven't been given life they 've only been lent it

It 's in the scenes when De Niro fighting against an on-rush of uncoordinated tics and twitches is beginning to relapse into the coma from which he 'd been so recently aroused that he and Williams are particularly impressive

And yet  there are so many questions unanswered

For a start the patients cannot at any stage have been braindead  otherwise they couldn't have adapted so well when awakened

You see what I mean

De Niro had been  asleep for thirty years and yet there he 's perfectly logical and cogent

So what one wonders is what went on in his mind

What went on in all their minds during those comatose years

The film doesn't tell us

Neither except most perfunctorily does it show their reaction to waking up in a world of T V junk foods miniskirts nuclear weapons rock and roll and all the other wondrous gifts of modern civilisation

So now let 's get on to Blood Oath another story based on facts

During the Second World War eleven hundred Australians were held in a Japanese prisoner-of-war camp on Ambon Island in Indonesia

Only three hundred survived 

Blood Oath set in nineteen forty-six deals with the prosecution for war crimes  of ninety-one Japanese officers and men who ran the camp

A bad time to bring out a war film particularly in view of the fact that the video release of Memphis Belle has been delayed on the grounds that it 's inappropriate in the present climate 

Well no I don't think so

Indeed Blood Oath serves as a salutary reminder that it behoves us all to keep an eternally watchful eye on our leaders whoever they may be

Sceptics turn their eyes to that deadliest form of international trade arms sales

History is on their side 

During that flurry of early twentieth century entente cordiale it was the dreadnoughts in the German and British shipyards which told a different story

With the ink scarcely dry on the United Nations Charter signed by the Great Powers in nineteen forty-five the United States and the Soviet Union began a menacing nuclear-tipped arms race 

Will the impact of the Gulf War be any different

Or will it very swiftly be business as usual for the world 's armourers eyeing that once lavish market in the Middle East a region which has only three per cent of the world 's population but fuelled forty per cent of the global arms trade in the nineteen eighties

Sir Anthony Parsons former British Ambassador to the United Nations was in charge of the British Embassy in Teheran when the Shah fell and began his diplomatic career as our military attach&eacute; in Baghdad nearly forty years ago 

But has that lesson been learned

The arms trade operates in an alibi society

The manufacturers in Britain France and America all say rightly that theirs is not a free market governments regulate them with controls and export licences

The buck and with it the moral responsibility is conveniently passed to the politician

In Britain it stops on the desk of Douglas Hurd the Foreign Secretary 

What will go into the making of that logical and realistic approach

Already the Prime Minister John Major has pressed for a U N register of arms transfers

The five permanent members of the Security Council between them account for nearly ninety per cent of all arms sales to the Middle East

President Bush has announced the United States 's intention of destroying its stockpile of chemical weapons provided the current talks in Geneva succeed in producing a treaty banning their use

There 's talk in Washington of a ban on sales of enriched uranium and the raw materials needed for chemical and biological warfare plus an agreement among the world 's most advanced weapon states not to sell any but the shortest range missiles to Middle East countries

James Baker the United States Secretary of State it appears has been pressing for more on the conventional arms side the kind of weapons that wars are actually fought with

Mr Baker argued for a prolongation of the de facto moratorium on new arms sales to the Middle East which the State Department has been operating since last autumn

Though substantial tranches of old orders signed before the Gulf War have continued to pass through the pipeline to Saudi Arabia especially 

The signs are that Mr Baker has lost the battle for the President 's ear to the more hawkish lobbying of the Pentagon and the National Security staff 

Congressman Lee Hamilton chairman of the House Foreign Affairs Sub-Committee on Europe and the Middle East is one of the group of influential Democrats pressing for a temporary freeze on arms exports 

The Bush administration 's policy of rewarding its allies with arms supplies does seem to find support across the Atlantic

Douglas Hurd the Foreign Secretary 

True

Washington is already an open book in this sense

Under the so-called Javitz Rules Congress is initially told in confidence about any big arms transfer the government has in mind

The deal is then announced openly when the State Department has agreed it

And Congress has thirty days to approve or reject the sale

Mr Hurd too has no intention of importing Washington style openness into Westminster

That central need to ease mutually reinforcing threat perceptions as Mr Baker and his Soviet opposite number Alexander Besmyartnik have been discovering is proving almost as difficult post-Gulf as it has during every attempt to negotiate a regional peace settlement since nineteen forty-eight

No

India with its regional superpower ambitions is one

There is another kind of pressure on weapon supplying governments too much closer to home

In the arms business the big merchants of the apocalypse are the governments who could grant or withhold export licences

The black market of gun runners is a problem of a different if worrying order

not least in Washington where given the size of America 's domestic market the Pentagon more than at any time since the Cold War restarted old World War Two production lines over forty years ago is in a position to determine which defence companies live or die 

Just how deeply has the current post-Gulf moratorium on new exports bitten already

Joel Johnson of the Aerospace Industries Association 

Was there ever an arms lobbyist in history who didn't warn about a dangerous gap looming in the production cycle 

American manufacturers do at least enjoy the largest home market in the world

But their British and French counterparts are obliged by their relatively tiny domestic markets to strive to double that figure if their costs are to be kept manageable

So export markets could be absolutely crucial to their survival

At all levels of income in the last decade people have enjoyed rising wages and salaries and increasing wealth

P E Ps Tessas building society deposits are increasing rapidly

All these are income which come to people not through any contribution from themselves not because they 've made any contribution but from the contribution which has been made by someone else and therefore represents an exploitation which divides the society and brings to those people who 've established that surplus and that enormous wealth at the top of society a solidarity with one another which gives them that class entity which is so obvious to anyone who ever looks at how they work

These are utterly hierarchical institutions totally insensible to any accountability

And the fact that they 've become more powerful in the society while even your blessed shareholders have lost out in the last seven or eight years is just another indication of the way in which the class has established new forms of solidarity and new forms of hierarchy which they didn't have before

That 's all that represents

What he doesn't say is that over the last few years particularly but certainly development over the last hundred and fifty years fewer and fewer companies have controlled more and more greater and greater corporate power

There are five thousand manufacturing companies with a share value of more than a hundred pounds in this country

Twenty-one of those companies control a quarter of all the manufacturing output in this country

Tiny little bureaucracies totally irresponsible totally undemocratic

Now you 've got to show if you want to show it 's rapidly becoming a classless society you 've got to show that those bureaucracies those hierarchies have become weaker and it has not

Everything that has happened in the last ten years has indicated that this ruling class these hierarchies which control the means of production have become more powerful not less powerful

Everything about our society is dominated by class

It twists our skills perverts our democracy ruins our economy

We 've seen our great piles of bricks built up while the homeless grow

That 's the world we live in

It 's a rotten world perverted by class and it 's time to change it

The Metropolitan Police  were quick to introduce human awareness studies into the initial training of recruits  and nationwide police came to place emphasis on community policing 

Panda cars were out 

foot patrols were in 

After nineteen eighty-one  the public were alive to the gap which had developed between police and the society they policed  demanding more officers on the beat and consultation on operational matters  especially when the police had in contemplation a high-profile and possibly provocative operation 

Brixton 's Operation Swamp was not forgotten 

That was the street saturation operation  designed to tackle street crime in Brixton which the police undertook without consulting or warning local people 

Indeed wretched relations  between police and public were a root cause of the disorders

That is the lesson of Brixton

In fact  organised community police relations had collapsed in Brixton prior to the disorders 

Far too many police  disillusioned and distrustful of local people  pursued with a narrow intensity their law enforcement duties while viewing somewhat contemptuously  the tiresome routines of community policing 

In their view the home beat officer was a nanny

They were the warriors of the law 

But we are now assured that this attitude is past and gone

What matters now is not what the police do but how they do it

Indeed senior police officers and a wide range of ordinary citizens have in this inquiry gone to considerable trouble to explain this is now what matters  like Brian Hayes the Chief Constable of the Surrey Police

So consultation and cooperation with the public  as well as speed and a sympathetic understanding in response to calls for help from the victims of crime and a physical presence on the streets are what the public now seek of the police 

And as we 've heard the police have said emphatically that this is the service which they seek to give 

They declare that good relations with the public are more important to them than performance indicators of success in the battle against crime 

a view which I find comforting in the light of the uncertainty of any conclusion based on any crime statistics 

Helen Reeves of Victim Support underlined this

But is this the whole picture 

The ethnic minorities of the inner cities still feel excluded 

They recognise the efforts being made from the top to reform the police service and change attitudes  but do not yet give the police their total confidence 

They contrast the fine words of men at the top with what they see as harassing and racist conduct all too prevalent on the streets 

They still see the police a white male organisation harbouring a great deal of racial prejudice and tolerating or at least failing to prevent misconduct towards black and coloured people 

They speak of continuing racial harassment especially of young black men 

Put simply  the principles of policing as asserted at the top  have not yet made in their view a sufficient penetration at all levels 

The same situation is noted within the force by black officers like Sergeant Sultan Taylor

And dissatisfaction is not limited to the ethnic minorities 

Victims of crime  demand a speedy and more understanding response to their calls for help 

And many neighbourhood watch volunteers believe that not sufficient encouragement and cooperation is offered them in the task of preventing crime

Like Alan Jones who feels his willingness to help is resented

And the general public  who have had many spokesmen in this enquiry notably a forthright and impressive team from Scotswood in Newcastle  want the reassurance of a constant sympathetic efficient police presence on the streets

Contrast what we 've just heard  with Brixton nineteen eighty-one  when many honourable law-abiding people felt  that the less they saw of the police the happier they would be 

But is all the talk about change of attitudes  and specifically of switch of priorities to community policing  too complacent 

Is there a darker truth  beneath the attractive public relations chatter 

Are police changes of attitude any more than skin-deep 

Do not the police really remain  as to many they appeared in nineteen eighty-one to have become  a white male force encased in technology and moving almost all the time upon four wheels while they pursued their first priority  a policy of reactive policing by which is meant the investigation of crime and the pursuit arrest and interrogation of suspects  with a few breaks on foot to suppress some public disorder 

These questions need to be put  even though the police may with some justification think them unfair 

Historically they are unfair 

The policeman was seen from the beginning as the people 's friend the protector of the weak and vulnerable the enemy only of the bully and the villain 

Today the romantic vision of the village policeman and the fictitious character of Police Constable Dixon may seem to be legends bequeathed to us by a state of society which no longer exists 

But they represented in their time  values which are at the heart and soul of community policing 

The change of attitude  perceived as a fact by some  and as a necessity by all witnesses to this enquiry is in truth a reversion to old values 

What have the police done 

Has there been action on the ground  as well as the verbal pursuit of high-flown principle 

I think there has been actual progress 

An impressive example of action was described to me by the Chief Constable of Surrey 

It is a new way of policing a community 

As some of its officers told me it is clumsily but accurately described as total geographic policing

And I have also been told that the Metropolitan Police  are introducing what they call sector policing which is to all intents and purposes the same system 

This really is action  not words and it should work well 

However  Surrey is one place  the inner cities another

More is needed there where the police have to do their job in a community  which has to endure heavy unemployment homelessness and poverty and which includes amongst its most deprived  ethnic minority men and women at the bottom of the pile of wretched living and working conditions 

Yet even in the inner cities there has been a change for the better 

Progress has naturally been patchy  for confidence in the police is a fragile growth

Distrust in the police remains a disturbing presence

Hostility may no longer be overt or general but it continues to exist 

Let me just show what progress there has been since nineteen eighty-one  by dwelling for a few moments on what the police have done or have not done  upon recommendations for specific police action which I put forward in the Brixton Report ten years ago

Overall the police have done well  but there still remain one or two matters  where not enough has been achieved 

I look first at the recruitment of black officers 

There is still a long way to go before it can be said that the ethnic minorities are adequately represented in the membership of the police 

And women are still under-represented 

While some but as yet pretty few women are at last achieving promotion to senior rank  senior black officers are rare indeed 

I recommended an independent system for the investigation of complaints against the police

but I did appreciate  that such a system might well be beyond our resources not only of finance for it would be very expensive but of skilled manpower in the work of investigation

And let 's face it 

the police are experienced and skilled investigators 

Indeed that itself is a strong reason for allowing the police under independent supervision to investigate complaints against the police 

The Police and Criminal Evidence Act of Nineteen Eighty-Four  has established an independent body the Police Complaints Authority to monitor supervise and review police investigation into complaints of police indiscipline 

The authority could and in my opinion should be given greater powers 

But the statutory system has made a good beginning and the police are cooperating well  with the Authority

I also made some recommendations about the accountability of the police 

Accountability as all acknowledge is a necessary constitutional mechanism for rendering the police democratically answerable for what they do 

In Britain accountability does exist  but it is muddled and incomplete

In England and Wales police forces with the exception of the Metropolitan Police are accountable to local police authorities 

This is called the tripartite system 

But the division into three parts is unequal and not clearly defined 

Indeed on operational matters the Chief Constable gets nearer to absolute power than any body or person in our democracy save Parliament itself 

The Metropolitan Police are however not locally accountable 

They answer only to the Home Secretary and through him to Parliament 

While it may well be necessary  for reasons of national importance that this should be so  there is no reason why the Metropolitan Police should not like all other police forces in the country be locally accountable 

Finally I said a few words about handling of disorder 

The police have greatly improved their training and equipment  for handling public disorder

The true risk here is that they may go too far  especially in the development of weapons 

A vital principle in British policing is that of the unarmed policeman

There have to be exceptions

but they must be few  and the case for them made out to public satisfaction

Now  let me say again that is not a bad record by the police

Indeed I think it 's a very good one 

Now lastly I 'd like to look at today and at the future 

Community policing  which is rightly the priority of the moment is a method and a style of policing necessary in a civilised and democratic society 

But it does not define or describe the policing function

I sense a confusion  in public and police thinking as to the nature and the limits of the police function 

The police provide a limited  but crucially important social service 

I would identify three basic police functions in our modern society 

the enforcement of the criminal law  the maintenance of public order  and an invaluable  first aid and control function in the aftermath of accident ranging from catastrophe to a minor mishap 

Everybody wants to see a policeman then 

Law enforcement duty  requires a very real power over the citizen being entrusted to the policeman 

It is therefore only to be expected  that when a case of miscarriage of justice  is exposed by the Court of Appeal and is attributed by the court to police misconduct public confidence in the police is diminished 

Dramatic evidence that this is so has been provided by two very serious cases 

The Guildford Four 's appeal heard in nineteen eighty-nine upon a reference by the Home Secretary to the Court of Appeal  and a similar appeal by the Birmingham Six this year 

The first point to be made is that the Guildford Four and the Birmingham Six cases arose and were dealt with in the years nineteen seventy-four to nineteen seventy-seven long before the enactment of the Police and Criminal Evidence Act Nineteen Eighty-Four 

That act  was a great reforming piece of legislation and by and large it has been successful 

It has strengthened the rights of the suspect 

The act has however imposed a heavy administrative burden upon all ranks of the police 

But the price has been worth paying 

One may reasonably expect that the act will reduce the number of miscarriages of justice arising from police misconduct 

But is this enough 

In nineteen seventy-four seventy-five the year which witnessed the Guildford and Birmingham pub bombings in a sustained I R A campaign of violence  public pressure on the police to catch and bring to justice the perpetrators of these outrages  was enormous

In such a situation there is always a possibility  that an interrogating officer may be tempted to take a short cut to proof  by putting in evidence a false confession when he was certain he had caught the real villain or villains 

And that temptation will be strengthened if perfectly understandable pressures should be exerted from the top  to secure results in a case o of great concern to public opinion

An effective judicial control  of the preparation of serious criminal cases for trial could greatly reduce  the opportunities of police wrongdoing at that stage  or at the very least expose such wrongdoing before trial

On the lips of doctors

It 's really shorthand for the view that wellbeing depends on more than the absence of disease 

It 's not the case

so doctors will tell you that they 've only just discovered this idea 

Concern for patients ' welfare they claim  has never been confined to curing people 's illnesses and ensuring their survival 

Until recently though  doctors have had few methods for measuring someone 's quality of life

Such methods are essential because different people rate quality of life in different ways  and no assessment is valid until a great deal is known about the needs and values of the person being assessed 

Before considering how quality of life can be measured  what impact can assessments of this kind actually have on medicine 

Dr Michael Hyland is a health psychologist at the Polytechnic South-west in Plymouth 

He 's made a special study of the lives of people with asthma 

The most obvious use of any form of quality of life assessment  would be in making routine decisions about treatment

It 's one thing to use these measures to compare the benefits of two treatments for the same illness  quite another to use them in deciding whether more overall good comes of doing say heart transplants or hip operations 

If quality of life is worth measuring  who should make the assessment the doctor or the patient 

Kingston G P Dr Michael De Souza has a simple answer to that

So Dr Hyland like Dr De Souza before him  thinks that the views of both parties should feature in the final reckoning 

The first systems for measuring quality of life were designed for use with any group of patients suffering from any form of disease 

But general assessments of this kind are relatively insensitive

Hence the development of more and more quality of life scales tailored to specific illnesses 

Dr Hyland himself has devised what he calls a Living with Asthma questionnaire 

How did he begin

Dr De Souza would also like to see quality of life assessments in routine use  but he 's backing a rather different way of getting there

As Dr De Souza is well aware  computerization of this kind won't be with us in three weeks ' time 

What we will be seeing very shortly on April the first to be precise  is the advent of all sorts of changes within the N H S including what 's known as an indicative drug budget 

Henceforth the annual cost of all the drugs prescribed within each general practice will be totted up and compared with a figure which the health authority has deemed reasonable 

What effect does Dr De Souza think this will have on drug prescribing  particularly in relation to the quality of patients ' lives

G P Dr Michael De Souza 

The consequences and effects of changes within the N H S are matters we 'll be hearing a lot more about in the coming weeks 

Finally this week another development in our understanding of the causes of heart disease  and the extent to which those causes lie within ourselves  specifically within our genes 

Professor Steve Humphries is the director of a British Heart Foundation research group based at the Sunley Centre in west London 

He and some of his colleagues have been trying to unravel one of the complex mechanisms which govern the formation of blood clots 

It 's important to know how clotting occurs  because one which forms in an already narrowed coronary artery  and blocks it can trigger a heart attack 

There are occasions following a cut for example when clotting is essential 

Most of the time though the tendency of the blood to clot must be resisted 

but not so firmly that it won't clot at all 

A balance has to be struck 

Acting on the side of restraint  in other words limiting the formation of clots and dissolving those already in existence  is an enzyme

So having too much of this inhibitory substance  P A I is a bad thing 

But why do some people 's bodies make more of it than is good for them

That 's a question P H D student Sally Dawson has been trying to answer

Sally Dawson  whose work is funded by the charity Research into Aging

That was Mike Grierson a sociologist at Manchester University 

One of the driving forces behind the new interest in hearing voices is a Dutch social psychiatrist Professor Marius Bloggs of Limburg University 

Mike Grierson is one of those who have been influenced by his work

Besides being an academic sociologist  Mike Grierson is also the warden of a small block of flats for people diagnosed as suffering from schizophrenia 

This gives him continuous access to people who hear voices  and ample opportunity to learn about their experiences  and to understand how they themselves interpret them 

He thinks two are now a further source of insights

Some interpretations of voices are unhelpful 

The belief for example that the voices are emanating from alien beings who seek to control the hearer  is not only at variance with objective reality but likely to be taken as evidence of madness  and treated accordingly

If the hearer can be persuaded that such beliefs are false  and then encouraged simply to accept the fact of the voices  to accept them as part of his or her nature and being  that person is less likely to become isolated and stigmatised 

Mike Grierson argues that the first step towards achieving this  is to understand what the hearers themselves make of the experience 

Kevin O'Sullivan too is interested in this aspect of hearing voices

The true explanation of auditory hallucinations is a matter of debate 

There are theories rooted in the neurophysiology and chemistry of the brain  theories based on the way it handles information  and psychodynamic theories which might offer interpretations like that put forward just now by Alan Leader 

But whatever the origin of the voices  and however mild they have to be coped with

As Kevin O'Sullivan has found out people devise all sorts of strategies for coping with their voices

What then does Kevin O'Sullivan think that voice hearers have to gain by attending a conference on the topic

Alan Leader  who manages to put his own experience to good use  as the coordinator of the Lambeth Forum for Mental Health the charity which is organising Friday 's conference 

A couple of months ago we reported how medical ethics is being taught at St Mary 's Hospital Medical School in London 

Shortly after that programme was broadcast  Anne Bird Senior Tutor in the School of Nursing at the same hospital  wrote to suggest that I ought to have called in at the building next door to see how she and her colleagues were approaching the matter 

Belatedly I 've done so and learned that trainee doctors aren't the only health care students being asked to think more about what they do  while they learn to do it 

The new nursing curriculum known rather grandly as Project Two Thousand  stipulates that ethics are to be taught to student nurses but leaves decisions on how much and in what way to individual schools 

Anne Bird and her fellow tutors have seized the opportunity with enthusiasm

Anne Bird Senior Tutor at Parkside and Harrow College of Nursing and Midwifery 

Take three times a day with meals reads the label on the medicine bottle  or take twice daily or three pills every four hours 

But how many of us follow these instructions to the letter 

The technical term for this is patient compliance  an unfortunate choice of words perhaps with connotations of authority and compulsion 

But terminology aside it 's a problem real enough to have prompted doctors at Leeds General Infirmary  to organise a conference on it 

The reasons for which we neglect taking our medicines as advised include forgetfulness fear of side-effects and misunderstandings of the instructions provided 

Of course a failure to do so isn't always disastrous

Indeed in the case of say painkilling drugs to go on methodically taking them even if the pain ceases to be troublesome  would be foolish

In other cases though there may be only a limited margin for error before the treatment stops being effective 

You might think that finding out whether or not patients are swallowing their pills as prescribed  wouldn't be too demanding a task

In fact it 's extraordinarily difficult 

Dr Morgan Feely Senior Lecturer in Clinical Pharmacology at Leeds General has a particular interest in compliance 

First then what 's wrong with simply asking patients if they 've been taking their medicines

Joe 's aged five and bangs his head rhythmically against a wall

Anna seven years old clings to any adult she meets

Alan who 's eleven makes himself bleed 

Not normal behaviour is it 

When Joe 's father realised he couldn't cope with Joe 's behaviour he went to see Social Services

and they introduced him to Peter and Sheila who have a daughter of their own and sometimes two foster children 

For the last two years Joe 's father has visited him regularly at Peter and Sheila 's home

and on Friday nights Joe goes to his father 's for the weekend

Peter and Sheila are members of the National Foster Care Association and have been trained by them 

Thousands of babies children and young people who have had early experiences that have left them damaged need a foster family for perhaps a week a month sometimes even a few years maybe while their mother is having another baby or is too ill to care for the family and there is no other relative who can step in to help

So foster carers look after the children and keep them in touch with the other members of their family until the crisis is over and they can return home 

There are eighty-four thousand children in care in Britain today

Over half of them live with foster carers but more than twenty-seven thousand still live in children 's homes or lodgings

Many of these could be fostered too

The National Foster Care Association is the only organisation in Britain concentrating solely on foster care

It was set up in nineteen seventy-four and believes that fostering is the best way of caring for most children while they cannot live with their own families

N F C A receives some government funding as well as support from trusts and companies but this is not enough 

An important part of N F C A 's work is giving free advice to foster carers and children and young people in care

N F C A advise on the best way to recruit more foster families help carers children and young people who are having difficulties

They also answer many many general enquiries on fostering from the public

Foster carers involve the children 's families so that they don't lose touch

Two-year old Darren had to go into care when his mother Angela had a mental breakdown

His father is an epileptic and couldn't look after Darren so Darren went to a family who not only welcomed him but also his parents

The foster mother took Darren to visit Angela in hospital

And as she got better Angela was able to visit the foster home

In nineteen ninety eight thousand people used N F C A 's information and advice service

It is the only organisation offering impartial help advice information and support

And it must improve this valuable part of its work

Its current limited resources mean that some people don't get that support

A dedicated helpline must be set up

It 's this kind of immediate help that enables children and young people 's views to be heard and hard-pressed foster families to go on fostering 

Not everybody has the time to foster but everyone can help

Every penny counts and will mean a great deal

By giving a donation you will be helping those who foster and the children in their care

I was fostered when I was young and am very grateful and aware of the security and the love that it gave me
