It 's always been difficult in economies run along Marxist principles to arrive at any firm conclusions about exactly how well or how badly they 're doing but one economic law is immutable

The more exchange rates you have for your currency the more likely you are to be living in a country teetering on the brink of disaster 

In the Soviet Union for example the rouble is non-convertible

a concept which means crudely that it 's worth whatever the government can get away with charging for it according to different circumstances

If for example you are attempting to do business with a Soviet firm you have the dubious privilege of paying for everything at what 's known as the official exchange rate three roubles to the pound

Until recently it was one for one 

That of course would make almost anything in the Soviet Union absurdly expensive so there is a second rate for tourists ten roubles to the pound

Quite illegally there 's a third market in money as well the black market which it 's said values the pound at somewhere between thirty-five and forty roubles

The whole system makes it extremely difficult to offer any assessment of what is going on in the Soviet economy

A winter coat costs about five hundred and fifty roubles cripplingly expensive for most Soviet citizens

It is after all two months ' wages for many workers

But for Soviet citizens with access to hard currency and therefore to the black market it is cheap

Now it is admitted what one observer has called an economic experiment which lasted for four generations after the Revolution is slowly and painfully being given up

It 's an experiment which produced some bizarre anomalies

There can't be many other countries for example where the retail price of a loaf of bread is lower than the wholesale cost of the ingredients from which it 's made

In his homely efforts to explain the need for change Mr Gorbachev refers over and over again to seeing groups of boys playing football with loaves because they 're so cheap to buy 

The price rises of course won't solve these problems overnight

Indeed they might never solve them

But they are the product of months of agonising debate which have in the end forced Mr Gorbachev a natural seeker of compromise to take sides in the interminable argument between liberals and hardliners about how to tackle the country 's chronic crisis 

Last summer when the government first put forward plans to raise consumer prices it changed its mind at the last moment and a team of radical economists close to Mr Gorbachev produced a Five Hundred Day Programme for Sweeping  Change

The title was designed to give the people of the country a psychological shock and to remind them of the scale and the urgency of the task which confronts them if they 're ever to develop a healthy economy

In the end its proposals many of them now adopted by Boris Yeltsin proved too radical for the Soviet government

The plan was shelved

The reasons why are easy to describe and very difficult to correct

If market reforms are to mean anything then market mechanisms must be used to set prices

In other words the cost of buying something in a shop must bear some relationship to the cost of making it in a factory

But at the moment the function of setting prices for everything from spaceships to saucepans is firmly in the hands of the army of bureaucrats who run the Communist system

They are immensely powerful and they know that they would have quite literally no role to play in a normal economy

The labyrinthine agreements they draw up which govern every area of economic life would be replaced by what they regard as the anarchy of the market

Mr Gorbachev 's steady retreat from the cutting edge of reform to an increasing reliance on the traditional institutions of Soviet power like that bureaucracy might almost with hindsight be dated back to his decision not to endorse the Five Hundred Day Programme

His problem it seems is insoluble

Preserve the old system and the steady decay which has gripped the Soviet Union for decades will continue and perhaps accelerate

Tamper with it or as the radicals demand scrap it and the vital interests of the apparatchiks of the party are threatened to the point where they hit back

There is of course also the risk that the anger which the price rises will inevitably provoke might somehow result in an explosion of industrial disputes or popular unrest

When the impact of the price rises sinks in the fear is that the increasing hardship will turn that smouldering discontent into a fire which could sweep across the country 

It was commonplace at the end of last year for western reporters to write about the long hard winter to come 

Now for much of the country that winter is over and most of the snow is gone from Moscow

But the prospect for many people is of a spring in which the problems only continue to multiply

In a few days ' time the Lopez family which owns the electricity monopoly here and has banking and industrial interests is to hold a family reunion

The several hundred people who 'll attend will decide in secret which candidate the family should sponsor in next year 's presidential election and what policy changes to seek through the members of parliament it controls and the cabinet ministers it can influence to advance its economic interests 

The Hashintos the Delgados and the dozen or so other great families which make up the oligarchy that controls much of the Philippines economy will make similar choices

And through a complex web of tacit understandings behind the political stage they 'll ensure that whichever candidate wins they will continue to hold the reality of power 

This is not an Asian system

You find it in Latin America in Colombia and Argentina a comprador capitalism introduced by the Spanish during three centuries of colonial rule

Manilla has the heat and violence the colour the vibrancy and the squalor of a Latin American not an Asian city the fourth highest murder rate in the world bracketed with Bogota and Sao Paulo

The rich live in whitewashed haciendas on private estates among palm trees and bougainvillea protected by barbed wire fences and warnings outsiders keep out

The destitute live on Smoky Mountain amid the filth of the city 's rubbish tips

Just the recipe you might think for a revolutionary upheaval

But wrong

The oligarchy is underpinned by a conservative Catholic Church led by the redoubtable Cardinal Sin a church which this Easter as every year allowed the faithful to nail themselves to the Cross in a gory reenactment of the Passion of Christ

Suffering in this life wins redemption in the next

The Communist insurgency is running out of steam

The threat of another coup attempt appears to have receded

President Aquino is unpopular but is expected to see out her term

Change in this country is slow and rarely what it seems

Even the overthrow of President Marcos was partly a settling of scores between the great families and the so-called crony-capitalists that Mr Marcos had raised 

Not that politics in the Philippines are just an empty charade

After the Marcos dictatorship democratic institutions have been put in place

The press is the raciest in Asia and among the freest

Mrs Aquino herself appeared in court recently to bring a libel suit against a columnist who wrote that she 'd hidden under her bed during one coup attempt

But the tentacles of the oligarchy are not easily prised free

If Manilla today is a city of potholes and leaking water mains peeling facades brownouts due to power cuts and uncollected rubbish it 's because the rich have blocked efforts to raise taxes which are barely half what they are in Singapore and Malaysia and no-one in or out of government seems too sure what the remedy is

The root of the problem perhaps is that machismo the Church and the Wild West have stifled whatever might have been the Philippines ' cultural identity

And without a strong sense of national identity it 's very hard to know where you 're heading

During one of the many television appearances he made during the Gulf War President Mitterrand was asked by a questioner about the future

The fact was observed the interviewer that there seemed to be perfect harmony between the French and American governments

He wanted to know whether one could expect once the war was over the return of what he described as French specificity

It was the thinking behind the question that was revealing

An assumption somehow that an identity of views between the United States and France was freakish and that if business as normal were to be resumed then there had to be a French position that differed from that of that of the Americans and quite possibly everybody else too 

Mr Mitterrand gave no very precise reply to the question and his interviewer must still be waiting for the specificity to manifest itself

Since the war ended the cascade of French initiatives in line with the much criticised solo last-minute attempt to avert the war which might have been expected has not materialised

More striking still Paris which had been arguing for years for its solution to the problems of the Middle East in the form of one or more international conferences has shown a readiness to let the United States pursue its ideas and while not abandoning its own schemes has put them to one side

Quietly and without undue fuss all sorts of cherished aspects of foreign policy seem to be under revision

In the eyes of some the ghost of Gaullist foreign policy is being at last exorcised

That policy has been the victim of gross caricature over the years not least by those who claim to be its heirs

Ignoring the fact that at moments of real crisis the late General was firmly on Washington 's side they have deformed it to a point where Gaullism almost became synonymous with anti-Americanism and a Gaullist position was defined by the fact that it was clearly separate from the American one whatever the merits of the case

This policy embraced the belief that France had a special and privileged role as an interlocutor with the Third World particularly the Arab states and a special relationship with Africa

It was distrustful of the Anglo-Americans

Fierce national independence required the ability to perform a variety of military tasks naturally without allies 

Whether or not the General himself would have recognised all these characteristics as Gaullist the Gulf War has in any case largely put paid to them

The present French Foreign Minister can now observe that the famous Arab policy was a myth a succession of illusions and with only the most modest of outcries

Gone are the days when any ruler in Francophone Africa could summon French troops to put down local unrest as more than one has recently discovered

Opinion polls find that the French are more pro-American at the moment than perhaps at any time since the last war

The immense difficulty that the French had in assembling a force for the Gulf has revealed the extent of their self-deception in defence matters

Paris eventually sent twelve thousand men who performed in an exemplary fashion under American command another break with the recent past but the quality of their equipment was often lamentable

Much thinking is going on as to why the British with a smaller army could manage to despatch three times as many troops with much more modern equipment

It is clear now if it wasn't before that France 's military ambitions to be a nuclear power and to maintain forces able to intervene rapidly in trouble spots and to be capable of fighting a major conventional war in Europe those ambitions hopelessly outrun its capabilities

Logic pushes in the direction of a European Army closer cooperation with neighbours such as Britain and the sharing of some tasks and not towards fantasies about the ability of a medium rank European power to ape American abilities

There are even signs that France is edging closer to the military wing of NATO which she left twenty-five years ago

On the European stage reassured perhaps by Germany 's confused reaction to the war and its continuing problems of unification France seems readier to play a constructive role

The French are never going to have a relationship with the United States in particular like that of the British

Nor are they going to ignore their history their culture and their interests throughout the world

but one consequence of the Gulf War may have been to open their eyes to who and what they really are

There was nothing in itself remarkable about the embrace of welcome which Jalal Talabani received from President Saddam Hussein in Baghdad

It was merely a Middle Eastern formality conducted before the massed ranks of the international press

But the result was an image which will linger long in the minds of all who saw it 

the man who 's done so much to bring misery and despair upon millions of his people planting a fleshy kiss on the cheek of a veteran opponent

It was at one and the same time both sinister and absurd

How could it happen

How could Mr Talabani and his colleagues conceivably deal with let alone trust President Saddam Hussein whose policies of deception torture and murder  have had their impact on almost every household in Iraqi Kurdistan 

The answer is simple

The Kurds had no real alternative

They were they are desperately aware that the very survival of an entity identifiable as Iraqi Kurdistan  is at stake in the present crisis

The Kurds make up a fifth of the Iraqi population  just under four million people but now the bulk of them have abandoned their homeland

The fear and panic which gripped people in the wake of last month 's failed uprising has yet to be dissipated 

On the border rumours of continuing Iraqi army atrocities abound and still the collective memory of Haladja and the terrible consequences of Saddam 's willingness to use chemical weapons override the general longing to return home 

But return home they must for there 's no life for them in exile neither in Turkey nor Iran

United Nations officials working in the mountains which straddle the Iran Iraq border estimate that two thousand refugees are still dying each day while waiting to be allowed into camps on the Iranian side of the border

Such figures are easy to use but difficult to understand 

Perhaps it 's more useful to say that still a month after the extent of the Kurdish exodus became clear to the world scores of babies and young children are fading away every night dying simply because supplies of basic drugs of tents and blankets have yet to reach the people who need them most 

True the international relief effort in Iran is now swinging into action after a desperately slow start

Even the Americans have expressed a belated willingness to fly supplies directly to Iran  but the Kurds know that humanitarian assistance alone will not ease their long-term plight

Those who stay in the hastily established camps in Turkey and Iran will join a long list of other displaced peoples  forced by tyranny or war to live in temporary and often squalid confinement

Today 's Kurdish refugees don't have to look to the Palestinians to appreciate the limitations of such a future

They merely have to talk to their brothers and sisters who fled from Saddam 's persecution of the Kurds in nineteen eighty-eight and who 've been stuck in closely guarded Iranian and Turkish camps ever since 

So it was the need to get their people back to avoid the creation of a permanent Kurdish diaspora that forced not just Jalal Talabani but the other main resistance leaders as well to contemplate a deal with Saddam Hussein

The Pashmurga guerillas have accepted that the removal of Saddam by force is beyond their capabilities 

And it 's clear to them now in a way in which it wasn't clear six weeks ago that the Western allies will not support their military campaign

And so to the agreement signed last Wednesday night

The details have yet to be released but the basis of the deal seems to be the nineteen seventy agreement between the Iraqi government and the Kurds which promised self-government for Iraqi Kurdistan and guaranteed wide-ranging economic and cultural freedom 

This time the Kurds are even talking about a much more powerful say in the affairs of central government and the army 

But is any of this credible

Given Saddam Hussein 's track record the answer has to be no

For the allies who fought the war for the liberation of Kuwait and for the United Nations itself  one simple question has to be faced

Could force ever be sanctioned as a means of protecting the Kurds and indeed the Shiites of Iraq from the excesses of President Saddam Hussein

At the moment there appears to be no coherent answer from any of the parties involved 

President Bush said time and again that American troops would never intervene in the internal affairs of Iraq

But there they are on the streets of Zakho alongside British French and Dutch troops telling the Iraqis to get out of town or face the consequences 

Indeed the Kurds appear to be pinning their faith on a long-term international commitment to their security

But in a sense they have no choice

How else could they return to their homes with Saddam still in Baghdad

One can only hope that their faith is well founded 

If not then the agreement between the Kurds and Saddam will have been nothing more than a hollow charade  a prelude to yet more suffering for the Kurds of Iraq

When President Gorbachev returned from Japan a week ago he appeared to be in big trouble

His Tokyo summit looked like a waste of time and money

He 'd abandoned his collapsing country for a whole week to fly a huge retinue of government ministers advisers and experts half way round the world and come back with nothing  no promises of Japanese aid for the Soviet economy  no breakthrough in bilateral relations 

For the Soviet public watching his journeying on television it was an insult

While he his wife and his dozens of officials enjoyed lavish guesthouses and expensive Tokyo hotels attended banquets and planted trees  back home ordinary people were trying to come to terms with price rises that had just turned their lives upside down 

And who was financing this Tokyo trip

How could it be necessary to spend all this foreign currency when President Gorbachev himself admitted the Soviet Union didn't have enough money to pay its foreign debt let alone Tokyo hotel bills 

No wonder when the Soviet leader returned to Moscow he was deluged with calls for his resignation

His critics were attacking him on all sides 

There were the miners on strike for nearly two months now in a protest that was partly in reaction to the new price rises but mostly a renewal of the miners ' strike that shook the Soviet Union the summer before last a public demonstration of no confidence in President Gorbachev and his government who said the miners were not taking their demands for better conditions and more control over their own affairs seriously 

There were other strikes breaking out

on the railways the Leningrad metro shiftworkers in factories in steel mills and most tellingly of all in the once docile republic of Byelorussia

Signs of people reaching the limit of their patience 

Now not only were the queues for basic food just as long

but when you finally reached the front of the line the prices were two three six times higher 

But the immediate problem for President Gorbachev wasn't just strikes 

His opponents on the right the hardliners that is were also marshalling their forces

First there was the Sojuz group in the Soviet Parliament clearly influential

They 'd warned the President on the eve of his Tokyo visit not to negotiate any territory away to the Japanese and indeed he had not

But they also wanted a tougher line on domestic policy

And before President Gorbachev had barely set foot back on Soviet soil the Sojuz group had passed a vote of no confidence in him a decision to gather a petition to call an emergency session of the Congress of People 's Deputies the only body that has the power to oust him as President 

To collect signatures for that petition will take time

And summoning a congress is only the first step to impeachment 

But it 's a threat that still looms over him 

But the other challenge to President Gorbachev from the hard right was more immediate this last week 's plenum of the Soviet Communist Party 

Their complaints echoed those of the Sojuz group

He was letting the country go to rack and ruin

He was refusing to take necessary tough action to restore order

Plus more specific communist complaints

He had ignored the views of his own political party

He was abandoning socialism

He head of the party that should be leading the proletariat was neglecting the interests of the working class 

Well  as we now know President Gorbachev survived that Party plenum

In effect he called his colleagues ' bluff

It was a Communist chief from Kemerovo in Siberia apparently who provoked him angrily blasting him for incompetence and weakness

At which Mr Gorbachev sprang up brushed aside his advisers ' protestations stalked to the microphone to announce that if the party didn't need him he didn't need the party 

And then of course they all appealed for him to stay 

And so he did 

Well that 's how his supporters and advisers related that 's how he described it to the Soviet Parliament the following afternoon

It makes a good dramatic tale with a clear moral to it

Where would the Communist Party be without Mikhail Gorbachev

Where would the Soviet Union be 

So Mr Gorbachev ended his week still Soviet President and still leader of the Communist Party 

But has he really strengthened his position 

By staying on as head of a divided and angry party he may have lost out in two ways 

His communist opponents are still there and they 'll continue to work against him behind his back 

And he 's passed up an opportunity to rid himself of an unpopular label

While he 's got the Communist Party round his neck he 's not going to win back the confidence of ordinary people 

There Boris Yeltsin is one step ahead of him 

But there 's been another development this past week that could be much more significant 

That was the long meeting stretching late into Tuesday night that took place in a government villa outside Moscow 

It wasn't a round table President Gorbachev said later

it was a square table

But seated at it alongside him and politicians from eight other republics there was also the Russian leader soon possibly to be Russian President  Boris Yeltsin

What 's more the meeting produced a joint declaration which looks like the start of a compromise between President Gorbachev and his most powerful critic 

Not that the declaration necessarily means anything will change in practice

So much in this frustrating country never gets beyond words on a page 

But what it could mean is that President Gorbachev is beginning to acknowledge his own weakness  and recognise that though he no longer has the nation 's confidence  there are other politicians who do

It was a walkover

The European Community 's attempts to take on the United States during last December 's world trade talks here ended in embarrassing failure 

E C civil servants were simply no match for highly experienced political operators from Washington

They won the day

And the Community was left in the dock of international opinion as the guilty party behind the breakdown of the vitally important GATT negotiations 

The one Community official who did try to compete with the Washington machine before the world 's media  the first and possibly last Commission press spokesman to engage in the politics of the twenty second soundbite  has since been removed from his job

Put your head above the parapet in the European Commission and you 're out of work 

It 's on such occasions that the wide disparity between the United States and Europe the would-be superpower becomes starkly apparent 

The other day the American Secretary of State Mr James Baker and his entourage breezed into Luxembourg for talks with the Community

He was the master of events 

At encounters like this the sheer power which the United States can exert is glaring

By comparison Jacques Delors cuts a diminutive figure 

Beneath this perhaps superficial reflection upon the comparative strength of the two  there lies a very real question about future relations between the U S and E C

Before the Gulf War Washington was proclaiming its clear desire to upgrade its ties with the Community 

Washington signalled to the British Government that although the special relationship was still alive  the United States believed it should find its expression increasingly via the Community 

That changed of course with Britain 's resounding support for America in the liberation of Kuwait

Britain fought while most of the others fiddled 

But the war is over now and the United States will be taking a new look at matters in the cold light of day

The indications are that Europe will once again become the priority because slowly and awkwardly  a treaty is taking shape which will most likely emerge by the end of this year as a new European union

It won't fulfil the dreams of the wilder European federalists 

On the other hand it will disappoint those who 'd hoped that further integration had disappeared in the folds of the Arabian sands 

Out of it all the European Community will acquire a greater deal of policy coordination much of it on the basis of qualified majority voting

More areas of policy making may come under its competence

And the groundwork will be laid  should the E C decide eventually to assume a defence role

In sum the Community will more and more become a bloc which major partners especially the United States will come to deal with as a single entity  even though Anglo-American ties will remain a strong pillar of this new relationship 

The fact that Mr Major chose to launch his safe haven plan at a European summit before informing the Americans  indeed sought E C support before he went in to bat in Washington and at the United Nations reveals that he too understands that Britain in the years ahead cannot live off the glory of Desert Storm 

Late last year a new transatlantic declaration was signed cementing ties and there are now firmly established and regular diplomatic contacts between the Community and Washington

Indeed at the most recent encounter  following immediately after the E C summit  Mr Delors and the Luxembourg Prime Minister currently holding the Community presidency were able to reinforce Mr Major 's safe haven appeal 

That said there is a question mark over how far the U S wants to see its relationship with Europe become one of true equals 

Certainly Mr Baker is keeping the Community well briefed on his Middle East peace efforts

Any help the Europeans can offer in bringing the Arabs to the negotiating table  he will welcome

But that 's a far cry from Washington allowing the E C to join in as co-sponsors of a peace conference as it has demanded 

In Washington there 's great caution too over the prospect of the Europeans through the Western European union or an E C defence capability  pre-cooking decisions affecting American interests within the transatlantic alliance

And just see what happens if the GATT dispute is not resolved

The administration pressured by Congress and numerous lobby groups will have no qualms about taking its revenge in a bitter trade war 

When it comes to real power politics Washington knows how to play hard-ball  whatever its proclamations about a new atlanticism

My lords and members of the House of Commons 

I look forward to visiting Australia in February  the European Parliament and the Council of Europe in Strasbourg  and Malta next May  France in June and Germany in October 

My government attach the highest importance to maintaining our security 

For nearly half a century  NATO has formed the cornerstone of our defences 

It will continue to be the principal focus of the dissolution of the Warsaw Pact and the other welcome developments in the Soviet Union and Eastern Europe  permit changes to NATO strategy and will enable us to maintain our security with smaller forces 

Nevertheless instability and other risks remain in Europe and elsewhere  and substantial and effective nuclear and conventional forces will be maintained 

The United Kingdom will work for balanced and verifiable arms control agreements  including early ratification of the Conventional Armed Forces in Europe Treaty 

Efforts will continue to control the proliferation of weapons of mass destruction  and to encourage greater international responsibility and the transfer of conventional weapons 

The completion of multilateral negot negotiations on the ab abolition of chemical weapons will be pursued 

My government will require full unconditional compliance by Iraq with the United Nations Security Council resolutions  including the disposal of its missiles and weapons of mass destruction 

They will press for long-term peace in the Middle East  including a settlement of the Palestinian problem 

They will continue their efforts to secure the release of hostages in the Middle East 

They will continue to work for a stronger more effective United Nations 

My government will with our Community partners pursue the successful conclusion of the Uruguay round of multilateral trade negotiations 

Within the Community they will continue to play a constructive role in the two intergovernmental conferences on political union and economic and monetary union  and will work to complete the single European market to promote budgetary discipline and to reform the common agricultural policy 

They will prepare for the United Kingdom 's presidency of the Community beginning on the first of July nineteen ninety-two 

The United Kingdom will continue to develop our good relations with the Soviet Union and its republics  and to encourage their integration into the world economy  and will work to help Estonia Latvia and Lithuania re-establish themselves in the international community 

My government will further encourage the development of democratic institutions and market economies in Central and Eastern Europe  and pursue the completion of association agreements with Hungary Poland and Czechoslovakia 

They hope for a peaceful settlement in Yugoslavia 

They will contribute constructively to the Helsinki Conference on Security and Cooperation in Europe 

My government will encourage all sides in South Africa to pursue peaceful means of constructing a democratic non-racial society 

A substantial aid programme aimed at promoting sustainable economic and social progress and good government in developing countries will be maintained 

My government will continue to support the Commonwealth 

My government will continue to administer Hong Kong in the interest of its people and to cooperate with China in implementing the Sino-British joint declaration 

My government will continue their fight against terrorism in the United Kingdom and elsewhere 

They will vigorously pursue their policies to combat drug trafficking and misuse of drugs nationally and internationally 

The United Kingdom will work for a successful United Nations Conference on Environment and Development next June

Members of the House of Commons  estimates for the public service will be laid before you 

My lords and members of the House of Commons  my govmt would government will pursue within the framework of the Exchange Rate Mechanism firm financial policies designed to reduce inflation further and maintain the conditions necessary for sustained growth 

They will promote enterprise and training and improve the working of the economy 

They will continue to prepare for the privatisation of the British Railways Board and the British Coal Corporation 

They will maintain firm control of public spending with the aim of keeping its share of national income on a downward trend over time 

My government attach the highest priority to improving public services 

They will implement the programme of reform in the White Paper on the Citizens ' Charter including bringing forward charters for individual public services 

Legislation will be introduced to reinforce the regulation of privatised utilities 

Legislation will be introduced to provide for a new council tax  to establish the review of local government structure in England  and to enhance competitive tendering for local authority services 

Action will be taken to improve quality and choice in education 

Legislation will be introduced to reform the funding of further education and sixth form colleges and to reform higher education in England and Wales  and to make information available about the performance of individual schools 

My government will continue to develop policies to enhance the nation 's health and to improve the effectiveness of the health and social services and the social security system 

Work for the regeneration of our cities will continue 

A bill will be introduced to enable applications for asylum in the United Kingdom to be dealt with quickly and effectively 

A bill will be presented to create an offence of prison mutiny  and to increase the maximum penalty for aiding prisoners to escape 

Legislation will be introduced to revise health and safety arrangements for offshore installations 

A bill will be introduced to replace private legislation as the means for authorising transport development schemes 

A bill will be introduced to provide for a Cardiff Bay barrage 

For Scotland legislation will be introduced to reform further and higher education 

In Northern Ireland my government will resolutely seek to defeat terrorism through the even-handed and energetic enforcement of the law  to promote political progress to strengthen the economy  and to create equa equality of opportunity and equity of treatment for all sections of the community 

They will maintain positive relations with the Republic of Ireland 

Legislation will be introduced to improve the supervision of charities 

Other measures will be laid before you 

My lords and members of the House of Commons I pray that the blessing of Almighty God may rest upon your counsels

Mr Deputy Speaker I intended to carry forward my predecessor 's work 

My central economic aim is to bring inflation down and to keep it down 

Beyond that my objective is to encourage enterprise by creating a broadly based tax system that allows markets to do their job with the minimum of distortion and government interference 

While there is no scope this year for an overall reduction in taxes  my budget today will include measures to help business through the recession in the short term and to encourage them to invest for the longer term 

It will provide assistance for families

It will also further the process of tax reform and it will make some radical changes in the tax system 

However as usual I shall begin with a review of the economic situation and prospects

I shall then deal with monetary policy and public finances

Finally I will present my tax proposals 

The financial statement and budget report together with a number of press releases filling out the details of my proposals will be available from the Vote Office as soon as I have sat down 

I turn first to international developments

The past year has brought recession to a number of major industrial countries including the United States Canada and Australia 

Growth in Germany has been sustained by reunification  but elsewhere in Europe activity has slowed and industrial production has fallen in recent months in Spain Italy and France 

In five out of the seven leading industrial  nations industrial output is now lower than it was a year ago 

The basic cause is the same everywhere

Very rapid growth Very rapid growth in the industrialized world during the nineteen eighties led to the re-emergence of inflationary pressures 

A period of slower growth was needed to stop inflation taking hold again 

In the autumn the slowdown was magnified by the Gulf crisis

Business and consumer confidence was badly dented first by the uncertainties  and the sharp rise in oil prices that followed the invasion of Kuwait and then by the prospect of war

Travel and tourism were especially hard hit 

Mercifully  the war was brief and the outcome successful

Confidence is recovering

And that will strengthen the economic upturn when the time comes 

And the fall in oil prices has already improved the outlook for inflation 

So while nineteen ninety-one as a whole will show little growth in the seven major economies a half per cent increase in industrial production compared to five and three quarters per cent in nineteen eighty-eight the slowdown is unlikely to last long 

Inflation is already moderating in those countries which are in recession  and activity should start to recover later this year in North America helped by continued expansion in Germany and Japan 

In the U K the recession came after eight years of growth averaging three per cent a year 

This sustained growth bred confidence and that in turn led to a quite unprecedented rise in borrowing 

Personal borrowing increased by nearly forty per cent in nineteen eighty-eight alone to reach fifty-four billion pounds and a new record for the ratio of debt to income 

This produced a sharp drop in the personal savings ratio which coincided with a massive boom in investment by companies 

In itself the rise of investment nearly eighty per cent between nineteen eighty-one and eighty-nine was welcome but the economy could not go on expanding at that rate

Some firms and individuals became over-extended and we saw a deterioration in the current account and a wholly unwelcome rise in inflation

It is easy with the benefit of hindsight to s to say that policy should have been tighter and once the problem became clear policy was tightened

We ran a large budget surplus

Interest rates were raised  and they had to stay high until there were unmistakeable signs that excess demon pra excess demand pressure had been removed 

This took longer than we or outside commentators expected

And the delay meant that the adjustment when it came was all the sharper 

Since the middle of last year individuals and companies have been taking steps to reduce their borrowing consumer spending has fallen back and the savings ratio has risen sharply to ten point eight per cent 

Firms have found it hard going

Profits have weakened caught in the pincer of low turnover and rising costs and the burden of debt taken on in the late nineteen eighties has proved a heavy one 

So Mr Deputy Speaker it is not surprising that business investment has fallen from the heights of nineteen eighty-nine and early nineteen ninety

Stocks are now being reduced and companies are making strenuous efforts to cut costs

This has led to a sharp increase in unemployment in recent months though there are welcome signs that firms are continuing to invest in skills and training

I expect output in nineteen ninety-one as a whole to be about two per cent less than in nineteen ninety 

Much of that fall of course has already happened

It is largely behind us and I sh as I shall be explaining in a moment the resumption of growth should not be long delayed

The process of retrenchment has been painful as it always is but it has been necessary and is now producing results 

The current account deficit has improved sharply especially the balance on manufactures even though world trade has been weak

Imports have fallen while exports in some sectors  notably cars have continued to grow strongly

testimony to the fact that industry is immeasurably better placed today than it was ten years ago 

And no one can doubt that inflation is on the way down 

We have already seen a fall of two percentage points since the peak last October and there is widespread agreement that the fall in inflation will continue through nineteen ninety-one and into nineteen ninety-two 

Indeed the prospects are now better than they seemed at the time of the autumn statement

The February survey by the C B I showed the balance of firms expecting to increase prices was at its lowest level ever 

The forecast published today taking account of the effect of the budget measures is for inflation to fall to an average of four per cent in the last quarter of this year and below four per cent in the first half of ninety-two

Perhaps my title is a little too defensive ladies and gentlemen

Perhaps too coy

You might even say disingenuous

After all you don't really expect me to stand here and tell you that in fact Yiddish isn't a real language but that nonetheless I presume to teach it at U C L

However my reasons for posing the question are not altogether flippant

And oddly enough it 's not only outsiders who ask it 

I dare say most of us feel that the nature of the work we do is insufficiently understood or appreciated by the public at large or even by our colleagues

No doubt that 's one of the reasons why these lunchtime lectures were instituted

You may think I am biased

But it seems to me that the subject that I teach Yiddish must be pretty high up on the list of subjects about which misinformation abounds and where the true facts are widely ignored 

So what is Yiddish

Is it just another name for Hebrew

The more knowledgeable of you uh m more uh knowledgeable among you may well laugh

But not long ago The Linguist of all things the official journal of the British Institute of Linguists carried an article solemnly informing its readers that Yiddish is a Semitic language 

It is of course nothing of the sort 

Hebrew is a Semitic language as are Aramaic Arabic and several Ethiopic languages

Somebody should explain to the author of the offending article that religion is not relevant to the philological classification of languages 

Yiddish on the other hand is a Germanic language that came into existence around the year one thousand when Jews migrating into southern Germany from Italy ah South-Eastern and Central Europe began speaking a subtle blend of their Christian neighbours ' Old High German just as it was beginning to mutate itself into Middle High German 

This was uhm uh much modified of course by the sub and ad strata composed of the complex linguistic heritage that they brought with them

From the beginning uh the language has been enriched by a large input of Hebrew and Aramaic as well as the various other Jewish languages such as Judeo-Italian Judeo-Old Czech Judeo-Greek that they brought with them

In the course of time the Slav component assumed a greater and greater importance without of course Yiddish in any way ceasing to be a Germanic language in the same way that it would never occur to us to describe English as a romance language just because a high proportion of its vocabulary is of Latin or French origin

Originally in a relatively stair uh Originating in a relatively restricted area in the Danube valley Yiddish gradually spread to a huge area extending from Amsterdam to Odessa from Venice to Vilnius

As the everyday language of millions of Jews for just over a m millennium it is naturally the vehicle for a rich popular culture

In addition to this there developed a sophisticated secular literary tradition which has had its two high points in the fifteenth and sixteenth centuries in Germany and Italy then in the nineteenth and twentieth centuries in Eastern Europe 

By the eve of the Second World War there were approximately twelve million speakers of Yiddish in its traditional Eastern European heartland

That is to put things in perspective more than the combined numbers of speakers of Swedish and Danish at the same period uhm or approximately three times the number of speakers uh that Modern Hebrew has today

This means of course that in demographic terms uh Yiddish was  uh the third or possibly the fourth most widely spoken Germanic uh uh language uhm after English and German and with approximately at that period I reckon uhm much the same number of speakers as Dutch and in any case way ahead of any number of other Germanic languages whose future is scarcely in question today 

One of the many paradoxes of Yiddish cultural history is the way in which it has suffered on account of its virtues

It 's a commonplace in this country that the expressive powers of the English language have gained immensely from the diversity of the raw linguistic material that it has absorbed in the course of its history

All the varied vocabulary of Celtic Anglo-Saxon Scandinavian French Latin and more exotic origin offers us an enviable choice of registers and nuance

Exactly the same is true of Yiddish a sister Germanic language which has been able to profit immeasurably from the linguistic and cultural riches that it has inherited from the Jewish languages that preceded it and uh with which it forms part of a continuous tradition as well as from the uhm uh uhm uh lexical and uh uh phrasi uh phraseological uh enrichment ab absorbed from the Slav languages subsequently 

One crucial difference it seems to me and this is where the parallel between Yiddish and English breaks down is that whereas English speakers have been overwhelmingly monolingual since the disappearance of Anglo-Norman at least Yiddish speakers like Jews everywhere since the Babylonian e exile have been predominantly bilingual if not polylingual

Since educated uh usually male Jews had a good knowledge of Hebrew and Aramaic and the levels of literacy among European Jews were astonishingly high when compared with their gentile neighbours until recent times and since a high proportion of the working often female population had a fair knowledge of the co-territorial usually Slav language it followed that there existed a very high degree of etymological awareness among or ordinary Yiddish speakers that would be unthinkable in an English context

This meant among other things that speakers were ca capable of a special kind of code switching which involved deliberately choosing to avoid uhm words of Germanic origin which normally formed the greater part of the vocabulary

Thus  you would normally translate the uh uhm uh the sentence uh the gentleman understands every word you 're saying as der Wersteht yede wordt uhm

And of course anyone who knows German immediately understands

And that 's the problem

So instead if you were afraid of having your conversation overheard by a non-Jew you would say  where only the article and the verb are not Semitic

The reverse case also existed

That is circumstances in which words derived from the holy tongue or loshen kodesh were to be avoided as for example when purifying oneself from a Mikva that is the ritual bath

This high degree of component awareness as we could call it left ordinary Jews potentially vulnerable to the suggestion that they didn't speak a proper language but a barbaric agrammatical mixture of several

This reaction was triggered a m uh uh as much as for any reason as any other reason as the result of the German Aufklarung or enlightenment movement

What happened basically was that as enlightened Germans began reflecting towards the end of the eighteenth century that there was no good reason for denying uh equal civil rights to the Jews who lived among them

educated Jews such as Moses Mendelssohn the famous friend of Lessing started to put forward the idea that if Je Jews were to deserve to be treated equally that they should come to think of themselves as Deutsche Statsburger wear the same clothes as their neighbours and speak standard German on the streets and at home while cultivating Hebrew in the Synagogue

In other words Yiddish like distinctive clothing was regarded as a cause of anti-semitism and a barrier to full participation in western ci uh civilisation

The result of such thinking was that in the German speaking lands in the West where a form of Yiddish lacking the Slav component continued to be spo spoken well into the eighteenth century and in some cases beyond the language almost totally disappeared largely as a result of this advocacy of standard German for all secular purposes by the Haskalah or Yiddish enlightenment movement 

By the middle of the nineteenth century Yiddish had almost completely disappeared from Germany where the Aufklarung and the endeavour to demonstrate fitness for equal citizenship had given rise to a systematic adoption of the ideals of Bildung and of the German middle class way of life

Not only was Yiddish shunned but all traces of Jewish accent or gesture the despised  were studiously eschewed

German Jews even made efforts to dissociate themselves from the Ost Juden of Galicia Prussian Poland and the Russian Empire

The assimilated western Jew uhm uh felt threatened by the outlandish demeanour of his eastern coreligionists who were increasingly to be seen on the streets of German cities after the Russian pogroms of the eighteen eighties

Yiddish came to be associated with the ghetto the caftan and uh talmudic sophistry

Even with absence of hygiene and with moral depravity uhm uhm se seen as characteristics of a medieval barbarism from which the German of the Mosaic faith had himself so recently escaped and of which he preferred not to be too insistently reminded 

In the East however the Haskalah unwittingly gave Yiddish culture a critically significant stimulus

The ideas of the Enlightenment it was believed could be propagated among the Jewish masses of central Europe only by means of a didactic literature which had no choice but to employ Yiddish 

However what was originally intended as a propaedeutic uh uh tool be uh had before long developed into the vehicle of an increasingly autonomous literary culture

The moralistic writings of Maskilim like Yitsak Meyer Dick and Eliakum Zunser paved the way for the astonishing efflorescence of Mendele Mocher Seforim and Sholem Aleichem

Despite of all this rich and diverse Yiddish cultural activity the Maskilic contempt for Yiddish continued to spread a kind of inferiority complex among Yiddish speakers and authors who wrote in both Hebrew and Yiddish uhm and who often signed their uh Yiddish pieces with pseudonyms lest the fact that they had stooped to write in the colloquial language damaged their reputations as as serious Hebrew authors

It was It 's partly for this reason that many Yiddish uh authors of this period including Mendele Mocher Seforim and Sholem Aleichem are still known by their pseudonyms 

Even Sholem Aleichem incidentally as he tells us in his autobiographical  when faced by the quandary of choosing whether pu purs to pursue his literary career through the medium of Russian Hebrew or Yiddish had to face the prospect that many of his potential readers would ask themselves the same question which we are considering here today



Is Yiddish a real language

True everybody spoke it but was it really fit to become a means of sophisticated literary expression 

Sholem Aleichem opted of course as we all know in favour of Yiddish and was far from being alone in challenging the prevailing negative attitudes

Noson Birmboim otherwise known as Nathan Birnbaum for example uh had been one of the earliest Zionists

But he became disenchanted with the movement 's exclusive preoccupation with Palestine and broke with Herzl

He turned instead to the concept of Diaspora Nationalism or cultural autonomism

Having rejected assimilationism in the past he now repu repudiated the plans of the Zionists to create a new hypothetical Jewish nation in the future

The real nation he contended already existed in Eastern Europe possessed of an authentically Jewish culture passed down through the medium of the Yiddish language

The task of the deracinated western Jew was to participate in a kind of reverse assimilation and to reintegrate himself into his vital tradition

It was uh uhm Noson Birnboim who convened the famous Chernowitz conference in August nineteen O eight which brought together a cross-section of Jewish writers and intellectuals who all from their various perspectives were concerned with Yiddish

Though Mendele Mocher Seforim and Sholem Aleichem were unable to attend the novelist Sholem Ash the dramatist Yaakov Gordon the poet Moshe Leib Halpern the philologists Martis Mizus and Noach Chalutsky took part in the proceedings

Chalutsky fought unsuccessfully for a resolution declaring Yiddish the national Jewish language

a compromise amendment to the effect that it was a national language was carried

Bitter wrangling between the Hebraists and left wing Bundists marred the conference however and it was unsuccessful in its primary aim of establishing a permanent organisation to promote the language

But it did much to raise the status of Yiddish in the eyes of a wide public 

Although the way had been paved by the Chernowitz conference a specific institution devoted to the standardization of the language and to the pursuit of relevant educational and cultural aims did not come into existence until nineteen twenty five when the Yiddish Scientific uh Institute Yivo  Yidisher Visenshaftlikher Institut was founded in Berlin and located in Vilna Vilnius

Writers still passingly refer to Anglo-Portuguese trade as vigorous regular modest increasing decreasing  but on what scale 

Is vigorous trade in the Anglo-Portuguese context two five or ten ships a year 

I became interested in Portuguese trade years ago as I wrote on Spanish trade

Well it seemed to me that despite the very good political relations that there are between England and Portugal  trade was modest  and I 'll come to some numbers later on

While the Basque and Spanish trades seemed to flourish very much better in rather less welcoming political circumstances 

And it seemed to me that with approach the approach of nineteen ninety-two with its promised closer commercial links in Europe  now including Portugal that it seems a good time to review England 's medieval links with what is commonly called her oldest trading partner

What I intend to do today is to look at the scale and the patterns of the Anglo-Portuguese trade in the fifteenth century especially at the Portuguese activity in English ports and to try to set this briefly against the background of the other areas in which the Portuguese deal

So what I 'm doing today is essentially uh at once limited it 's just looking at the activity in English ports but also very broad because it 's trying to set it in uh the setting of the whole century and  to some extent in the whole of Atlantic trade

How well I succeed in this you will of course judge at the end 

Superficially it seems reasonable to expect a regular and well-integrated trade between the two countries

Access  political relations and commodities would all point in that direction 

Access by sea is straightforward given the recognised hazards of the time such as storm wreck and piracy 

And geographically uh Portugal northern Spain Gascony England and Ireland are clearly all close and the Atlantic seas between them are familiar 

The opening of the regular sea routes between the Mediterranean and the Channel at the end of the thirteenth century tied Portugal Spain and England ever more tightly into the trade network with Europe

The English control of Gascony and the regular carrying of pilgrims between England and Corunna for Santiago reinforced English familiarisation with the Bay of Biscay

The fifteenth century instructions for the circumnavigation of England  a map taken from which I 've placed on the overhead projector just to remind you where Portugal is  uh the instructions for the circumnavigation of England describe the most frequent routes of navigation

Uh there is no such map like that in the directions themselves

They 're simply written directions in which the compass uh directions between Ushant and Cape Ortegal or between uh  Cape Clear and Finisterre are given

But what I have simply done is to trace on to a map the directions that are given which give you some indication of the  familiar routes the regular routes which the seamen would expect to sail and which I think underlines the number of direct routes across the Bay of Biscay that uh that were possible 

uh directions are given from Ushant uh from the Scillies uh from the south coast of Ireland down to Cape Ortegal or Finisterre

And then the directions take ships on to San Lucar uh using the  Rock uh Mount Cintra down by uh Lisbon and Cape St Vincent as navigation points

These are the routes which are familiar to the English and Portuguese ships and others on the routes

We don't have full descriptions of the journeys left by any merchants that I know of uh although casual references and charter parties refer to direct crossings and to the routes they used 

There are one or two descriptions of  journeys which underline  both the fact that they used the direct routes and the difficulties of it notably weather and the uh unintended landfalls that you can make if you set off from Finisterre uh to the south-west of England

Scores of ships are going to be plying these routes each year

The Portugal The Portuguese ones come overwhelmingly from uh Lisbon and Oporto

Of all the named ships that I can find about eighty-six per cent come from those two ports uh if figures mean anything at all

The English ships are predominantly those from Bristol London and the West Country with Dartmouth particularly prominent in those

But some ships come occasionally from as far afield as Hull 

Lisbon was the main English market and about eighty-five per cent of the Bristol shipping movements were to and from Lisbon

And at the end of the fifteenth century free access was allowed once more to the Algarve about ten per cent uh  ships to and forth from there 

Return journeys would take about three or four months which would include turnround times uh in port

And although the summer outward sailings tended to predominate from England and inward sailings sometimes bunched in December as fruits and sweet wines were brought in for the Christmas market and the winter festivities sailing did take place in just about all months 

Political relations were also very good as probably most people know

Uh they 've been good since the twelfth century really when the English crusaders helped the reconquest and they 'd been tightened most recently in the negotiations which led to the Treaty of Windsor in thirteen eighty-six and the marriage of Lancaster 's English daughter Philippa to the usurping John the First of Portugal

Philippa and her household kept very close contacts with England for thirty years until her death in fourteen fifteen

Her three eldest sons Duarte who had become king in fourteen thirty-three Pedro Duke of Coimbra and Enrice better known to us as The Navigator all became Knights of the Garter as did Duarte 's successor his son and his grandson kings of Portugal

Philippa 's daughter Isabelle married Philip the Good of Burgundy in fourteen twenty-nine and became involved from fort in thirt in fourteen fifty in Anglo-Burgundian diplomatic negotiations very often dealing with her half uncle Cardinal Beaufort

Of all Philippa 's children it was the infant Pedro de Co Coimbra who was later regent for his young nephew Alfonso the Fifth who was most familiar with England

He came at least three times

Uh in fourteen twenty-five as part of a European tour uh when he served as a very successful mediator in the quarrel between his cousin the Duke of Lan the Duke of Gloucester and his half-uncle Henry Beaufort Bishop of Winchester  riding according to Gregory 's chronicle no fewer than eight times between the two before he could get them to agree

In fourteen twenty-eight he was back for his installation as Knight of the Garter and in fourteen twenty-nine he attended the coronation of Henry the Sixth

At that time he might also by chance have met his sister Isabella who was blown into Plymouth on her way to her marriage in Burgundy and stayed for about a month visiting the English Court en route 

After Pedro 's death and disgrace in a rebellion against Alfonso the Fifth in fourteen forty-nine it was Isabella who tried to find careers and sanctuary for his two young sons uh in England 

These royal links were deepened with aristocratic ones

uh Philippa encouraged the marriage of John 's illegitimate daughter Beatrice to the the Earl of Anthorp

And John and his son Alvaro  made quite  spectacular I suppose careers uh in England with Alvaro  being created Count of Avranches by Henry the Sixth in fourteen forty-five

The impact of royal and aristocratic links on trade can be seen in the activity of John Church of London as factor to the king of Portugal and in the royal and aristocratic ships which are used in the trade between the two countries 

The Treaty of Windsor was confirmed throughout the century at every change of monarch but links of course grew more slender as generations passed

The old links between the houses of Lancaster and  did not stop the king of Portugal recognising the Yorkist Edward the Fourth as king of England in fourteen sixty-one

nor did it stop Henry the Sixth 's supporters from a major act of piracy against Portuguese shipping in fourteen seventy 

There had been suggestions of further Anglo-Portuguese marriages for Henry the Sixth Edward the Fourth and Richard the Third but none of these came off the starting blocks at all

By this time Castile was looking by far the most valuable ally again 

Even at the beginning of the century uh political links had had tensions

The unpaid debts of John the First 's ambassadors from the thirteen eighties were still rankling among some of the English creditors who had ships arrested in fourteen hundred and three fourteen hundred and four and fourteen hundred and ten still trying to get their money paid 

And of course individual attitudes were always very unpredictable

Piracy and robbery and fraud could occur between individuals at any time whatever treaties said

Uh  one Portuguese John de Port found himself imprisoned in Honiton threatened with death in fourteen thirty-four as he tried to get from Devon to London to sue against those who 'd robbed him in Devon

They were desperate to stop him getting there in the first place

And in the fourteen forties uh Henry May of Bristol had a ship which rescued the Portuguese ship from pirates

Uh when he 'd rescued the ship the English master of Henry May 's was heard to say that if he 'd known the pirates were English he wouldn't have bothered to save the Portuguese and since they hadn't paid him a penny for his trouble he was disposed to wash his hands of them anyway

And if redress for all crimes was slow then the crimes that were committed uh on both sides

and there are occasions when the King of Portugal uh removes protection from English merchants so that reprisal can be made against them for accrued up crimes which have not been amended 

Further of course no treaty can work in isolation and Anglo-Portuguese relations were constantly affected by Anglo-French and Anglo-Castilian relations

On the one hand Portuguese merchants would benefit when war was open and Castile as a French ally became an enemy alien because then they would become uh the main source for Iberian goods  and it probably helped to promote their surge in the fourteen twenties to the thir to the beginning of the fourteen thirties

On the other hand they suffered when the Anglo-Castilian treaty of fourteen sixty-six gave Spaniards an economic edge over them by allowing them customs  

There were also tensions in mid century when the Anglo-Burgundian conflict upset the Portuguese who were used to dealing in both areas

The recent marriage of Isabella to Burgundy in fourteen twenty-nine did encourage trade there and also encouraged the triangular trade to develop between Portugal England and the Low Countries

But conflict meant that it was dangerous to sail between the two and the Burgundian embargos on cloth meant that English cloth was less available uh in Flanders 

The surge of Portuguese activity in the fourteen thirties seems to be partly linked with what 's going on in Burgundy 

Nevertheless the two countries did remain familiar ground despite the tensions

and a Portuguese immigrant Edward Branton who made a very successful career under Edward the Fourth was not the only uh Portuguese to acquire denization papers in the fourteen seventies

There are a lot of callers at our front doors nowadays some of them more welcome than others but in April there 'll be one caller you shouldn't miss the man or woman from the census the great national counting of heads 

The census aims to make a tally of everyone in the country on a certain day Census Day and the next one is Sunday April the twenty-first 

Where we are in what numbers of what ages and sexes and much more besides is the foundation of a vast statistical picture of enormous importance to all our futures 

It 's the basis of the planning and management long-term as well as short of all the services and resources that we tend to take for granted in our daily lives

Someone somewhere has to plan for the future 

How many ambulances to provide  how many football pitches  how many telephones 

One of the key statistics must be just how many of us there are 

The long tradition of the census means that we can trace the exact change in population over two hundred years back to Britain 's first census in eighteen hundred and one 

The last census in nineteen eighty-one showed the smallest increase ever recorded between one census and the next a population growth of about half a per cent

That statistic alone will have a vital effect for generations to come 

All the individual census forms from which statistics are produced are kept here in strict confidence for one hundred years 

The latest census forms that any member of the public can ask to see were filled in when Queen Victoria was on the throne 

The fine detail of a bygone age 

What will the census of April the twenty-first tell our descendants about us when it 's first available for public scrutiny in the year two thousand and ninety-two 

The census is a nationwide operation designed to apply the same kind of information gathering to every part of the country simultaneously 

If each local area carried out the survey each would go about it in their own way and at different times

It 's the overall picture of each part of the country at one moment in time that makes these statistics so valuable 

We all know in our own lives what changes the last ten years have brought

but none of us knows the picture overall

and that 's what the census supplies 

Take owner-occupiers for example

In the country as a whole forty per cent in sixty-one fifty-six per cent twenty years later

What will the figure be in nineteen ninety-one 

The number of pensioners living alone has increased markedly since the end of the war

Important to know in planning services to meet their needs 

The message about cars is loud and clear 

Car use for getting to work up from thirty-five to fifty per cent in ten years 

Two-car households nearly doubled in the same period 

We know there are around fifty-six million of us

but where are we to be found and in what numbers 

The distribution of the population changes in response to all kinds of factors and the census charts these human tides 

An accurate count of people helps central and local government and a host of other bodies to work out where to allocate funds and what 's required in the future across the whole spectrum of our needs  where you place shopping malls supermarkets petrol stations schools health services libraries police services and much else besides 

To make sure everyone 's included in the census the country is divided into small areas containing about two hundred households

Each of these is the responsibility of one person

That 's the enumerator a key figure in this giant operation 

It 's on the diligence of the enumerator who delivers and collects the forms of each household that the accuracy of the census depends 

Enumerators come from all kinds of backgrounds and are carefully selected and trained for this part-time job 

They are given strict instructions about confidentiality 

What you can be sure of is that the confidentiality of the census is complete

The enumerators are even allocated to districts some distance from where they live 

Another early lesson for the one hundred and thirty thousand enumerators working countrywide is that we don't all live neatly in houses

But their challenge is to find us wherever we are on Census Night  regardless of our lifestyle 

For census purposes a household is a group of people either related or rooming together like these students living at the same address with communal housekeeping 

A boarder living in a private house who eats with the family forms part of the household 

If you rent a bed-sitting room and provide food for yourself but don't share a living room you count as a separate household 

If you live alone of course you are the one who completes the form 

About two weeks before census an explanatory leaflet is delivered to each household

Every enumerator will produce an authority card for your reassurance 

About a week before the twenty-first of April the enumerators will be round again calling in person to deliver the census form 

Names and addresses are important at this stage to ensure that everybody is included in the census but except for the postcode they will not be entered onto any computer record 

For people whose first language is not English there will be leaflets available in eleven languages to help them understand the form 

A Welsh version of the form itself will be available in Wales 

There is in fact a legal requirement to fill in the form

but since we all benefit so much from the information it provides it 's well worth our time to deal with every query to the best of our knowledge

After all we 're only called upon once every ten years 

The census form has been designed so that household questions appear on the front and back

Personal questions are inside 

Answering most of the questions just means putting a tick in a box 

The form has space for details of a group up to six people

More than that and you 'll need another form 

Among a group like these students one person can deal with the form for everyone

Or if you 're over sixteen you can have a separate form 

Perhaps there 's some information you don't want to share with others 

For the first time the nineteen ninety-one census will include a question about long-term illness to help plan services and facilities for long-term sick and elderly 

A question relating to ethnic groups has been introduced 

This will help identify where racial disadvantage exists so it can be tackled 

The enumerators will be back to collect completed forms as from Monday April the twenty-second at a time which is convenient to you 

In case you have any problems your enumerator has been trained to help 

The complete forms will be kept safe and will be used to produce statistics only about the population in general not any individuals

And it is actually against the law for the census offices to pass information about identified people or households on to anyone else government departments outside organisations or individuals 

The census is a tried and tested method of gathering information vital to the management of our country

It 's not only worthwhile

it 's essential for now and for future generations 

Make sure that you don't miss out on Sunday April the twenty-first 

Remember

if just two people weren't counted in each of the one hundred and thirty thousand areas covered by the census net that 's more than a quarter of a million people adrift a city the size of Nottingham wiped off the map 

The census

It counts because you count
