Mr Chairman thank you very much for those extremely kind remarks

I think possibly some undeserved

but uh thank you all the same 

Ladies and gentlemen it 's a great pleasure for me to be here this evening  and to be able to tell you something about the Ordnance Survey in this its two-hundredth year 

I am conscious that your society i is older than my department by some forty years

And I am also aware  that your society in the late eighteen hundreds was very active  in encouraging proper mapping of England and devised an award to achieve that through the mapping of English counties  at a scale of one inch to one mile and to a consistent quality 

What the Society did uh at that time undoubtedly had an effect on the Ordnance Survey thinking  in that the county was established as a unit of mapping  and one inch to one mile was established as a scale in general use 

Also in looking at Ordnance Survey records I am aware that I am not the first Director General to address this Society 

It was in eighteen ninety-one  that  after our first hundred years that uh Major General Sir Charles Wilson spoke here about the making of maps and their distribution 

You 're obviously a Society which takes an interest in mapping  but at one hundred year intervals you don't place 

I thank you for that 

Well ladies and gentlemen Ordnance Survey makes maps and has done so for two hundred years

It makes maps for other people to use in a very wide variety of activities 

For maps are about the land and the land is vitally important to all of us 

The land is mankind 's primary asset 

We are fed clothed and housed from it 

We use it to generate our wealth and for our recreation 

Maps are a record of the land and as such are a necessary aid to good decision-making about matters concerning the land its development and the orderly administration of our society 

I believe that good maps will help good decision-making which will protect and enhance our environment 

As you will gather I think maps are very important 

I also think that this importance is often overlooked in Britain today because Britain is well mapped  one of the best mapped countries in the world 

And so maps tend to be taken for granted by the vast majority of us 

Of course this is perhaps the greatest compliment that could be played paid to the Ordnance Survey namely that its works are good 

they meet the needs of the nation for maps

and therefore there 's no need to concern ourselves more with the matter 

This evening I would like to explain to you how this happy situation came about  how the Ordnance Survey was born  and how the mapping developed 

And I shall also say a little of its future 

This is our two hundredth anniversary 

One very serious aspect of mapping is its use in insuring the security of the state against both internal and external threats 

It is always a high priority for national mapping agencies 

And it was the security needs of the state  which brought Ordnance Survey into being  in seventeen ninety-one 

Ordnance Survey takes its name from the Board of Ordnance  which in the eighteenth century was an important element of the military being concerned with fortifications artillery engineering and all matters technical 

This is the coat of arms of the Board of Ordnance the three cannons surmounted by  the cannon balls 

In the troubled times of the latter half of the eighteenth century there was a need for consistent and homogeneous mapping of Britain 

Following from as some saw it an unsatisfactory act of settlement between England and Scotland  the Jacobite rebellion of seventeen forty-five left the Scottish Highlands in turmoil 

And war with France  its revolution and the rise of Napoleon threatened England from the south 

In these circumstances and to be able to defend the country against internal insurrection and external aggression  there was a military need for reliable maps of consistent quality covering the threatened areas 

The pioneer of Ordnance Survey was a young Scot named William Roy  who in seventeen forty-seven when aged twenty-one was working with the army in Scotland 

At this time the Board of Ordnance decided that a map of the Scottish Highlands was urgently needed to allow the country to be opened up to troops and civil administration 

The work was ex executed by soldiers of the Board of Ordnance 

and much of it by William Roy himself 

This is a contemporary sketch of a military survey party in the Highlands  the surveyor with his theodolite or circumferentor uh on its tripod with the party in front of him 

It 's a sketch of the Kinlochrannoch area 

William Roy held a commission in the Royal Engineers and was also a Fellow of the Royal Society 

In addition to practical surveying for mapping he was keenly interested in scientific matters 

Thus he undertook work to determine the shape of the earth  a matter of much discussion in his day 

And indeed there was doubt about the relative positions of the Royal Observatories of London and Paris 

and  to resolve this Roy measured a base line of at that time high accuracy on Hounslow Heath now the site of Heathrow Airport 

He carried out triangulation to link the two observatories 

For the work he used a theodolite with a three foot diameter circle 

This very fine instrument had been made by the leading instrument maker of the time a man called Jesse Ramsden and it had been commissioned at the expense of the King uh George the Third 

It was in its time the most accurate instrument available 

It uh its horizontal circle was divided into ten minutes of arc this  brass circle here  eh very fine subdivisions for that time 

It was read by microscopes  uhm 

And indeed it was used until eighteen fifty-three 

It was the first theodolite that was capable of detecting spherical excess when measurements were taken on the curved surface of the earth 

In fact the original theodolite uh this was the second of Ramsden 's theodolites and this is on view in the Science Museum at Kensington 

the original theodolite was unfortunately destroyed

I 'll mention that later on 

Tragically although Major General Roy with much support in high places laid the foundations for Ordnance Survey it was not to come into being until one year after his death in seventeen ninety 

With the London to Paris triangulation complete  and after much debate  it had been decided that the triangulation of Great Britain should be carried out as the basis for a topographic survey 

And so a further theodolite was purchased that was this one  for Ram from Ramsden on the order of the third Duke of Richmond 

He at that time was the Master General of the Board of Ordnance and had earlier supported William Roy 's proposals for national mapping 

This purchase is shown in the expenses ledger of the Board of Ordnance on the twenty-first of June seventeen ninety-one

And this is the record that is taken as the founding of the Ordnance Survey 

Portrait of the third Duke 

The Dukes of Richmond have their estates in fact in West Sussex Goodwood quite near to Southampton

And eh I am pleased to say that we have uh uh maintained a a connection with that family

The young Ordnance Survey quickly extended the trigonometrical work which already linked London and Paris until an accurate triangulation covered Great Britain 

This provided the framework for the mapping which was to follow 

The first priority of course was for mapping of the South coast of England and its fortifications  for it was here that the army faced the threat of invasion from France

Hence in the late seventeen nineties the entire staff of the Ordnance Survey was deployed in producing military maps of the southern counties 

These maps were of a scale of one inch to one mile  a scale of the order still found appropriate for military mapping throughout the world today and indeed the scale at which this Society had  inaugurated the county mapping of Britain 

The great attention  paid to  terrain and lines of communication  marked out these early maps as particularly suited to military use

This is part of the map of Kent  uh the North Foreland Isle of Sheppey  Canterbury in here Dover down here 

But you can see the very heavy marking of the escarpments which would of course in those days have been  uh very great barriers to military movement 

As the threat from France receded the Ordnance Survey began to produce one inch maps to a more orderly production pattern

And these were then modified perfected and updated  to become the much-loved one inch maps later one in fifty thousand maps  which today have such a very broad user base in education recreation way-finding and indeed still in defence 

The energies of the department were largely absorbed by this mapping eh during the early eighteen hundreds 

One of the busiest periods for Ordnance Survey was during the time of Major General Colby 's leadership 

He was appointed in eighteen twenty  and was the head of the department for twenty-seven years longer than any other 

And he was one of the more energetic and inventive of our directors 

He had a very deep and fundamental effect on the Survey 

And the ideas developed by him and under his guidance have affected the Department to this day 

Soon after his appointment  Thomas Colby was required to concentrate the effort of the Ordnance Survey on cadastral mapping of Ireland 

This mapping was needed for the proper and fair assessment of a land tax  the existing assessments having been shown by new surveys to be grossly inequitable in many cases 

Bearing in mind its purpose  the map needed to be accurate and at a fairly large scale 

To ensure the accuracy Colby 's surveyors triangulated the country to emplace trigonometrical control

And he chose a scale of six inches to one mile  to show the necessary detail 

At the start of the triangulation Colby measured a base line of about eight miles on the shores of Loch Foyle and this is a  sketch of base measurement being carried out 

the tentage is to protect the instruments and not the observers 

In measuring this base Colby showed his scientific bent by designing a new instrument  his compensating bars 

These were two strips of metal  with different coefficients of expansion and indicator arms attached by pivots to the ends of both bars

The measuring points were marked on the pivoting arms so that the distance between the points remained constant over a range of temperatures 

In fact we do at S oops sorry  at Southampton we have a set of Colby 's uh compensating bars in the  the museum 

And the bars are  sheltered in the wooden trough

And again there are microscopes at th the mounted at the far end for reading the fine marks

The uh trestles uh are uh placed uh uh uh so as to keep a constant height across the open ground 

Very slow process indeed 

But uh Colby 's work uh on this base was of such accuracy  that when uh the Loch Foyle base was remeasured with modern equipment in nineteen sixty  old and new measurements agreed to within one inch over the eight mile length 

That 's uh  about one part in five hundred thousand 

A remarkable achievement for that time 

By the end of Colby 's time with Ordnance Survey the work in Ireland had been completed and the department had moved to Southampton 

From its formation in seventeen ninety-one the Ordnance Survey had its drawing offices in the Tower of London 

And uh that 's a contemporary sketch of the Tower 

Uh our drawing offices were  in this building here 

Uh but unfortunately  in eighteen forty-one uh a great fire so damaged the those offices that the department had to find another home 

This was to be in an existing military establishment at Southampton 

And these buildings were to be the home of Ordnance Survey for the next one hundred years

They are the barrack buildings at London Road Southampton 

The question raised by the Moore case  was this 

If a patient 's tissues are used as source material for the  commercial development of biotechnology products  what property rights can the patient assert over his cells and the profits generated from the sale of those products 

Well this was the more or less revolutionary question put to the California Supreme Court a year or so ago 

Previously some ten years before that the United States Supreme Court had held in a previous case that patent protection extended to genetically engineered bacteria 

and one commentator then uh responded by stating that the bio-technology revolution had moved from the classroom to the boardroom and from the New England Journal of Medicine to the Wall Street Journal 

And since that case in nineteen eighty biotechnology has attracted massive investments and become a highly commercial industry 

The universities in these days when profit is as important as prophecy have not been left out of the race to exploit this new market 

The biotechnology research on human cells consists broadly of three technologies

Tissue and cultre cul uh cell culture technology hypodermic technology and recombinant D N A technology 

The promise of these methods is the development of new drugs and treatments which may alter conventional medicine 

The commercial value of these developments cannot be readily calculated

But as an example an estimate of the products from John Mer John Moore 's cell-lines based on his leukaemia cell was three billion dollars by the year nineteen ninety 

bio-technology has altered the practices of the medical research community

It 's also had an incalculable impact on the relationship between doctors and researchers and patients   when physicians are also researchers whose work on the patient can lead to financial profit 

The latter may take priority or at least advance the risk of seeming to conflict with duties towards patients 

The doctor who engages in biotechnological research uses as raw material his patient 's tissue and may from this develop commercial and profitable biotechnological uh and and may from this develop commercial and profitable biotechnological t technological products 

This may it need hardly be said lead to compromise over the patient 's best medical treatments to promote personal and commercial interests

For example the doctor may go beyond what is strictly necessary for treatment to obtain or to gain easier access to material for experimentation and commercial exploitation 

This dilemma has found a partial answer in the development of the doctrine of informed consent to include disclosure by the doctor-researcher of any personal academic or commercial interest in the patient 's cells or the specific treatment recommended 

Thus in soliciting the patient 's consent to treatment or the removal of tissues the doctor has to disclose any potential or other economic gain that he or anyone else so far as he knows may obtain from the post-operative use of the patient 's tissues 

Without such disclosure any consent received would not be informed or valid

In addition the doctor would be in breach of his fiduciary duty 

These are not my concerns here

The Moore case raises the possibility of the recognition of a property right over cells and other tissue

Should the law recognise human tissue as the personal property of the individual from three-or-four-words

Should the law permit the individual to sell his tissue

These are questions of deep moral significance 

The Moore court failed to meet the challenge 

What I 'm going to do is look at some of its reasoning and see why and then look at some of the moral and ethical issues that are involved

It 's an issue which I would suggest will not go away

and other courts and other institutions are bound in America and indeed I suspect in this country to be confronted with claims like the claim made by John Moore 

Now it all started in nineteen seventy-six when Moore learned he had hairy-cell leukaemia

He approached the medical centre of the University of California at Los Angeles and under the supervision of Dr David Gold the doctor who had attended Moore at U C L A he was hospitalised and went through a series of tests which included the withdrawal of extensive amounts of blood and cells 

It 's the case that at the time all five defendants were aware of the great commercial and scientific value of Moore 's cells 

On Dr Gold 's recommendation of treatment Moore signed a written consent form authorising the removal of his spleen 

Before the spleen was removed Gold had already given instructions that the removed splenar cells were to be transferred to separate research units 

These research activities had no relation to Moore 's medical care

He was not told

His permission was not sought 

In the next seven years Moore returned several more times to U C L A medical centre because he was told that this was medically necessary 

In fact on each visit Gold withdrew additional samples of blood skin bone marrow and sperm 

It 's assumed that throughout Gold and the medical centre were engaged in extensive research on Moore 's cells planning their commercial exploitation

In short this commercial expectation exploitation including establishing an immortal uh cell-line from Moore 's uh T-lymphocytes applying and securing a patent on the cell-line and entering with other defendants into the development and manufacture of important therapeutic drugs uh was  that they were on about

Dr uhm Gol uh Gold and his research assistant were in fact named as the inventors of these drugs

Now Moore never challenged the decision to remove his spleen 

It may have saved his life 

But he did attempt to state thirteen causes of action including conversion lack of informed consent breach of fiduciary duty fraud deceit and unjust enrichment and there wouldn't be much else that would be left 

The Court of Appeal for the Second District of California held that a person does have a tangible right to his own tissues and that conversion occurs when these bodily constituents were taken for any purpose without his consent

That court reasoned that since a person has the ultimate right to control his own body commercialization of a patient 's tissues by his doctor without prior consent could give rise to an action for damages 

The defendants ' appeal was held by a full Supreme Court in California

It can only It only considered three of Moore 's causes of action

Conversion breach of fiduciary duty and lack of informed consent

As to the conversion claim which is the one that I 'm going to be centring on the majority held that the cell-line could not be a patient 's property so that the conversion uh cause of action had to fail 

The court agreed claims as to breach of fiduciary duty and lack of informed consent did disclose causes of action

The b b majority in fact purports to show that Moore could achieve what he wanted under the latter causes of action

But it is the decision as to property rights on which I will concentrate

The reasoning of the court is poor often incoherent and it fails to live up I would suggest to you to the new challenges of biotechnology 

There is a   which does I think meet the challenge to some extent but I will make little reference to that 

The essence of a property issue was put like this by the court

First of all it characterises conversion as a tort that protects against interference with possessory and ownership interests in personal property

And then it goes on to say that Moore theorises that he continued owning those cells following their removal from his body at least for the purpose of directing their use and had never consented to their use in potentially lucrative medical research and that he moreover owned a proprietary interest in each of the products that any of the defendants might ever create from his cells or the patented cell-line 

Now in the majority opinion Moore 's allegation was examined under the existing law and found to be wanting 

No reported Common Law decision could be found which recognised human cells as capable of being the subject of property and of being converted 

They missed in fact or passed over an old Australian authority but it wasn't strictly relevant and I won't detain you with it 

The court went on to state what it considered to be several problems with the idea of ownership of cells 

Moore relied inter alia on the opinion of the United States courts that every person has a proprietary interest in his own likeness and alleged that if the courts had found a sufficiently proprietary interest in one 's persona how could one not have a right in one 's own genetic material something far more profoundly the essence of one 's human uniqueness than one 's name or face 

The court 's unsatisfactory response is that   genes have the same molecular structure in every human being and the same important functions in every human being 's immune system 

Moreover said the court a particular genetic material which is responsible for the natural production of the leukogene and which the defendants used in the manufacturing process is I quote also the same in every person

It is no more unique to Moore than the number of vertebrae in the spine or the chemical formula of haemoglobin 

This cannot be sustained

It surely is irrelevant for the tort of conversion that what is to be converted is to be found everywhere 

Property is based on the relationship between a person and an object 

The object That the object is one of a class commonly or even universally found is alien to the theory of property rights

Of course if Moore 's cells were really like everyone else 's they would not have been exploited for profit 

The fact that the genes though similar in every human being 's cell were arranged in a way which has value for the researchers make them unique not in their essence but in their ability to be used with a plaintiff 

The anomalous nature of the court 's reasoning can be demonstrated by imagining that Morm 's Moore 's spleen had been given to them in a formalin jar 

It could not then be unlawfully removed by the doctors or indeed anyone else 

The court also relied on Californian legislation dealing with the disposal of unwanted or used human tissue to dismiss Moore 's claim of ownership

The practical effect of this legislation said the court was to limit drastically a patient 's control over excised cells 

What the legislation did was restricting how excised cells could be used and requiring their eventual destruction

And said the court the statute eliminates as a result of this so many of the rights ordinarily attached to property that one cannot simply assume that what is left amounts to property or ownership for the purposes of conversion law

But this reasoning will not do 

The statute referred to tackles matters of public hygiene and to do this it limits rights 

It circumvents what a person may do with what is his

But it is no less his because he cannot do with it what he wishes

Implicit in the court 's reasoning is the assumption that ownership is absolute or it 's not ownership 

That this is wrong hardly I think needs demonstration

If it were correct it would make much twentieth century social legislation for example rent acts confiscatory and it would deny our property 

Furthermore what the court ignored is that the effect of the statute and its limitation would only take effect after the cells had been lawfully transferred to the researchers and the use of them terminated

The statute is actually of no relevance at all to the Moore case uh  because uh uh i i i i it is of no relevance at all to the transaction before the material becomes waste 

In any case it doesn't indicate that a doctor who removes uh the patient 's cells has a greater right to dispose of them than the patient himself 

The court refused then to recognise Moore 's property in the patent the patented cell-line and the products derived from it because the patented cell-line is said the court factually and legally distinct from the cells taken from Moore 's body 

The court asserted that what is protected by law is the patenting of organisms that represent the product of human ingenuity but not naturally occurring organisms

I believe that we now face  some months possibly some years  of very great danger 

The historic parallel of what is happening in the former Soviet Union  and to a lesser extent in Central and Eastern Europe  might be with the French Revolution

it 's too early to say 

That one can see the development of anarchy  that one can see the possibility of terror that one can recognise the possibility of the imposition of a new order  a new order itself both harsh and commanding 

all these things might happen 

They haven't happened yet 

It may be that the parallel is with the period of the  fall of the Tzar  the short-lived stage of the Mensheviks  who referred to the kind of common history of democracy that they shared with the Western countries at that time before they were replaced by the Bolsheviks and before Russia the Soviet Union plunged first into the brief  lit period of the new economic policy  and then into the terrible relentless darkness of Stalinism 

What we can say and need to say  is that we face something we have never before faced  the prospect of chaos in a nuclear world 

And it 's that prospect of chaos in a nuclear world that ought to I believe concentrate our minds  to try to respond to the challenge in more bold and unorthodox and imaginative ways than we have so far yet done 

I 'll come back to that 

but let me say that for many of us I believe the cold war was a kind of rigor mortis  a period during which nobody had to think very hard politically  about relations between the superpowers  a period in which the apolyptic apocalyptic threat of nuclear weapons meant that both the superpowers accepted the so-called mad scenario  the mutually destructive position of deterrents  and both sides believed that neither would actually risk unleashing a nuclear war 

Hence both Americans and Russians and their allies could rest reasonably comfortably in bed  because we lived in a world that was locked  between the superpower deterrents 

Of course many people since the Second World War have died  in broiling quarrels and civil wars in Africa in Asia in Central America 

There have been hundreds and thousands of deaths 

but all of them brought about by conventional weapons some of them supplied by all of us in the Western countries 

Terrible as they have been  the death squads in South Africa and El Salvador  the massacre of the Kurds  the destruction more recently of people and of priceless buildings  in what was  the Croatian section of Yugoslavia  the rich insulated western world has only felt itself to be marginally affected 

There have been moments when our insulation has been broken through  the agony for many veterans who served in Vietnam which goes on to this day the concern of relief workers working in places as different as orphanages in Cambodia or Aids hospitals in Rumania 

such men and women have felt the pressure of what France Surname called the wretched of the earth

but most of us live in a strange charmed circle  relatively rich countries where above all our newspapers and we ourselves are preoccupied with President Bush 's lips and Mr Major 's tea leaves

It is if I may say so a somewhat inadequate response to the terrible challenges of our time 

We were for many many months  reluctant to recognise that the Soviet Union was disintegrating 

I went there in September  to be an adviser on the construction of the constitution of the Russian Federation and we paid a visit to the Kremlin to try and discover what was happening to the constitution of the Union

We met a charming young man who was trying to write on the back of as far as I could tell an envelope  one or two amendments to the Union constitution 

He clearly believed in it no much more than we did and he smiled at us winningly and said  the kitchen is very hot here  he meant the Kremlin 

the only problem is there are no dishes in it

There were no dishes in it though the West went on believing in the Union long after it had effectively died 

Let me then say that today we at long last confront the scale of the crisis 

Today in Long Island  perhaps an appropriate place given the connection with the Great Gatsby  the countries of the West are meeting to discuss  emergency aid to the former Soviet Union 

Today at the request of Mr Baker  they are discussing what Mr Baker has outlined to them when he said a social and political explosion is a very real possibility 

But we have lost a tremendous amount of time  time in which the Western powers simply failed to respond  time that went on through the whole of nineteen ninety and nineteen ninety-one and where we are still effectively I believe underestimating the scale of what is required for us 

Let me then ask the first of a few questions 

What happened since the singing days of the velvet revolution  when we watched the collapse of the communist empire  fatally weakened by the unwillingness of Mikhail Gorbachev to use force to maintain its power 

One of the first things that happened was the coming to power in Central and Eastern Europe  and today of course in the former Soviet Union  of new leaders  immensely gifted  immensely brave people  but by the nature of things  utterly inexperienced 

The people that Eastern Europe chose to lead it  were people who had been least damaged  by living a lie 

They were often musicians philosophers physicists  men and women who had chosen these professions specifically because they could still bear some witness to the truth 

Their great strength was that they had never been involved in the politics of the old regime 

Their great weakness is that they have never been involved in politics at all 

But one of the things  I think we have sadly learned is that politicians  for all their poor reputation  are in fact indispensable in democracies 

The second thing that happened  was that much of the bureaucracy was dubiously loyal at best and in almost every case passive detached uncommitted to the velvet revolution

I remember being  at a dinner addressed by the Foreign Secretary of one of the Eastern European democracies  and looking at a worn-out young woman who was sitting beside me so tired that she could hardly stand 

I said to her why don't you let one of your other colleagues go next time the minister goes abroad 

you 're obviously absolutely tired out 

And she said

I can't

and I said

oh

come now

let somebody else have a chance 

She said I can't because there 's nobody else in the Foreign Secretary 's office that he can trust 

The instance therefore of a passive and sullen bureaucracy is much more important than it would be in the United Kingdom or the United States

The reason that it 's so important is because the bureaucracy was the transmission belt of these command economies in the way that the market is the transition transmission belt for Western economies 

Therefore the bureaucracy in the period of transition  is of even greater importance than it would be in our own democracies

It is a bureaucracy which is virtually unreformed 

I was told  only a week ago by a Minister of the Interior  that up until May nineteen ninety in his Ministry there had been  Soviet policy analysts who among other things were armoured with guns and who gave instructions to his Ministry as to how they should behave

He said to us it 's strange to get used to having to make the decisions yourselves 

Two final examples of some of the things that have made the transition so difficult 

First the absence of a civil society 

The more time I spend in Eastern Europe and in the former Soviet Union  the more conscious I become of how important a civil society is

What does one mean by that

One means by that the fabric of voluntary organisation  open relationships  a willingness for people to move together to try to change and alter and sustain things

One means in effect  the social contract about which John Locke wrote at the end of the seventeenth century  and which has been perhaps been one of the greatest inheritances of the Anglo-Saxon world 

In the absence of a civil society and at least to a very considerable extent it doesn't really exist in the post-Communist societies  what one gets is a pervasive distrust  what Vaclav Havel described as a moral vacuum 

And in a situation where there 's a moral vacuum  the absence of any certain borders  the absence of any settled nationality tends to mean that rootless populations and beleaguered minorities  feel themselves and indeed are  considerably at risk 

In the case of the transition looking for a moment at the economic sphere let me again mention a few factors that I believe have been important 

Excessive expectations  in effect the result of television  led many people in Central and Eastern Europe to believe that democracy  equalled the market  equalled immediate prosperity 

One of the great sources of disillusion in Central and Eastern Europe has been the extreme slowness of economic prosperity to break through 

This has been made  the more so by the lack of entrepreneurial experience in almost all the countries of which I 'm speaking  which is perhaps best summed up by a story that I will mention in a moment that I get from the Ukraine  but which shows the extent to which  the ability to  do deals  to fix influence  to reach those who you can  manage to get favours from  is much more important in these societies than the ability to manage  the ability to market  the ability to invent 

And it 's only gradually that people with the qualities required for success in a command economy can develop the qualities that are required to succeed in a free market economy 

But one of the problems  that is summed up in the story I will tell you from Ukraine  is the problem of believing that the state will provide all that has to be provided 

The story goes like this

An Englishman a Frenchman and a Russian were discussing what was their heart 's desire

The Frenchman said

my heart 's desire is to be married to a woman so beautiful that everybody else in the room is jealous of me 

The Englishman said

my heart 's desire is to have a great estate  with beautiful thoroughbred horses galloping around it 

And the Russian said

my heart 's desire is that my neighbour Ivan 's donkey shall die tomorrow morning  

Uncertainty about ownership is of course another factor that has made the economic transition difficult 

Even now in Hungary where I just left this morning  one sees the argument going on between the political parties

On the one side Fidesz a remarkable party which has an age limit of thirty-five for its members of Parliament  saying that it 's inappropriate to compensate people who owned land and owned property  forty-five years ago  that history must look after its own  a line must be drawn  and transitions must be allowed to go ahead without consideration for these historic concerns

On the other side the Smallholders ' Party  so utterly determined to make sure that every last penny of rehabilitation is paid to the old owners  that it 's now announcing it will leave the Hungarian government coalition unless its desires are met in full 

And one final example  one that perhaps comes closer to the heart to the heart of our Chairman 

and that is  that in a sense what is now clear I believe about the inner weakness of the command economy structure is that it was unable to make the transition  to information-based technologies 

I had the pleasure yesterday of talking at length  to one of the leading experts of the C M E A the Comicon economic group 

And he said

one of the things that the West has not appreciated  is that the Soviet Union absolutely refused to allow the diffusion of any technological advances from its defence industries to its civilian industries and from either to the other members of the pact  in other words  to Central Europe 

And consequently therefore in a way  the Soviet Union killed its own economic union  because it was unable to move and to adapt to the new technological revolution that was overtaking the advanced economies 

The whole concept of the degree of discretion of judgement of innate willingness to initiate and manage  that flows from a society of personal computers and networks between them  was one that was fundamentally deeply alien to the hierarchical structure of a command society

I was reflecting as I left the Department  eight years ago  on changes in the British ports industry 

This industry  had long been in the public eye  as marked by immobilised rusting cranes  dilapidated buildings a poor history in health and safety  and endemic bad industrial relations 

But the technology of the container was there as well 

In the private sectors Felixstowe  in the public sectors National Docks Board  and in the Trust Ports half way between 

It wasn't one form of organisation which was showing the way 

The National Ports Council  led in turn by Philip Chappel and Sir John Page  together with my excellent colleagues of the Department  the late and much beloved John Sanderson  and in Scotland  Ronald Gibbs  made a crucial largely unnoticed contribution by finding talent for the industry 's boards and top jobs 

Technology and people were at work 

Well I said  in nineteen eighty-two  that within ten years the ports ' industry would 've become a showpiece of British commerce  looking like a tidy site in the hands of an excellent clerk of works  colourful clean efficient safe and competitive 

Well I was wrong about it being a showplace 

its achievement has passed largely unnoticed 

If we 're going to uh look at the future with reasonable assurance we must at least  pick processes which can be seen to be at work already  which exercise wide influence  and which would require something cataclysmic to stem or reverse them 

Uh

this will bring us to some questions about what can reasonably be expected from organised government  operating within a framework of nations  in which nationhood  is regarded as incomplete  unless it entails sovereignty 

Perhaps something has to be given up now  to public opinion formed on a wider base than a nation 

Then we can go back to look at what would be seen on Judgement Day as what we could 've done 

What should the inhabitants of the British Isles try to do  in an age in which the world will be involved in inter-relationships suffusing the whole of its surface  with the people of the world as spectator of events  at the moment when they occur 





Uh transoceanic commerce is one of these inter-relationships

The common heritage of science is another  so is the aspiration to add to it so is the distribution or the maldistribution of food and medicine  so is the world 's endowment of trees  and of fuel  so are all the arts and technologies of communication 

Language is a technology of communication

But languages may be a barrier to communication as well as a medium of it 

In the past differences between languages  often given another dimension by differences between scripts as well  have impeded understanding between societies and for long periods limited discovery 

One example has been at China 's frontiers 

Another from which we suffer still  has been of the divide between Christendom and Islam 

Sometimes language has become inadvertently or otherwise an instrument of exclusion 

When Latin uh what what Latin was to the medieval cleric 's virtual monopoly of literacy  technical language may be to the modern possessor of special knowledge  or jargon to the pretence of it 

In past ages individual study apart  languages have been tied closely to geography largely because most people in their lifetimes generation after generation  did not have the transport to move away  unless they were driven to do it on foot  by force or famine 

What I want to claim is  that communication now extends far beyond language  because of technologies which have matured from infancy during the twentieth century 

Those of radio and television are no respecters of national boundaries  though political regimes have histories of trying to jam them 

Television being visual largely circumvents language as a means of reporting 

It is ironic that the power of the technological media to penetrate  has been enhanced by the ballistics of rocketry  the development which  uh was accelerated first by Hitler 's concern to acquire the V Two weapon  and then by the political rivalry to be first on the moon 

The important point is  that the technology  has arrived 

At the same time  aviation reached the stage at which it became the instrument of military force 

This seemed to establish its importance in national politics 

It then moved on to demonstrate that force has only a negative return 

And aviation had a second child  in the form of mass international tourism  which as a form of communication  owes very little to national politics  but it has enhanced the world 's social life perhaps more than anything else 

So technology has breached barriers of geography and also with some resistance those of national politics 

It is also pitched directly against barriers of language 

Electronic aids to learning languages help to overcome these barriers and the apparatus of simultaneous translation helps to set them aside 

But  people who can converse in languages other than their own  as I can not  advance the cause of civilisation 

Technology is not the only force at work  uh towards wider understanding 

Political history has created a current too  rather inadvertently 

Britain 's commercial naval and colonial past  has made the English language the prevailing first language in the official and international commercial circles  of the fifty countries of the Commonwealth  which include one thousand four hundred million people or more than one in four of the world 's population 

That same history planted English geographically  so that it became the founding and bonding language of the United States  though the occasion was the defeat of British colonial power 

English has held its place in the U S A  in spite of the enormous range of ancestral ethnic origins  and their changing proportions among her people 

The significance of this fact is vastly magnified  by the importance which the United States economy assumed  as a massive force in the world 's commerce  and in international aid 

Consequently as Japan and other strongly commercial states in the Pacific basin  have become major players  and expect to become greater ones still  in international trade  they have taken pains to be proficient in English as their second language if not their first one 

The People 's Republic of China has been pursuing the same end for years  not without some valued help from this house 

Another and perhaps conclusive feature of the twentieth century  is that for air traffic control a single language has become more and more obviously necessary

The language n which now predominates in the air is English 

Now nothing that I 've said implies any sort of cultural judgement between languages any more than Latin as the lingua franca of learning in Europe  in the Middle Ages would be judged superior to Greek as a vehicle of culture 

The Eu European Community  sets an excellent example  by its proper cultural respect for the separate languages of its member states

But that respect is due to the whole literary tradition of mankind  in the ancient and modern civilisations of the west  to say nothing of the Middle East  or of the Far East 

Literature in all its forms is one thing

Convenience of communication and commerce is another 

Both have their place 

My point is that language of convenient communication which used to be the hallmark of nations has become the property of the whole world 

To reverse the technological achievements of the twentieth century in communications or in aviation  and to lose access to the sciences on which they are founded  would entail such cataclysm  that it can have no part in the probabilities of prediction 

Political forces could release nuclear annihilation  which could be sufficiently cataclysmic 

But predictions wouldn't then matter  so there 's no point in not carrying the achievements of science and technology forward as realistic components in the future

They carry their own primacy over political forces in any form with which we 're familiar 

Galileo proved to be right 

and the princes of the day to be wrong 

Well I suppose that by daring to attempt uh to look into the future  I lay myself open to a demand to produce some projections about the size of the world 's population and alongside that the volume of s life-sustaining resources that may be deployed in the world 

Well you all know that Malthus said two hundred years ago 

population when unchecked increases in a geometrical ratio 

Subsistence only increases in an arithmetical ratio 

Well there 's a hideous ring of truth about that statement  when we think of it in terms of localities  where we have seen populations rising and famine occurring

But we have also seen different things happening in different parts of the world 

Within the last twenty years the People 's Republic of China  became so fearful of the population outstripping the means of subsistence within her frontiers  that Peking if I can still call it like that  decreed restraint of parenthood  under penalty  to one child for each couple 

But society in China has to reckon also  with a golden tradition of the young generation caring for the old in the family circle  and with a black tradition of female infanticide 

The matter will not end with a decree 

In India Pakistan and Bangladesh there 's a huge population subsisting within a democratic tradition in general support of education directed both to establishing birth control and also to reducing infant mortality 

There are just a lot of people to teach 

In south-east Asia and in South America there 's less of a tradition of democracy less articulation of the consequences of the birth rate among the very poor but there 's also less evident inadequacy of natural resources 

In Soviet Russia the prospect is of the population of White Russia growing no more while the Islamic population of the southern republics continues to grow 

Shortages of food have been a repeated feature of recent Soviet experience  with heavy dependence on grain imported from the United States as the Soviets ' own production has failed 

But the spotlight has been on empty shops in the towns rather than empty larders in the countryside 

It is to Africa that the television cameras go to show what happens when local natural resources are so inadequate for the population living off them that drought or continuous small-arms war causes famine for the people counted in millions and death for many of them 

Apart from such disasters in succession in the same or in different places infant mortality is the main counter to the birth rate 's effect in Africa 

and in parts of the continent the heterosexual incidence of Aids may prove to have halted or even reversed the growth in the population of potential parents and condemned large numbers of children to early death 

I infer from this all too swift outline of the world 's population at the threshold of the twenty-first century not that it is proved that there 's not enough nutriment to go round but that it is clear that there 's not enough of taking it round 

Yet we collect ours from all over the world and know how it can be stored 

I wonder whether anything has proved more effective in reducing the birth rate than a rising standard of living 

Perhaps we need another Malthus  uh to uh deliver  a new message

I was led to Robert McNamara as my authority by Susan George 's memorable book How the Other Half Die  which she published in nineteen seventy-six

but the prime cause of my desire to know about this was the work of my late brother Kenneth  who spent and lost his life trying to raise the livelihoods of African populations above subsistence 

He learned and taught that where there is no livelihood to be earned except from the land  it is better use of local agricultural conditions and only that can lay the foundations of better life

In Bangladesh it was less than ten per cent

In Africa only five per cent

I think I 've set myself a very difficult if not impossible task in trying to talk about prosodic analysis  and its place in linguistics in just forty-five minutes 

Two reasons

First of all because  what is subsumed under prosodic analysis doesn't really  constitute a single totally self-consistent theory 

It 's rather a set of proposals made by a number of different scholars 

And secondly I obviously can't do justice in sus in such a short time  to the exposition of the ways in which this theory differed from other views at the time 

Prosodic analysis had its origins in a number of articles written by J R Firth in the nineteen-thirties 

But almost all of the relevant papers were produced by Firth and members of the staff and students from the Department of Phonetics and Linguistics  who became later known as the London School  between nineteen forty-eight and nineteen and the middle nineteen-sixties 

Firth 's early works uh were collected and published by him in Papers In Linguistics

I have listed in fact all relevant things as you 'll see on the sheet 

Uhm if you haven't got one you should have collected one from the uhm  table over there 

They were collected in Papers In Linguistics nineteen thirty fou one four to nineteen fifty-one which Firth himself edited 

And a collection of his later works found in Selected Papers in  nineteen fifty-two fifty-nine  but none of these articles in that volume dealt specifically with prosodic theory 

He was n already  turning his attention to other interests

But a collection of sixteen papers on prosodic analysis  all of which had been published previously  between nineteen forty-eight and nineteen sixty-one  together with a bibliography of ninety items is to be found in Prosodic Analysis nineteen seventy of which I was the editor 

Most of the peop papers had already appeared in journals especially the  of the school 

but a set of original papers was also published under the title of Studies In Linguistic Analysis  in nineteen fifty-seven 

For an excellent contemporary account of the theory I would advise you to look at Robins ' Aspects Of Prosodic Analysis nineteen fifty-seven 

It is generally known that the most imp obvious point about prosodic analysis was its complete rejection of most of the beliefs or dogmas of the American Structuralist version of the phoneme theory  which had its origins in the work of Bloomfield but had been developed and made rigorous  that was a favourite term of the age  by scholars such as Bloch  Hockett  Harris and Pike 

The most important articles written by these so-called post-Bloomfieldians were with the exception of the works of Pike  for reasons that I shall explain later  republished in Readings In Linguistics  edited by Martin Jones in nineteen fifty-eight 

But it 's important to realise and to remember that Firth also worked during the nineteen thirties  in the Department of Phonetics at University College London  then headed by Daniel Jones  who was as equally committed to the phoneme  as were his American contemporaries 

Jones 's work was often quoted in American works in the early nineteen thirties it 's quoted for instance or in the nineteen thirties

in fact it 's quoted for instance in the article by name which I mention down here and on the uniqueness of phonemic solutions  and also  by uhm  by Twaddell  uh On Defining The Phoneme 

But it was almost completely ignored  in the so-called rigorous publications of the nineteen forties 

Undoubtedly there are two aspects of prosodic analysis  that clearly distinguish it from the American-style phonemics 

For in phonemics  speech could and must be segmented into discrete segments  linearly arranged in sequence 

These were the phonemes  and it was held that there was a single l limited inventory of such elements  all with the same theoretical status  and that the phonological description of a text  was entirely stateable in terms of the distribution of such phonemes 

By contrast the emphasis in prosodic analysis  was on non-segmental features which were not aligned not arranged in linear sequence  and on the view that there was not a single inventory of phonological units  but a number of different systems that might or might not have shared members or terms 

In this sense the approach was said to be both non-segmental and polysystemic  in contrast with the segmental and monosystemic phonemics 

Prosodic analysis was I suppose born  with the publication of uh Sounds And Prosodies in nineteen forty eight 

though of equal if not perhaps of greater importance for the development of the theory was Henderson 's Prosodies in Siamese  nineteen forty nine  which was published by as you see in the following year 

While Firth 's work is programmatic and discursive  and it 's often difficult to understand precisely what he intended  Henderson 's article  showed how the theory could be applied and can perhaps be seen as a classic exposition of it 

In fact however  although in the spirit of Sounds And Prosodies it took the theory in a direction that Firth may not perhaps fully have expected  and it provided the model for most of the later works 

In Sounds And Prosodies  Firth aims to distinguish prosodic systems from what he calls phonematic systems  taking as he says words as his I quote principal isolates 

He avoids the word phoneme preferring sound and this explains the title of the article 

Using the familiar symbols of C and V for consonant and vowel  he is first able  to extract to establish the syn syntagmatic syllabic structures of words  and then to abstract the features which he says mark  word and syllable initials  word and syllable finals or word functions  and to regard these  syntagmatically as prosodies  distinct from the phonematic constituents which are units of the consonant and vowel systems 

It was entirely  in that paper 

No I 'm sorry in a later paper 

He later talks about the syllabic structure 

I beg your pardon in that paper 

He later talks about syllabic structure with properties such as initial final and medial characteristics the number and nature of the syllables quantity stress and tone 

The distinction seems to me clear and distinction uh clear and simple 

The features that can be stated in terms of syllabic or word structure are prosodic 

These features are abstracted  and what remains makes up a paradigmatic uhm vowel and consonant systems  the terms of which are the phonematic units 

It would appear from what he says that he recognises three different types of prosody  first the world the word and syllab syllabic structure itself  secondly the features of quantity stress and tone  which are of course prosodic in the traditional sense  and thirdly the features to be abstracted as characteristics of syllable and word final medial and and initial 

It was with this last type that much of the later prosodic analysis was concerned  especially with what were called the W and Y prosodies  but also with features such as nasalization openness etc 

Firth provided some examples  but he was in fact apparently more interested at the time in matters of syllabic structure than with this last type 

Indeed in discussing  c parallel colloquial Arabic he had eight prosodies  of which only one  and that is what he called the clear or dark  on the syllable is of this  third kind 

Similarly an analysis of a stretch of English marks as prosodies stress and intonation  analysis into schwa  with V and C and what he calls junctions  that link some words phonologically 

Henderson 's Prosod Prosodies in Siamese  unlike Sounds and Prosodies is largely descriptive  and introduces  many of the features that were seen  later to be typical prosodies 

Its aim is to present a prosodic analysis in terms of a hierarchy  beginning with a sentence  and working downwards  to the vowels and to the consonants 

There are therefore  from the top downwards in the hierarchy  prosodies of the sentence  prosodies of sentence parts  prosodies of polysyllables  prosodies of syllables and prosodies of syllable parts 

And finally there are the paradigmatic consonantal and vocalic phonematic units 

The work begins with monosyllables with a description of the gma of the prosodies of syllable beginning  the prosodies of syllable ending  and the prosodies of the syllable as a whole 

This is the most striking exemplification  of what was to become the main thrust of the theory 

In phonemic terms  Siamese has an inventory of twenty consonants in initial position  but only seven in final position 

But the initial and final consonants  differ greatly in terms of their phonetic features 

These differences  made it possible to abstract all the features associated with initial position only  features of plosion  aspiration  voice  except the nos nasality  affrication friction lateralisation rhoticisation and labialisation 

And these were the prosodies of syllable beginning 

But once all these features were abstracted  the number of consonantal contrasts  including those of consonant consonant clusters is greatly reduced 

No longer was it necessary to recognise twenty different consonants  and eleven consonant clusters initially 

Instead there is a system of only six  which Henderson symbolized as k p t uhm eng long-tailed n m n and zero 

Thus what were phonemically t  t h and d  are an all analysed as t with initial prosodies  of plosion plosion with aspiration plosion with voice respectively 

And there 's an anal similar analysis  for all the other consonants

for instance k h r  is k with the prosodies of plosion aspiration and rhoticisation 

The importance of the analysis of syllable parts as a model for later scholars  must not disguise the fact that analysis in terms of a hierarchy  that applies prosodic analysis to all the constituents of a sentence  is a proper aim for a theory 

and Henderson 's articles  Henderson 's article was by far the most successful in this respect 

I think perhaps it may however be said  that the case  it may be said perhaps that the overall neatness and completeness of her analysis  was possible only for a language such as Siamese 

Although nineteen forty eight and nineteen forty nine are such important dates for prosodic analysis  the origins of it are to be found in Firth 's works during the nineteen thirties 

In for instance Phonological Features Of Some Indian Languages nineteen thirty five  he discusses voice aspiration and length  and says that nasals and nasalization I quote raise fundamental problems for phonetic and phonological theory 

He also talks about systematic relations between the letters of an alternance  and he recognises a two term alternance of nasal initially  with a three term alternance finally 

Here we find  the first signs of his interest in non-segmental features  and in the notion of multiple systems 

There are similar ideas in other works notably in the Technique Of Semantics  nineteen thirty five  which was regarded as his major prewar prewar work 

but it is in The Structure Of The Chinese Monosyllable In A Hunanese Dialect  nineteen thirty seven that he argues explicitly for distinct places in the syllable 

and he rejects the notion that the vowel alternations in a syllable with final nasals should be identified with vowels in other contexts 

And he further says  the yoticisation and labialisation differences may be regarded as syllabic diacritical diacritica  and not as being placed 

Placed he put in quotes again put in quotes himself 

Yoticisation and la labial velarisation  are of course  what were to become the familiar Y and W prosodies 

The term prosodic unit the term prosodic is used here  but only to refer to features such as tone 

But he thinks it with these other features when he says  the prosodic diacritica  and to a certain extent what we have termed yoticisation yotisation and labial velari velarisation  are characteristics of the syllable as a whole 

It 's interesting to note that some years later  he presented a copy of that article  to Eugenie Henderson and wrote on it

and I quote 

this was the first quote non-phonemic end of quote article published in English  and the first to separate the again quoted  in quotes by him successive or quotes by him placed  units from those which are not placed  and may be regarded as non-successive 

People have passed it by in English in England  because the principles were lost in the detail  but quite a new theory is here implied 

There is also a comment in the margin of the page where he discusses initial consonants in terms of consonantal types  aspiration tensity voice difference etc  and the differentiation of the syllable in terms of yoticisation and libo labial velarisation

The truth the truth is Mr Speaker  that in many aspects of politics  style and substance  complement each other

Mr Speaker the Prime Minister and I  have shared together  something like seven hundred meetings  of cabinet or shadow cabinet  over the last eighteen years 

Some some four hundred hours alongside each other  at more than thirty international summit meetings 

For both of us I suspect that 's a pretty daunting record 

The House might well feel that something more than simple matters of style  will be necessary to rupture such a well-tried relationship 

It was indeed a privilege to serve as my right honourable friend 's first Chancellor of the Exchequer  to share in the transformation of our industrial relations scene  to help launch our free market programme commencing with the abolition of exchange control  and above all  to achieve such substantial success against inflation  getting it down within four years from twenty-two to four per cent  upon the basis of the strict monetary discipline involved in the medium term financial strategy 

Not one of our economic achievements would have been possible  without the courage and the leadership of my right honourable friend 

And if I may say so Mr Speaker  they possibly derived some little benefit  from the presence of a Chancellor  who wasn't exactly a wet himself 

It was too a great honour  to serve for six years as Foreign and Commonwealth Secretary  and to share with my right honourable friend  in some in some notable achievements  in the European Community  from Fontainebleau to the Single European Act 

But it was as we moved on to consider the crucial monetary issues  in the European context  that I 've come to feel increasing concern 

Some of the reasons for this anxiety  were made very clear  by my right honourable friend the member for Blaby  in his resignation speech just over twelve months ago 

For like him I concluded at least five years back  that the conduct of our policy against inflation  could no longer rest solely  on attempts to measure and control the domestic money supply 

We had no doubt  that we should be helped in that battle and indeed in other respects  by joining the exchange rate mechanism  of the European monetary system 

There was or should have been nothing novel about joining the E R M 

It 's been a long-standing commitment  and we 'd found for a quarter of a century after the Second World War  that the very similar Bretton Woods regime  did serve as a useful discipline  and now as my right honourable friend the Prime Minister has acknowledged two weeks ago  our entry into the Exchange Rate Mechanism can indeed be seen  as an extra discipline for keeping down inflation 

But it must be said  that this important practical conclusion  has only been achieved  at the cost of substantial damage  to her own administration  and more serious still  to its inflation achievement 

For as my right honourable friend the member for Blaby has explained  the real tragedy is  that we did not join the Exchange Rate Mechanism at least five years ago

That was as he also made clear  not for want of trying 

Indeed the so-called Madrid Conditions came into existence  only after the then Chancellor of the Exchequer and myself as Foreign Secretary  made it clear that we could not continue in office  unless a specific commitment to join the Exchange Rate Mechanism was made 

As the House will no doubt have observed  neither member of that particular partnership now remains in office 

Our successor as Chancellor of the Exchequer  has during the last year  had to devote a good deal of his considerable talent  to demonstrating exactly how those Madrid conditions have been attained   so as to make it  so as to make it possible to fulfil to fulfil a commitment  whose achievement has long been in the national interest 

It is now alas  impossible to resist the conclusion  that today 's higher rates of inflation  could well have been avoided  had the question of E R M membership  been properly considered and resolved  at a much earlier stage 

There are I fear developing grounds for similar anxieties  over the handling not just at and after the Rome summit  of the wider much more open question of economic and monetary union 

Let me first make clear  certain important points on which I have  no disagreement  with my right honourable friend 

I do not regard the Delors Report as some kind of sacred text  that has to be accepted or even rejected on the nod  but it is an important working document 

As I 've often made plain  it is seriously deficient in significant respects 

I do not regard the Italian presidency 's management  of the Rome Summit as a model of its kind   Far

far from it 

It was much the same as my right honourable friend the Prime Minister will recall in Milan some five years befo five years ago 

I do not regard it  as in any sense wrong for Britain to make criticisms of that kind  plainly and courteously  nor in any sense wrong  for us to do so if necessary alone 

As I 've already made clear  I have like the Prime Minister and other right honourable friends  fought too many European battles in a minority of one to have any illusions on that score 

But it is crucially important  that we should conduct those arguments  upon the basis of a clear understanding  of the true relationship between this country  the Community  and our Community partners 

And it is here I fear  that my right honourable friend  increasingly risks leading herself and others astray  in matters of substance  as well as of style 

It was the late Lord Stockton formerly Harold Macmillan  who first put the central point clearly 

As long ago as nineteen sixty-two  he argued that we had to place and keep ourselves  within the European Community 

He saw it as essential then as it is today  not to cut ourselves off  from the realities of power  not to retreat  into a ghetto of sentimentality about our past  and so diminish our own control over our own destiny in the future 

The pity is  that the Macmillan view  had not been perceived more clearly a decade before in the nineteen fifties 

It would have spared us so many of the struggles of the last twenty years  had we been in the Community from the outset  had we been ready  in the much too simple phrase  to surrender some sovereignty  at a much earlier stage 

If we had been in from the start  as almost everybody now acknowledges  we should have had more not less influence  over the Europe in which we live today 

We should never forget the lesson of that isolation  of being on the outside looking in  for the conduct of today 's affairs 

We have done best  when we 've seen the Community not as a static entity to be resisted and contained  but as an active process which we can shape often decisively  provided we allow ourselves to be fully engaged in it  with confidence with enthusiasm  and in good faith 

We must at all costs  avoid presenting ourselves yet again  with an over-simplified choice  a false antithesis  a bogus dilemma  between one alternative  starkly labelled  cooperation between independent sovereign states and a second equally crudely labelled alternative  centralised federal superstate  as if there were no middle way in between 

We commit a serious error  if we think always in terms of surrendering sovereignty  and seek to stand pat for all time on a given deal  by proclaiming as my right honourable friend the Prime Minister did two weeks ago  that we have surrendered enough 

The European enterprise  is not and should not be seen like that as some kind of  zero sum gain 

Sir Winston Churchi Churchill put it much more positively  forty years ago when he said 

is it not possible  and not less agreeable  to regard this sacrifice or merger of national sovereignty  as the gradual assumption by all nations concerned  of that larger sovereignty  which can alone protect their diverse and distinctive customs and characteristics of their national traditions 

I have to say Mr Speaker that I find Winston Churchill 's perception  a good deal more convincing  and more encouraging for the interests of our nation  than the nightmare image sometimes conjured up by my right honourable friend  who seems who seems sometimes to look out  upon a Continent  that is positively teeming with ill-intentioned people  scheming in her words to extinguish democracy  to dissolve our national identities  to lead us through the back door into a federal Europe 

What kind of vision is that Mr Speaker  for our business people who trade there each day  for our financiers who seek to make London the money capital of Europe or for all the young people of today 

These concerns are especially important  as we approach the crucial topic  of economic and monetary union 

We must be positively  and centrally involved in this debate and not fearfully and negatively detached 

The costs of disengagement here  could be very serious indeed
